313716_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	We are a global designer, manufacturer and distributor of machine tools, specializing in precision computer numerically controlled metal-cutting machines.
313716_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	The Company has the following direct and indirect wholly owned subsidiaries:
313716_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	We have manufacturing facilities located in Switzerland, Taiwan, the United States, China, and the United Kingdom.
313716_11_ITEM1_P3_S1	We manufacture the majority of the products we sell.
313716_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	Unless otherwise mentioned or unless the context requires otherwise, all references to "Hardinge," "we," "us," "our," "the Company" or similar references mean Hardinge Inc. and its predecessors together with its subsidiaries.
313716_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metal-cutting turning machines, grinding machines, vertical machining centers, and accessories related to those machines.
313716_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	We have been a manufacturer of industrial-use high precision and general precision turning machine tools since 1890.
313716_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	Turning machines, or lathes, are power-driven machines used to remove material from either bar stock or a rough-formed part by moving multiple cutting tools against the surface of a part rotating at very high speeds in a spindle mechanism.
313716_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	The multi-directional movement of the cutting tools allows the part to be shaped to the desired dimensions.
313716_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	On parts produced by our machines, those dimensions are often measured in millionths of an inch.
313716_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	leader in the field of producing machines capable of consistently and cost-effectively producing parts to very close dimensions.
313716_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	Grinding is a machining process in which a part's surface is shaped to closer tolerances with a rotating abrasive wheel or tool.
313716_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	Grinding machines can be used to finish parts of various shapes and sizes.
313716_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	The grinding machines of our Kellenberger subsidiary are used to grind the inside and outside diameters of cylindrical parts.
313716_11_ITEM1_P9_S3	Such grinding machines are typically used to provide a more exact finish on a part that has been partially completed on a lathe.
313716_11_ITEM1_P9_S4	The grinding machines of Kellenberger, which are manufactured in both computer and manually controlled models, are generally purchased by the same type of customers as other Hardinge equipment and further our ability to be a primary source for our customers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	Our Kellenberger precision grinding technology is complemented by the Hauser and Tschudin grinding brands.
313716_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	Hauser machines are jig grinders used to make demanding contour components, primarily for tool and mold-making applications.
313716_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	Tschudin product technology is focused on the specialized grinding of cylindrical parts when the customer requires high volume production.
313716_11_ITEM1_P11_S2	Our Tschudin machines are generally equipped with automatic loading and unloading mechanisms for the part being machined.
313716_11_ITEM1_P11_S3	These loading and unloading mechanisms significantly reduce the level of involvement a machine operator has to perform in the production process.
313716_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	During 2010, the Company established Jones Shipman Grinding Limited after acquiring the assets of Jones and Shipman, a UK-based manufacturer of grinding and super-abrasive machines and machining systems.
313716_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	Jones Shipman manufactures and distributes a range of high-quality grinding (surface, creep feed and cylindrical) machines used by a diverse range of industries.
313716_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	Machining centers cut material differently than a turning machine.
313716_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	These machines are designed to remove material from stationary, prismatic or box-like parts of various shapes with rotating tools that are capable of milling, drilling, tapping, reaming and routing.
313716_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	Machining centers have mechanisms that automatically change tools based on commands from a built-in computer control without the assistance of an operator.
313716_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	Machining centers are generally purchased by the same customers who purchase other Hardinge equipment.
313716_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	We supply a broad line of machining centers under the Bridgeport brand name addressing a range of sizes, speeds and powers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	Our machines are generally computer controlled and use commands from an integrated computer to control the movement of cutting tools, grinding wheels, part positioning, and in the case of turning and grinding machines, the rotation speeds of the part being shaped.
313716_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The computer control enables the operator to program operations such as part rotation, tooling selection and tooling movement for a specific part and then store that program in memory for future use.
313716_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	The machines are able to produce parts while left unattended when connected to automatic bar-feeding, robotics equipment, or other material handling devices designed to supply raw materials and remove machined parts from the machine.
313716_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	New products are critical to our growth plans.
313716_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	We gain access to new products through internal product development, acquisitions, joint ventures, license agreements and partnerships.
313716_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	Products are introduced each year to both broaden our product offering and to take advantage of new technologies available to us.
313716_11_ITEM1_P17_S3	These technologies generally allow our machines to run at higher speeds and with more power, thus increasing their efficiency.
313716_11_ITEM1_P17_S4	Customers routinely replace old machines with newer machines that can produce parts faster and with less time to set up the machine when converting from one type of part to another.
313716_11_ITEM1_P17_S5	Generally, our machines can be used to produce parts from all of the standard ferrous and non-ferrous metals, as well as plastics, composites and exotic materials.
313716_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	We focus on products and solutions for companies making parts from hard to machine materials with hard to sustain close tolerances and hard to achieve surface finishes and which also may be hard to hold in the machine.
313716_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	expertise, we are uniquely qualified to be the supplier of choice for customers manufacturing to demanding specifications.
313716_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	On many of our machines, multiple options are available which allow customers to customize their machines to their specific operating performance and cost objectives.
313716_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	We produce machines for stock with popular option combinations for immediate delivery, as well as design and produce machines to specific customer requirements.
313716_11_ITEM1_P20_S2	In addition to our machines, we provide the necessary tooling, accessories and support services to assist customers in maximizing their return on investment.
313716_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	The sale of repair parts is important to our business.
313716_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	Certain parts on machines wear over time or break through misuse.
313716_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	Customers will buy parts from us throughout the life of the machine, which is generally measured in multiple years.
313716_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	There are thousands of machines in operation in the world for which we provide those repair parts and in many cases the parts are available exclusively from us.
313716_11_ITEM1_P22_S3	In addition, we offer an extensive line of accessories including workholding, toolholding and other industrial support products, which may be used on both our machines and those produced by others.
313716_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	We offer various warranties on our equipment and consider post-sale support to be a critical element of our business.
313716_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	Warranties on machines typically extend for twelve months after purchase.
313716_11_ITEM1_P23_S2	Services provided include operation and maintenance training, in-field maintenance, and in-field repair.
313716_11_ITEM1_P23_S3	We offer these post sales support services on a paid basis throughout the life of the machine.
313716_11_ITEM1_P23_S4	In territories covered by distributors, this support and service is offered through the distributor.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	We sell our products in most of the industrialized countries of the world through a combination of distributors, agents, and manufacturers' representatives.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	In certain areas of China, France, Germany, Netherlands, North America, and the United Kingdom, we have also used a direct sales force for portions of our product lines.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S2	Generally, our distributors have an exclusive right to sell our products in a defined geographic area.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S3	Our distributors operate as independent businesses and purchase products from us at discounted prices for their customers, while agents and representatives sell products on our behalf and receive commissions on sales.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S4	Our discount schedule is adjusted to reflect the level of pre and post sales support offered by our distributors.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S5	Our direct sales personnel earn a fixed salary plus commission.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S6	Sales through distributors are made only on standard commercial open account terms or through letters of credit.
313716_11_ITEM1_P24_S7	Distributors generally take title to products upon shipment from our facilities and do not have any special return privileges.
313716_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	In 2010, we restructured our U.S. sales channels from a joint distributor network and direct sales force to a new group of distributors.
313716_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	These new distribution partners have exclusive sales, service, and support responsibilities for Hardinge and Bridgeport branded machines and repair parts in virtually all of the United States, with the exception of kneemills and workholding accessories, where they will operate on a non-exclusive basis.
313716_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	Additionally, members of this new distributor network will act as agents for our grinding products working with our direct technical team.
313716_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	Our non-machine products are sold in the U.S. mainly through direct telephone orders to a toll-free telephone number and via our web site.
313716_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	In most cases, we are able to package and ship in-stock tooling and repair parts within 24 hours of receiving orders.
313716_11_ITEM1_P26_S2	We can package and ship items with heavy demand within a few hours.
313716_11_ITEM1_P26_S3	In other parts of the world, these products are sold on either a direct sales basis or through distributor arrangements.
313716_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	We promote recognition of our products in the marketplace through advertising in trade publications, web presences, email newsletters, and participation in industry trade shows.
313716_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	In addition, we market our non-machine products through publication of general catalogues and other targeted catalogues, which we distribute to existing and prospective customers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P27_S2	We have a substantial presence on the internet at www.hardinge.com where customers can obtain information about our products and place orders for workholding, rotary, and kneemill products.
313716_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	A substantial portion of our sales are to small and medium-sized independent job shops, which in turn sell machined parts to their industrial customers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Industries directly and indirectly served by us include aerospace, automotive, computer, communications, consumer-electronics, construction equipment, defense, energy, farm equipment, medical equipment, recreational equipment and transportation.
313716_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	A customer who is a supplier to the consumer electronics industry accounted for 10.7% of our consolidated sales in 2010, and one customer who is a supplier to the automotive industry accounted for 6.8% of our consolidated sales in 2009.
313716_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	While valuing our relationship with each customer, we do not believe that the loss of any single customer, or any few customers, would have an adverse material effect on our business.
313716_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	Hardinge Inc. operates in a single business segment, industrial machine tools.
313716_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	In our industry, the barriers to entry for competition vary based on the level of product performance required.
313716_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	For the products with the highest performance in terms of accuracy and productivity, the barriers are generally technical in nature.
313716_11_ITEM1_P33_S2	For basic products, often the barriers are not technical; they are tied to product availability, competitive price position, and an effective distribution model that offers the pre and post sales support required by customers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Another significant barrier in the global machine tool industry is the high level of working capital that is required to operate the business.
313716_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	We compete in the various segments of the machine tool market within the products of turning, milling, grinding and workholding.
313716_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	We compete with numerous vendors in each market segment we serve.
313716_11_ITEM1_P35_S2	The primary competitive factors in the marketplace for our machine tools are reliability, price, delivery time, service and technological characteristics.
313716_11_ITEM1_P35_S3	Our management considers our segment of the industry to be extremely competitive.
313716_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	There are many manufacturers of machine tools in the world.
313716_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	They can be categorized by the size of material their products can machine and the precision level they can achieve.
313716_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	For our high precision, multi-tasking turning and milling equipment, competition comes primarily from companies such as Mori-Seiki, Mazak, and Okuma, which are based in Japan, and DMG, which is based in Germany.
313716_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	Competition in our more standard turning and milling equipment comes to some degree from those companies as well as Doosan, which is based in South Korea, and Haas which is based in the U.S., as well as several smaller Taiwanese and Korean companies.
313716_11_ITEM1_P37_S2	Our cylindrical grinding machines compete primarily with Studer, a Swiss Company as well as Toyoda and Shigiya, which are based in Japan.
313716_11_ITEM1_P37_S3	Our Hauser jig grinding machines compete primarily with Moore Tool, which is based in the U.S., and some Japanese suppliers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P37_S4	Our surface grinding machines compete with Okamota in Japan, and Chevalier in Taiwan.
313716_11_ITEM1_P37_S5	Our accessories products compete with many smaller companies.
313716_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	The overall number of our competitors providing product solutions serving our market segments may increase.
313716_11_ITEM1_P38_S1	Also, the composition of competitors may change as we broaden our product offerings and the geographic markets we serve.
313716_11_ITEM1_P38_S2	As we expand into new market segments, we will face competition not only from our existing competitors but from other competitors as well, including existing companies with strong technological, marketing and sales positions in those markets.
313716_11_ITEM1_P38_S3	In addition, several of our competitors may have greater resources, including financial, technical and engineering resources, than we do.
313716_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	We produce certain of our lathes, knee-mills, and related products at our Elmira, New York plant.
313716_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	The Kellenberger grinding machines and related products are manufactured at our St. Gallen, Switzerland plant and Hauser and Tschudin products are produced at our Biel, Switzerland facility.
313716_11_ITEM1_P39_S2	The Jones Shipman grinding machines are manufactured at our Leicester, England plant.
313716_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	machining centers and lathes at both Hardinge Taiwan in Nan Tou, Taiwan and Hardinge Machine (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. in Shanghai, China.
313716_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	We manufacture products from various raw materials, including cast iron, sheet metal, and bar steel.
313716_11_ITEM1_P41_S1	We purchase a number of components, sub-assemblies and assemblies from outside suppliers, including the computer and electronic components for our computer controlled lathes, grinding machines, and machining centers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P41_S2	There are multiple suppliers for virtually all of our raw material, components, sub-assemblies and assemblies and historically, we have not experienced a serious supply interruption, however with the recent increase in demand driven by worldwide order activity, producers of bearings, ballscrews, and linear guides have had difficulty meeting demand, which could impact our production schedules in the future.
313716_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	In 2009, we began strategic changes within our Elmira, NY manufacturing facility, which historically was vertically integrated with machining operations converting parts from raw castings to finished goods, the costs of which proved to be prohibitive.
313716_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	We have moved towards a more variable cost business model, outsourcing many of the non-critical components and subassemblies for machines which were being made in the Elmira facility.
313716_11_ITEM1_P42_S2	In conjunction with our decision to outsource certain parts and subassemblies, we identified certain property, plant and equipment that was no longer required for our manufacturing operations and sold them in 2010.
313716_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	A major component of our computer controlled machines is the computer and related electronics package.
313716_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	We purchase these components for our lathes and machining centers primarily from Fanuc Limited, a large Japanese electronics company and Heidenhain, a German control supplier.
313716_11_ITEM1_P43_S2	We also utilize controls from Siemens, another German control manufacturer, on certain machine models in our line of machining centers.
313716_11_ITEM1_P43_S3	On our grinding machines we offer Heidenhain and Fanuc controls.
313716_11_ITEM1_P43_S4	While we believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing from several other existing suppliers, and we occasionally do so for special orders, a disruption in the supply of the computer controls from one of our suppliers could cause us to experience a substantial disruption of our operations, depending on the circumstances at the time.
313716_11_ITEM1_P43_S5	We purchase parts from these suppliers under normal trade terms.
313716_11_ITEM1_P43_S6	There are no agreements with these suppliers to purchase minimum volumes per year.
313716_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	Our ongoing research and development program involves creating new products, modifying existing products to meet market demands, and redesigning existing products, both to add new functionality and to reduce the cost of manufacturing.
313716_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	The research and development departments throughout the world are staffed with experienced design engineers with varying levels of education, ranging from technical to doctoral degrees.
313716_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	The worldwide cost of research and development, all of which has been charged to cost of goods sold, amounted to $9.4 million, $9.3 million and $9.8 million, in 2010, 2009, and 2008, respectively.
313716_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	Although Hardinge Inc. holds several patents with respect to certain of its products, we do not believe that our business is dependent to any material extent upon any single patent or group of patents.
313716_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	Hardinge's business and that of the machine tool industry in general, is cyclical.
313716_11_ITEM1_P48_S1	It is not subject to significant seasonal trends.
313716_11_ITEM1_P48_S2	However, our quarterly results are subject to fluctuation based on the timing of our shipments of machine tools, which are largely dependent upon customer delivery requirements.
313716_11_ITEM1_P48_S3	Historically, we have experienced reduced activity during the third quarter of the year, largely as a result of vacations scheduled at our U.S. and European customers' plants and our policy of closing our U.S. and Switzerland facilities for two weeks during the third quarter.
313716_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	through 2010, due to the economic crisis (discussed further in Item 1A-Risk Factors), our third-quarter net sales, income from operations and net income typically have been the lowest of any quarter during the year.
313716_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	However, given the larger percentage of our sales now from Asia, the impact of plant shutdowns by us and our customers due to the Chinese New Year may impact first quarter net sales, income from operations and net income and result in the first quarter being the lowest quarter of the year.
313716_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	The ability to deliver products within a short period of time is an important competitive criterion.
313716_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	We must have inventory on hand to meet customers' delivery expectations, which for standard machines are typically from immediate to eight weeks delivery.
313716_11_ITEM1_P50_S2	Meeting this requirement is especially difficult with some of our products, where delivery is extended due to ocean travel times, depending on the location of the customer.
313716_11_ITEM1_P50_S3	This creates a need to have inventory of finished machines available in our major markets to serve our customers in a timely manner.
313716_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	We deliver many of our machine products within one to two months after the order.
313716_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	Some orders, especially multiple machine orders, are delivered on a turnkey basis with the machine or group of machines configured to make certain parts for the customer.
313716_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	This type of order often includes the addition of material handling equipment, tooling and specific programming.
313716_11_ITEM1_P51_S3	In those cases the customer usually observes and inspects the parts being made on the machine at our facility before it is shipped and the timing of the sale is dependent upon the customer's schedule and acceptance.
313716_11_ITEM1_P51_S4	Therefore, sales from quarter-to-quarter can vary depending upon the timing of those customers' acceptances and the significance of those orders.
313716_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	We feel it is important, where practical, to provide readily available workholding and replacement parts for the machines we sell and we carry inventory at levels sufficient to meet these customer requirements.
313716_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	We believe that our current operations and our current uses of property, plant and equipment conform in all material respects to applicable laws and regulations.
313716_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	No material portion of our business is subject to government contracts.
313716_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liability for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	Activities at properties we own or previously owned and on adjacent areas have resulted in environmental impacts.
313716_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	In particular, our Elmira, New York manufacturing facility is located within the Kentucky Avenue Wellfield on the National Priorities List of hazardous waste sites designated for cleanup by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, New York.
313716_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_11_ITEM1_P60_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Hardinge, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation, and Toshiba America, Inc., the Potentially Responsible Parties (the PRPs") have agreed to voluntarily participate in the Remedial Investigation and Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	On September 29, 2006, the Director of Emergency and Remedial Response Division of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region II, approved and executed the Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_11_ITEM1_P62_S2	The PRPs also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the cost of the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_11_ITEM1_P62_S3	The cost of the RI/FS was estimated to be approximately $0.84 million.
313716_11_ITEM1_P62_S4	We estimate our portion of the study to be $0.12 million for which we have established a reserve of $0.13 million.
313716_11_ITEM1_P62_S5	As of December 31, 2010 we have incurred total expenses of $0.12 million with respect to the study and other activities relating to the Site.
313716_11_ITEM1_P62_S6	The remaining reserve balance at December 31, 2010 is $0.01 million.
313716_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	The PRPs developed a Draft RI/FS with their consultants and, following EPA comments, submitted a Revised RI/FS on December 6, 2007.
313716_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	In May 2008, the EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan.
313716_11_ITEM1_P63_S2	The PRPs commenced field work in the spring of 2008 and submitted a Draft Site Characterization Report to EPA in the fall.
313716_11_ITEM1_P63_S3	The PRPs currently are performing Risk Assessments in accordance with the Remedial Investigation portion of the RI/FS.
313716_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice, Hardinge had never been named as a PRP at the Site nor had we received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the site.
313716_11_ITEM1_P64_S1	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond and found no evidence that our operations or property have or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_11_ITEM1_P64_S2	Other than as described above, we have not established a reserve for any potential costs relating to this Site, as it is too early in the process to determine our responsibility as well as to estimate any potential costs to remediate.
313716_11_ITEM1_P64_S3	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_11_ITEM1_P65_S0	Although we believe, based upon information currently available, that, except as described in the preceding paragraphs, we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to Hardinge.
313716_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	As of December 31, 2010 Hardinge Inc. employed 1,189 persons, 363 of whom were located in the United States.
313716_11_ITEM1_P66_S1	None of our U.S. employees are covered by collective bargaining agreements.
313716_11_ITEM1_P66_S2	Management believes that relations with its employees are good.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The various risks related to the Company's business include the risks described below.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	The business, financial condition or results of operations of Hardinge Inc. could be materially adversely affected by any of these risks.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The risks and uncertainties described below or elsewhere in the Form 10-K are not the only ones to which we are exposed.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also adversely affect our business and operations.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P1_S2	If any of the matters included in the following risks were to occur, our business, financial condition, results of operations, cash flows or prospects could be materially adversely affected.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our customers' activity levels and spending for our products and services have been impacted by the current global economic conditions, especially deterioration in the credit markets.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Many of our customers finance their purchases of our products through cash flow from operations, the incurrence of debt or from the proceeds received in connection with an issuance of equity.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Commencing in the fourth quarter of 2008, the global financial markets have experienced significant losses due to failures of many dominant financial institutions.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	During late 2008 and early 2009, the governments of the United States and several foreign countries instituted bailout plans to assist many banks and others impacted by the economic crisis.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	This crisis has resulted in, among other things, a significant decline in the credit markets and the availability of credit, the impact of which is still being experienced today.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Additionally, many of our customers' equity values have substantially declined.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P4_S4	The combination of a reduction in borrowing bases under asset based credit facilities and the lack of availability of debt or equity financing may result in a significant reduction in our customers' spending for our products and may impact the ability of our customers to pay amounts owed to us.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P4_S5	In addition, this crisis and economic uncertainty has resulted in an overall decrease in consumer and business spending, which negatively impacted the need our customers have for our products.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	As a result of this cyclicality, we have experienced, and in the future, we can be expected to experience, significant fluctuations in sales and operating income, which may affect our business, operating results, financial condition and the market price of our common shares.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Fluctuations in capacity at both OEMs and job shops; The availability of skilled machinists; The need to replace machines that have reached the end of their useful life; The need to replace older machines with new technology that increases productivity, reduces general manufacturing costs, and machines parts in a new way; The evolution of end-use products requiring machining to more specific tolerances; Our customers' use of new materials requiring machining by different processes; General economic and manufacturing industry expansions and contractions; and Changes in manufacturing capabilities in developing regions.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Our expenditures for post-retirement pension obligations could be materially higher than we have predicted if our underlying assumptions prove to be incorrect or we are required to use different assumptions.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P48_S0	We provide defined benefit pension plans to eligible employees.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P48_S1	Our pension expense, the funding status of our plans and related charges in other comprehensive income, and our required contributions to our pension plans are directly affected by the value of plan assets, the projected rate of return on plan assets, the actual rate of return on plan assets and the actuarial assumptions we use to measure our defined benefit pension plan obligations, including the rate at which future obligations are discounted to a present value, or the discount rate.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Our market-related value of assets recognizes asset losses and gains over a five-year period, which we believe is consistent with the long-term nature of our pension obligations.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P49_S1	As a result, the effect of changes in the market value of assets on our pension expense may be experienced in future years rather than fully reflected in the expense for the year immediately following the year in which the fluctuations actually occurred.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P50_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2010, the value of our Pension Plan Assets increased by $11.7 million due to increases in market value of the underlying assets as the world markets continued to recover from the impacts the global economic recession had on the world financial markets and related investment valuations.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P50_S1	The future investment performance of our pension plan assets could significantly impact the plan assets and future growth of the plan assets.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P50_S2	Should the assets earn a return less than the assumed rate of return over time, it is likely that future pension expenses and funding requirements would increase.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P50_S3	Investment earnings in excess of the assumed rate of return may reduce future pension expenses and funding requirements.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P51_S0	For our domestic and foreign plans, discount rates are based on the yields on high grade corporate bonds in each market with maturities matching the projected benefit payments.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P51_S1	Discount rates are used to determine the present value of the projected and accumulated benefit obligation at the end of each year.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P51_S2	A change in the discount rate would impact the funded status of our plans.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P52_S0	discount rate would reduce the pension liability and future pension expense and conversely, a lower discount rate would raise pension liability and the future pension expense.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P53_S0	To develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption, for our domestic and foreign plans, we consider the current level of expected returns on risk free investments (primarily government bonds) in each market, the historical level of the risk premium associated with the other asset classes in which the portfolio is invested, and the expectations for future returns of each asset class.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P53_S1	The expected return for each asset class is then weighted based on the asset allocation to develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P54_S0	For pension accounting purposes in our U.S. based plan, which is the largest of our plans, the rate of return assumed on the market-related value of plan assets for determining pension expense was 8.00% for 2010 and 2009.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P54_S1	The discount rate used for determining the obligation was 5.93% at December 31, 2010 compared to 6.27% at December 31, 2009.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P74_S0	We rely on estimated forecasts of our customers' needs and inaccuracies in such forecasts could adversely affect our business.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P75_S0	We generally sell our products pursuant to individual purchase orders instead of long-term purchase commitments.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P75_S1	Therefore, we rely on estimated demand forecasts, based upon input from our customers and the general economic environment, to determine how much material to purchase and product to manufacture.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P76_S0	Because our sales are based on purchase orders, our customers may cancel, delay or otherwise modify their purchase commitments with little or no consequence to them and with little or no notice to us.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P76_S1	For these reasons, we generally have limited visibility regarding our customers' actual product needs.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P80_S1	We currently maintain product liability insurance coverage; however, such insurance does not cover all types of damages that could be assessed against us in a product liability claim and the coverage amounts are subject to limitations under the applicable policies.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P80_S2	We may not be able to obtain product liability insurance on acceptable terms in the future.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P80_S4	An unsuccessful product liability defense could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P80_S5	In addition, we believe our business depends on the strong brand reputation we have developed.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P80_S6	In the event that our reputation is damaged, we may face difficulty in maintaining our pricing positions with respect to some of our products, which would reduce our sales and profitability.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P84_S0	We are subject to environmental laws that could impose significant costs on us and the failure to comply with such laws could subject us to sanctions and material fines and expenses.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P85_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P86_S0	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liability for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P87_S0	Activities at properties we own or previously owned and on adjacent areas have resulted in environmental impacts.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P88_S0	States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P89_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, New York.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P90_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P90_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P90_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P91_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P92_S0	Hardinge, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation, and Toshiba America, Inc., the Potentially Responsible Parties (the PRPs") have agreed to voluntarily participate in the Remedial Investigation and Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P92_S1	On September 29, 2006, the Director of Emergency and Remedial Response Division of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region II, approved and executed the Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P92_S2	The PRPs also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the cost of the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P92_S3	The cost of the RI/FS was estimated to be approximately $0.84 million.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P92_S4	We estimate our portion of the study to be $0.12 million for which we have established a reserve of $0.13 million.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P92_S5	As of December 31, 2010 we have incurred total expenses of $0.12 million with respect to the study and other activities relating to the Site.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P92_S6	The remaining reserve balance at December 31, 2010 is $0.01 million.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P93_S0	The PRPs developed a Draft RI/FS with their consultants and, following EPA comments, submitted a Revised RI/FS on December 6, 2007.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P93_S1	In May 2008, the EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P93_S2	The PRPs commenced field work in the spring of 2008 and submitted a Draft Site Characterization Report to EPA in the fall.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P93_S3	The PRPs currently are performing Risk Assessments in accordance with the Remedial Investigation portion of the RI/FS.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P94_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice, Hardinge had never been named as a PRP at the Site nor had we received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the site.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P94_S1	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond and found no evidence that our operations or property have or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P94_S2	Other than as described above, we have not established a reserve for any potential costs relating to this Site, as it is too early in the process to determine our responsibility as well as to estimate any potential costs to remediate.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P94_S3	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P95_S0	Although we believe, based upon information currently available, that, except as described in the preceding paragraphs, we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to Hardinge.

313716_11_ITEM1A_P102_S0	Our certificate of incorporation and bylaws provide that our Board of Directors, currently consisting of seven members, is divided into three classes of directors, with each class consisting of two or three directors, and with the classes serving staggered three-year terms.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P102_S1	This classification of the directors has the effect of making it more difficult for shareholders, including those holding a majority of our outstanding shares, to force an immediate change in the composition of our Board of Directors.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P103_S0	Removal of Directors and Filling of Vacancies.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P103_S1	Our certificate of incorporation provides that a member of our Board of Directors may be removed only for cause and upon the affirmative vote of the holders of 75% of the securities entitled to vote at an election of directors.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P103_S2	Newly created directorships and Board of Director vacancies resulting from death, removal or other causes may be filled only by a majority vote of the then remaining directors.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P103_S3	Accordingly, it is more difficult for shareholders, including those holding a majority of our outstanding shares, to force an immediate change in the composition of our Board of Directors.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P104_S0	Supermajority Voting Provisions for Certain Business Combinations.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P104_S1	Our certificate of incorporation requires the affirmative vote of at least 75% of all of the securities entitled to vote and at least 75% of shareholders who are not Major Shareholders (defined as 10% beneficial holders) in order to effect certain mergers, sales of assets or other business combinations involving the Company.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P104_S2	These provisions could have the effect of delaying, deferring or preventing a change of control of the Company.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P105_S0	In addition, as a New York corporation we are subject to provisions of the New York Business Corporation Law which may make it more difficult for a third party to acquire and exercise control over us pursuant to a tender offer or request or invitation for tenders.
313716_11_ITEM1A_P105_S1	These provisions could have the effect of deterring or delaying changes in incumbent management, proxy contests or changes in control.

313716_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	Our primary business is designing, manufacturing, and distributing high-precision computer controlled metal-cutting turning, grinding and milling machines and related accessories.
313716_11_ITEM7_P0_S1	We are geographically diversified with manufacturing facilities in Switzerland, Taiwan, the United States, China and the United Kingdom with sales to most industrialized countries.
313716_11_ITEM7_P0_S2	Approximately 77% of our 2010 sales were to customers outside of North America, 78% of our 2010 products sold were manufactured outside of North America, and 69% of our employees were outside of North America.
313716_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our machine products are considered to be capital goods and are part of what has historically been a highly cyclical industry.
313716_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our management believes that a key performance indicator is our order level as compared to industry measures of market activity levels.
313716_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	While general economic conditions around the world have improved, the global economic recession, which began in 2008, continues to have some impact on the industries in several of the regions in which we conduct business.
313716_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Reduced availability of credit has impacted our customers' ability to obtain financing.
313716_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	Order volumes have improved dramatically over 2009, however, we are still below 2008 levels in some of the regions where we conduct business.
313716_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	We are encouraged by the upward trend for global machine tool demand in 2010.
313716_11_ITEM7_P3_S3	Order volumes in the Asia and Other market have returned to early 2008 levels, as those economies rebound to normalized levels.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	Metrics on machine tool market activity watched by our management include world machine tool consumption (domestic production plus imports, less exports) as reported annually by Gardner Publications in the Metalworking Insiders Report and metal-cutting machine orders as reported by the Association of Manufacturing Technology (AMT), the primary industry group for U.S. machine tool manufacturers.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	World machine tool consumption data as reported by the Metalworking Insiders Report shows an increase in machine tool consumption of 19% in 2010 versus a 33% decrease in consumption in 2009 due to the worldwide economic conditions.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	This report indicates that consumption in China, the world's largest market, increased 38% in 2010 after remaining relatively stable over the course of 2009 versus 2008.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S3	Consumption in Germany, the world's second largest market, decreased by 9% in 2010 versus 2009 as measured in local currencies, and decreased 41% in 2009 compared to 2008.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S4	In the United Kingdom, machine tool consumption measured in pound sterling increased by 6% in 2010 versus 2009 and decreased by 40% in 2009 versus 2008.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S5	Machine tool consumption in the U.S. decreased by 15% in 2010 versus 2009 compared to a decrease of 51% in 2009 compared to 2008.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S6	In 2010, U.S. orders for metal-cutting machine tools reported by the AMT increased 85.3% versus 2009 as a result of the economic recovery in the U.S. market.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S7	In 2009 orders declined by 60.4% versus 2008, primarily related to the sharp decline in world-wide order activity brought on by the global economic conditions.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S8	The AMT's statistics are reported on a voluntary basis from member companies.
313716_11_ITEM7_P4_S9	The report includes metal-cutting machines of all types and sizes, including segments in which we do not compete.
313716_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	Other closely followed U.S. market indicators are tracked to determine activity levels in U.S. manufacturing plants that might purchase our products.
313716_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	One such measurement is the PMI (formerly called the Purchasing Manager's Index), as reported by the Institute for Supply Management.
313716_11_ITEM7_P5_S2	Another measurement is capacity utilization of U.S. manufacturing plants, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board.
313716_11_ITEM7_P5_S3	Similar information regarding machine tool consumption in foreign countries is published in various trade journals.
313716_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	Non-machine sales, which include collets, accessories, repair parts, and service revenue, have typically accounted for approximately 25% of overall sales and are an important part of our business, especially in the U.S. where Hardinge has an installed base of thousands of machines.
313716_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	Sales of these products do not vary on a year-to-year basis as significantly as capital goods, but demand does typically track the direction of the related machine metrics.
313716_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	Other key performance indicators are geographic distribution of net sales and orders, gross profit as a percent of net sales, income from operations, working capital changes, and debt level trends.
313716_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	In an industry where constant product technology development has led to an average model life of three to five years, effectiveness of technological innovation and development of new products are also key performance indicators.

313716_11_ITEM7_P116_S0	The following information has been provided in accordance with the Securities and Exchange Commission's requirements for disclosure of exposures to market risk arising from certain market risk sensitive instruments.
313716_11_ITEM7_P117_S0	Our earnings are affected by changes in short-term interest rates as a result of our floating interest rate debt.
313716_11_ITEM7_P117_S1	If market interest rates on debt subject to floating interest rates were to have increased by 2% over the actual rates paid in that year, interest expense would have increased by $0.1 million in 2010 and $0.3 million in 2009.
313716_11_ITEM7_P117_S2	These amounts are determined by considering the impact of hypothetical interest rates on the Company's borrowing cost.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S0	Our operations include manufacturing and sales activities in foreign jurisdictions.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S1	We currently manufacture our products in Switzerland, Taiwan, the United States, China, and United Kingdom using production components purchased internationally, and we sell our products in those markets as well as other worldwide markets.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S2	Our subsidiaries in the United Kingdom, Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Canada sell products in local currency to customers in those countries.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S3	These subsidiaries also transact business in currencies other than their functional currency outside of their home country.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S4	Our Taiwanese subsidiary sells products to foreign purchasers in U.S. dollars.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S5	As a result of these sales in various currencies and in various countries of the world, our financial results could be significantly affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in the foreign markets in which we distribute our products.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S6	Our operating results are exposed to changes in exchange rates between the U.S. Dollar, Canadian Dollar, British Pound Sterling, Swiss Franc, Euro, New Taiwanese Dollar, Chinese Renminbi and Japanese Yen.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S7	As a result of having sales, purchases and certain intercompany transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currencies of our subsidiaries, we are exposed to the effect of currency exchange rate changes on our cash flows, earnings and balance sheet.
313716_11_ITEM7_P118_S8	To mitigate this currency risk we enter into currency forward exchange contracts to hedge significant non-functional currency denominated transactions for periods consistent with the terms of the underlying transactions.
313716_11_ITEM7_P119_S0	Contracts generally have maturities that do not exceed one year.
313716_11_ITEM7_P120_S0	The preparation of our financial statements requires the application of a number of accounting policies which are described in the notes to the financial statements.
313716_11_ITEM7_P120_S1	These policies require the use of assumptions or estimates, which, if interpreted differently under different conditions or circumstances, could result in material changes to the reported results.
313716_11_ITEM7_P120_S2	Following is a discussion of those accounting policies, which were reviewed with our audit committee, and which we feel are most susceptible to such interpretation.
313716_11_ITEM7_P121_S0	We assess the collectibility of our trade accounts and notes receivable using a combination of methods.
313716_11_ITEM7_P121_S1	We review large individual accounts for evidence of circumstances that suggest a collection problem might exist.
313716_11_ITEM7_P121_S2	Such situations include, but are not limited to, the customer's past history of payments, its current financial condition as evidenced by credit ratings, financial statements or other sources, and recent collection activities.
313716_11_ITEM7_P122_S0	On a case by case basis, we offer long-term customer financing in the form of notes receivable at some of our foreign operations.
313716_11_ITEM7_P122_S1	We provide a reserve for losses based on current payment trends in the economies where we hold concentrations of receivables and provide a reserve for what we believe to be the most likely risk of uncollectibility.
313716_11_ITEM7_P122_S2	In order to make these allowances, we rely on assumptions regarding economic conditions, equipment resale values, and the likelihood that previous performance will be indicative of future results.
313716_11_ITEM7_P123_S0	We use a number of assumptions and estimates in determining the value of our inventory.
313716_11_ITEM7_P124_S0	An allowance is provided for the value of inventory quantities of specific items that are deemed to be excessive based on an annual review of past usage and anticipated future usage.
313716_11_ITEM7_P124_S1	While we feel this is the most appropriate methodology for determining excess quantities, the possibility exists that customers will change their buying habits in the future should their own requirements change.
313716_11_ITEM7_P125_S0	Changes in metal-cutting technology can render certain products obsolete or reduce their market value.
313716_11_ITEM7_P125_S1	We continually evaluate changes in technology and adjust our products and inventory carrying values accordingly, either by write-off or by price reductions.
313716_11_ITEM7_P125_S2	Changes in market conditions and realizable selling prices for our machines could reduce the value of our inventory.
313716_11_ITEM7_P125_S3	We continually evaluate the carrying value of our machine inventory against the estimated selling price, less related costs to sell and adjust our inventory carrying values accordingly.
313716_11_ITEM7_P125_S4	However, the possibility exists that a future technological development, currently unanticipated, might affect the marketability of specific products produced by the company.
313716_11_ITEM7_P126_S0	We include in the cost of our inventories a component to cover the estimated cost of manufacturing overhead activities associated with production of our products.
313716_11_ITEM7_P127_S0	We believe that being able to offer immediate delivery on many of our products is critical to our competitive success.
313716_11_ITEM7_P127_S1	Likewise, we believe that maintaining an inventory of service parts, with a particular emphasis on purchased parts, is especially important to support our policy of maintaining serviceability of our products.
313716_11_ITEM7_P127_S2	Consequently, we maintain significant inventories of repair parts on many of our machine models, including some which are no longer in production.
313716_11_ITEM7_P127_S3	Our ability to accurately determine which parts are needed to maintain this serviceability is critical to our success in managing this element of our business.
313716_11_ITEM7_P128_S0	We have acquired other machine tool companies or assets of companies.
313716_11_ITEM7_P128_S1	When doing so, we have used outside specialists to assist in determining the value of assets acquired, and have used traditional models for establishing purchase price based on EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) multiples and present value of future cash flows.
313716_11_ITEM7_P128_S2	Consequently, the value of goodwill and other purchased intangible assets on our balance sheet have been affected by the use of numerous estimates of the value of assets purchased and of future business opportunity.
313716_11_ITEM7_P129_S0	We regularly review the recent results and projected future results of our operations, as well as other relevant factors, to reconfirm the likelihood that existing deferred tax assets in each tax jurisdiction would be fully recoverable.
313716_11_ITEM7_P130_S0	We sponsor various defined benefit pension plans, defined contribution plans, and one postretirement benefit plan, all as described in Note 8 of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
313716_11_ITEM7_P131_S0	The calculation of our plan expenses and liabilities require the use of a number of critical accounting estimates.
313716_11_ITEM7_P131_S1	Changes in the assumptions can result in different plan expense and liability amounts, and actual experience can differ from the assumptions.
313716_11_ITEM7_P131_S2	We believe that the most critical assumptions are the discount rate and the expected rate of return on plan assets.
313716_11_ITEM7_P132_S0	We annually review the discount rate to be used for retirement plan liabilities, using bond pricing models based on high grade U.S. corporate bonds constructed to match the projected liability benefit payments.
313716_11_ITEM7_P132_S1	We discounted our future plan liabilities for our U.S. plan using a rate of 5.93% and 6.27% at our plan measurement date of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
313716_11_ITEM7_P132_S2	We discounted our future plan liabilities for our foreign plans using rates appropriate for each country, which resulted in a blended rate of 3.09% and 3.84% at their measurement dates of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
313716_11_ITEM7_P133_S0	A change in the discount rate can have a significant effect on retirement plan obligations.
313716_11_ITEM7_P133_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension obligations by approximately $12.2 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P133_S2	An increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension obligations by approximately $10.1 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P133_S3	A decrease of one percent in the discount rate would increase the Kellenberger pension obligations by approximately $11.9 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P133_S4	An increase of one percent would decrease the Kellenberger pension obligations by approximately $9.3 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P134_S0	A change in the discount rate can also have a significant effect on retirement plan expense.
313716_11_ITEM7_P134_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.1 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P134_S2	An increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.05 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P134_S3	A decrease of one percent would increase the Kellenberger pension expense by approximately $1.2 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P134_S4	An increase of one percent would decrease the Kellenberger pension expense by approximately $1.0 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P135_S0	The expected rate of return on plan assets varies based on the investment mix of each particular plan and reflects the long-term average rate of return expected on funds invested or to be invested in each pension plan to provide for the benefits included in the pension liability.
313716_11_ITEM7_P135_S1	We review our expected rate of return annually based upon information available to us at that time, including the current level of expected returns on risk free investments (primarily government bonds in each market), the historical level of the risk premium associated with the other asset classes in which the portfolio is invested, and the expectations for future returns of each asset class.
313716_11_ITEM7_P135_S2	The expected return for each asset class was then weighted based on the asset allocation to develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption.
313716_11_ITEM7_P135_S3	We used an expected rate of return of 8.00% and 8.00% at our measurement dates of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively, for our domestic plan.
313716_11_ITEM7_P135_S4	We used rates of return appropriate for each country for our foreign plans which resulted in a blended expected rate of return of 4.23% and 5.14% at their measurement dates of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
313716_11_ITEM7_P136_S0	A change in the expected return on plan assets can also have a significant effect on retirement plan expense.
313716_11_ITEM7_P136_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.8 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P136_S2	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.8 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P136_S3	A decrease of one percent would increase the Kellenberger pension expense by approximately $0.7 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P136_S4	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease the Kellenberger pension expense by approximately $0.7 million.
313716_11_ITEM7_P137_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2009-13, Revenue Recognition ASC Topic 605: Multiple-Deliverable Revenue Arrangements a consensus of the FASB Emerging Issues Task Force (ASU 2009-13).
313716_11_ITEM7_P137_S1	ASU 2009-13 addresses the accounting for sales arrangements that include multiple products or services by revising the criteria for when deliverables may be accounted for separately rather than as a combined unit.
313716_11_ITEM7_P137_S2	Specifically, this guidance establishes a selling price hierarchy for determining the selling price of a deliverable, which is necessary to separately account for each product or service.
313716_11_ITEM7_P137_S3	This hierarchy provides more options for establishing selling price than existing guidance.
313716_11_ITEM7_P138_S0	ASU 2009-13 is required to be applied prospectively to new or materially modified revenue arrangements in fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010.
313716_11_ITEM7_P138_S1	We do not expect adoption of this standard to have a material impact on our consolidated results of operations and financial condition.
313716_11_ITEM7_P139_S0	In January 2010, the FASB issued an amendment to ASC Topic 820 Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures.
313716_11_ITEM7_P139_S1	The amendment requires new disclosures on the transfers of assets and liabilities between Level 1 (quoted prices in active market for identical assets or liabilities) and Level 2 (significant other observable inputs) of the fair value measurement hierarchy, including the reasons and the timing of the transfers.
313716_11_ITEM7_P139_S2	Additionally, the guidance requires a roll forward of activities on purchases, sales, issuance, and settlements of the assets and liabilities measured using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3 fair value measurements).
313716_11_ITEM7_P139_S3	We have applied the new disclosure requirements as of January 1, 2010, which is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2010.
313716_11_ITEM7_P139_S4	Other than requiring additional disclosures, adoption of this new guidance did not and will not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.

313716_11_ITEM8_P11_S0	Hardinge Inc. (the "Company") is a machine tool manufacturer, which designs and manufactures computer-numerically controlled cutting lathes, machining centers, grinding machines, collets, chucks, index fixtures and other industrial products.
313716_11_ITEM8_P11_S1	A substantial portion of our sales are to small and medium-sized independent job shops, which in turn sell machined parts to their industrial customers.
313716_11_ITEM8_P11_S2	Industries directly and indirectly served by the Company include: aerospace, automotive, communications, computer, construction equipment, defense, energy, farm equipment, medical equipment, recreational equipment, and transportation.
313716_11_ITEM8_P12_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
313716_11_ITEM8_P12_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions are eliminated in consolidation.
313716_11_ITEM8_P13_S0	Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current-year presentation.
313716_11_ITEM8_P14_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with GAAP which requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period.
313716_11_ITEM8_P14_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.

313716_11_ITEM8_P15_S1	The fair value of the Company's cash and cash equivalents approximates carrying amounts due to the short maturities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	Occasionally, we are required to maintain cash deposits with certain banks with respect to contractual obligations as collateral for customer deposits or foreign exchange forward contracts.
313716_11_ITEM8_P16_S1	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, the amount of restricted cash was approximately $5.2 million and $4.2 million, respectively.
313716_11_ITEM8_P17_S0	We perform periodic credit evaluations of the financial condition of our customers.
313716_11_ITEM8_P18_S0	No collateral is required for sales made on open account terms.
313716_11_ITEM8_P18_S1	Letters of credit from major banks back the majority of sales in the Asian region.
313716_11_ITEM8_P19_S0	Concentrations of credit risk with respect to accounts receivable are generally limited due to the large number of customers comprising our customer base.
313716_11_ITEM8_P20_S0	trade accounts receivable to be past due when in excess of 30 days past terms, and charge off uncollectible balances when all collection efforts have been exhausted.
313716_11_ITEM8_P21_S0	We maintain an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments.

313716_11_ITEM8_P22_S0	In the past, we provided long-term financing for the purchase of our equipment by qualified end-user customers in North America, with the Company retaining a security interest in the purchased equipment.

313716_11_ITEM8_P23_S1	It has been our experience that such equipment resales have realized most, but not all, of the remaining contract value.

313716_11_ITEM8_P24_S0	Prepaid expenses and other current assets consist of prepaid insurance, prepaid real estate taxes, prepaid software license agreements, prepaid income taxes and deposits on certain inventory purchases.
313716_11_ITEM8_P24_S1	When applicable, prepayments are expensed on a straight-line basis over the corresponding life of the underlying asset.
313716_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost (computed in accordance with the first-in, first-out method) or market.
313716_11_ITEM8_P25_S1	Elements of cost include raw materials, purchased components, labor and overhead.
313716_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost.
313716_11_ITEM8_P26_S1	Major additions, renewals or improvements that extend the useful lives of assets are capitalized.
313716_11_ITEM8_P26_S2	Maintenance and repairs are expensed to operations as incurred.
313716_11_ITEM8_P27_S0	Depreciation expense is computed on the straight-line and accelerated methods over the assets' estimated useful lives.
313716_11_ITEM8_P27_S1	The depreciable lives of our fixed assets vary according to their estimated useful lives and generally are: 40 years for buildings, 12 years for machinery, and 10 years for patterns, tools, jigs, and furniture and fixtures, and 5 years for office and computer equipment.
313716_11_ITEM8_P27_S2	Depreciation expense was $5.7 million, $7.2 million, and $8.1 million for 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
313716_11_ITEM8_P28_S0	Goodwill and other separately recognized intangible assets with indefinite lives are not subject to amortization, but are reviewed at least annually for impairment or are reviewed for impairment between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that more likely than not would indicate the carrying amount may be impaired.
313716_11_ITEM8_P28_S1	Intangible assets that are determined to have a finite life are amortized over their estimated useful lives and are also subject to review for impairment, if indicators of impairment are identified.
313716_11_ITEM8_P29_S0	We review our long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
313716_11_ITEM8_P29_S1	To assess whether impairment exists, we use undiscounted cash flows and measure any impairment loss using discounted cash flows.
313716_11_ITEM8_P30_S0	Assets to be held for sale are reported at the lower of their carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell and are no longer depreciated.
313716_11_ITEM8_P31_S0	We account for income taxes using the liability method where deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized based on differences between financial reporting and tax bases of assets and liabilities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P31_S1	These deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
313716_11_ITEM8_P32_S0	A valuation allowance is established when it is more likely than not that all or a portion of deferred tax assets will not be realized.
313716_11_ITEM8_P32_S1	A review of all available positive and negative evidence needs to be considered, including a company's current and past performance, the market conditions in which the company operates, the utilization of past tax credits, the length of carryback and carryforward periods, sales backlogs, etc. that will result in future profits.
313716_11_ITEM8_P32_S2	Forming a conclusion that a valuation allowance is not needed is difficult when there is negative evidence such as cumulative losses in recent years.
313716_11_ITEM8_P32_S3	Therefore, cumulative losses weigh heavily in the overall assessment and were a major consideration in our decision to establish a valuation allowance.
313716_11_ITEM8_P33_S0	We maintain a full valuation allowance on the tax benefits of our U.S. net deferred tax assets and we expect to continue to record a full valuation allowance on future tax benefits until an appropriate level of profitability in the U.S. is sustained.
313716_11_ITEM8_P33_S1	We also maintain a valuation allowance on our U.K., German, and Canadian deferred tax assets related to tax loss carryforwards in those jurisdictions, as well as all other deferred tax assets of those entities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P34_S0	The determination of our provision for income taxes requires significant judgment, the use of estimates and the interpretation and application of complex tax laws.
313716_11_ITEM8_P34_S1	Our provision for income taxes reflects a combination of income earned and taxed in the U.S. and the various states, as well as federal and provincial jurisdictions in Switzerland, U.K., Canada, Germany, France, the Netherlands, China and Taiwan.
313716_11_ITEM8_P34_S2	Jurisdictional tax law changes, increases or decreases in permanent differences between book and tax items, accruals or adjustments of accruals for tax contingencies or valuation allowances, and our change in the mix of earnings from these taxing jurisdictions all affect the overall effective tax rate.
313716_11_ITEM8_P34_S3	Accordingly, these substantial judgment items impacted the effective tax rate for 2010.
313716_11_ITEM8_P35_S0	We account for our uncertain tax positions in accordance with the provisions of ASC 740.
313716_11_ITEM8_P35_S1	Interest and penalties are included as a component of income tax expense.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S0	Revenue from product sales is generally recognized upon shipment, provided persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, the sales price is fixed or determinable, collectibility is reasonably assured, and the title and risk of loss have passed to the customer.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S1	Sales are recorded net of discounts, customer sales incentives, and returns.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S2	Discounts and customer sales incentives are typically negotiated as part of the sales terms at the time of sale and are recorded as a reduction of revenue.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S3	The Company does not routinely permit customers to return machines.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S4	In the rare case that a machine return is permitted, a restocking fee is typically charged.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S5	Returns of spare parts and workholding products are limited to a period of 90 days subsequent to purchase, excluding special orders which are not eligible for return.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S6	An estimate of returns, which is not significant, is recorded as a reduction of revenue and is based on historical experience.
313716_11_ITEM8_P36_S7	Transfer of ownership and risk of loss are generally not contingent upon contractual customer acceptance.
313716_11_ITEM8_P37_S0	Prior to shipment, each machine is tested to ensure the machine's compliance with standard operating specifications as listed in our promotional literature.
313716_11_ITEM8_P37_S1	On an exception basis, where larger multiple machine installations are delivered which require run-offs and customer acceptance at their facility, revenue is recognized in the period of customer acceptance.
313716_11_ITEM8_P38_S0	Revenue from extended warranties are deferred and recognized on a pro-rata basis across the term of the warranty contract.
313716_11_ITEM8_P39_S0	We collect and remit taxes assessed by different governmental authorities that are both imposed on and concurrent with revenue producing transactions between the Company and its customers.
313716_11_ITEM8_P39_S1	These taxes may include sales, use, and value-added taxes.
313716_11_ITEM8_P39_S2	We report the collection of these taxes on a net basis (excluded from revenues).
313716_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	Shipping and handling cost are recorded as part of cost of goods sold.
313716_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	We offer warranties for our products.
313716_11_ITEM8_P41_S1	The specific terms and conditions of those warranties vary depending upon the product sold and the country in which we sold the product.
313716_11_ITEM8_P41_S2	We generally provide a basic limited warranty for a period of one year.
313716_11_ITEM8_P41_S3	We estimate the costs that may be incurred under our basic limited warranty, based largely upon actual warranty repair cost history, and record a liability for such costs in the month that product revenue is recognized.
313716_11_ITEM8_P41_S4	The resulting accrual balance is reviewed during the year.
313716_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	Factors that affect our warranty liability include the number of installed units, historical and anticipated rates of warranty claims, and cost per claim.
313716_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	We also sell extended warranties for some of our products.
313716_11_ITEM8_P43_S1	These extended warranties usually cover a 12-24 month period that begins up to 12 months after time of sale.
313716_11_ITEM8_P43_S2	Revenues for these extended warranties are recognized monthly as a portion of the warranty expires.
313716_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	These liabilities are reported in accrued expenses on our consolidated balance sheet.

313716_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	As a multinational Company, we are exposed to market risk from changes in foreign currency exchange rates that could affect our results of operations and financial condition.
313716_11_ITEM8_P49_S1	To manage this risk, we enter into derivative instruments namely in the form of foreign currency forwards.
313716_11_ITEM8_P49_S2	Our derivative instruments are held to hedge economic exposures, such as fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates on balance sheet exposures of both trade and intercompany assets and liabilities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P49_S3	We hedge this exposure with contracts settling in less than a year.
313716_11_ITEM8_P50_S0	Gains or losses resulting from the changes in the fair value of these hedging contracts are recognized in earnings.
313716_11_ITEM8_P51_S0	We have some forward contracts to hedge vendor firm commitments.
313716_11_ITEM8_P51_S1	These contracts which are for less than two years have maturity dates in alignment with our contractual payment requirements.
313716_11_ITEM8_P51_S2	These derivatives qualify for hedge accounting treatment and are designated as cash flow hedges.
313716_11_ITEM8_P51_S3	Unrealized gains or losses resulting from the changes in the fair value of these hedging contracts are charged to Other Comprehensive Income (Loss).
313716_11_ITEM8_P51_S4	Gains or losses on any ineffective portion of the contracts will be recognized in earnings.
313716_11_ITEM8_P52_S0	We account for stock-based compensation based on the estimated fair value of the award as of the grant date and recognize as expense the value of the award over the required service period.
313716_11_ITEM8_P53_S0	Comprehensive income consists of net income, postretirement plan adjustments, foreign currency translation adjustments and unrealized gains or losses on hedging, net of tax, and is presented in the Consolidated Statements of Shareholders' Equity.
313716_11_ITEM8_P54_S0	Basic earnings per common share is computed by dividing net (loss) income available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
313716_11_ITEM8_P54_S1	Net (loss) income available to common shareholders represents net (loss) income reduced by the allocation of earnings to participating securities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P54_S2	Losses are not allocated to participating securities.

313716_11_ITEM8_P56_S1	Recipients of restricted stock are entitled to receive non-forfeitable dividends during the vesting period, therefore, meeting the definition of a participating security.
