313716_11_ITEM8_P58_S0	We assess the valuation of our inventories and reduce the carrying value of those inventories that are obsolete or in excess of our forecasted usage to their estimated net realizable value.
313716_11_ITEM8_P58_S1	We estimate the net realizable value of such inventories based on analyses and assumptions including, but not limited to, historical usage, future demand, and market requirements.
313716_11_ITEM8_P58_S2	We also review the carrying value of our inventory compared to the estimated selling price less costs to sell and adjust our inventory carrying value accordingly.
313716_11_ITEM8_P59_S0	Reductions to the carrying value of inventories are recorded in cost of goods sold.
313716_11_ITEM8_P59_S1	If future demand for our products is less favorable than our forecasts, inventories may need to be reduced, which would result in additional expense.

313716_11_ITEM8_P74_S0	In June 2008, we entered into a five-year $100.0 million multi-currency secured credit facility ("Credit Facility").
313716_11_ITEM8_P74_S1	The Credit Facility was secured by substantially all of the Company's and its domestic subsidiaries' assets, other than real estate, and a pledge of (i) 100% of the Company's investments in its domestic subsidiaries and (ii) 66 2 / 3 % of the Company's investment in Hardinge Holdings GmbH, the parent corporation of our significant foreign subsidiaries.

313716_11_ITEM8_P75_S0	Interest was based on London Interbank Offered Rates ("LIBOR"') plus a spread which varied depending on the Company's debt to EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) ratio.
313716_11_ITEM8_P75_S1	A variable commitment fee of 0.20% to 0.375%, based on the Company's debt to EBITDA ratio, was payable on the unused portion of the Credit Facility.

313716_11_ITEM8_P146_S0	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
313716_11_ITEM8_P146_S1	Depending on the nature of the asset or liability, various techniques and assumptions can be used to estimate fair value.
313716_11_ITEM8_P146_S2	We are using the following fair value hierarchy definition:
313716_11_ITEM8_P147_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets and liabilities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P147_S1	Level 2 Observable inputs other than quoted prices in active markets for similar assets and liabilities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P147_S2	Level 3 Inputs for which significant valuation assumptions are unobservable in a market and therefore value is based on the best available data, some of which is internally developed and considers risk premiums that a market participant would require.
313716_11_ITEM8_P148_S0	The following table presents the fair values and classification of our financial assets and liabilities measured on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2010:
313716_11_ITEM8_P149_S0	The following table presents the fair values and classification of our financial assets and liabilities measured on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2009:
313716_11_ITEM8_P150_S0	Our derivative assets and liabilities are foreign exchange derivatives that are measured at fair value using internal models based on observable market inputs such as spot and forward rates.
313716_11_ITEM8_P150_S1	Based on these inputs, the derivative assets and liabilities are classified within Level 2 of the valuation hierarchy.
313716_11_ITEM8_P151_S0	Based on our continued ability to enter into forward contracts, we consider the markets for our fair value instruments to be active.
313716_11_ITEM8_P152_S0	As of December 31, 2010, there were no significant transfers in and out of Level 1 and Level 2.
313716_11_ITEM8_P153_S0	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, the carrying value of notes receivable approximated their fair value.

313716_11_ITEM8_P157_S0	(1) Growth funds represent a type of fund containing a diversified portfolio of domestic and international equities with a goal of capital appreciation.
313716_11_ITEM8_P157_S1	(2) Income funds represent a type of fund with an emphasis on current income as opposed to capital appreciation.
313716_11_ITEM8_P157_S2	Such funds may contain a variety of domestic and international government and corporate debt obligations, preferred stock, money market instruments, and dividend-paying stocks.
313716_11_ITEM8_P157_S3	(3) Growth and Income funds represent a type of fund containing a combination of growth and income securities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P157_S4	(4) Hedge funds represent a managed portfolio of investments that use advanced investment strategies such as leveraged, long, short and derivative positions in both domestic and international markets with the goal of generating high returns.

313716_11_ITEM8_P160_S0	Most of our defined benefit pension plan Level 1 assets are debt and equity investments that are traded in active markets, either domestically or internationally.

313716_11_ITEM8_P163_S1	The resulting gains or losses are recorded in the statement of operations.
313716_11_ITEM8_P164_S0	To minimize foreign currency exposure, we have foreign currency forwards with notional amounts of approximately $22.3 million and $12.4 million at December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009, respectively.
313716_11_ITEM8_P165_S0	Generally, our foreign currency forwards are recorded in the balance sheet at fair value and resulting gains or losses are recorded in the statements of operations, generally offsetting the gains or losses from the revaluation of the foreign currency denominated assets and liabilities.
313716_11_ITEM8_P165_S1	At December 31, 2010, the fair value of the foreign currency forwards was a $0.3 million asset, which was included in prepaid expenses and a $0.1 million liability which was included in accrued expenses.
313716_11_ITEM8_P165_S2	At December 31, 2009, the fair value of the foreign currency forwards was a $0.06 million asset, which was included in prepaid expenses and a $0.03 million liability which was included in accrued expenses.

313716_11_ITEM8_P170_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_11_ITEM8_P171_S0	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liability for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_11_ITEM8_P172_S0	Activities at properties we own or previously owned and on adjacent areas have resulted in environmental impacts.
313716_11_ITEM8_P173_S0	In particular, our Elmira, New York manufacturing facility is located within the Kentucky Avenue Wellfield on the National Priorities List of hazardous waste sites designated for cleanup by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_11_ITEM8_P174_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, New York.
313716_11_ITEM8_P175_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_11_ITEM8_P175_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_11_ITEM8_P175_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_11_ITEM8_P176_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_11_ITEM8_P177_S0	Hardinge, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation, and Toshiba America, Inc., the Potentially Responsible Parties (the PRPs") have agreed to voluntarily participate in the Remedial Investigation and Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_11_ITEM8_P177_S1	On September 29, 2006, the Director of Emergency and Remedial Response Division of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region II, approved and executed the Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_11_ITEM8_P178_S0	also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the cost of the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_11_ITEM8_P178_S1	The cost of the RI/FS was estimated to be approximately $0.84 million.
313716_11_ITEM8_P178_S2	We estimate our portion of the study to be $0.12 million for which we have established a reserve of $0.13 million.
313716_11_ITEM8_P178_S3	As of December 31, 2010 we have incurred total expenses of $0.12 million with respect to the study and other activities relating to the Site.
313716_11_ITEM8_P178_S4	The remaining reserve balance at December 31, 2010 is $0.01 million.
313716_11_ITEM8_P179_S0	The PRPs developed a Draft RI/FS with their consultants and, following EPA comments, submitted a Revised RI/FS on December 6, 2007.
313716_11_ITEM8_P179_S1	In May 2008, the EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan.
313716_11_ITEM8_P179_S2	The PRPs commenced field work in the spring of 2008 and submitted a Draft Site Characterization Report to EPA in the fall.
313716_11_ITEM8_P179_S3	The PRPs currently are performing Risk Assessments in accordance with the Remedial Investigation portion of the RI/FS.
313716_11_ITEM8_P180_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice, Hardinge had never been named as a PRP at the Site nor had we received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the site.
313716_11_ITEM8_P180_S1	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond and found no evidence that our operations or property have or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_11_ITEM8_P180_S2	Other than as described above, we have not established a reserve for any potential costs relating to this Site, as it is too early in the process to determine our responsibility as well as to estimate any potential costs to remediate.
313716_11_ITEM8_P180_S3	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_11_ITEM8_P181_S0	Although we believe, based upon information currently available that except as described in the preceding paragraphs we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to Hardinge.

313716_11_ITEM8_P223_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2009-13, Revenue Recognition ASC Topic 605: Multiple-Deliverable Revenue Arrangements a consensus of the FASB Emerging Issues Task Force (ASU 2009-13).
313716_11_ITEM8_P223_S1	ASU 2009-13 addresses the accounting for sales arrangements that include multiple products or services by revising the criteria for when deliverables may be accounted for separately rather than as a combined unit.
313716_11_ITEM8_P223_S2	Specifically, this guidance establishes a selling price hierarchy for determining the selling price of a deliverable, which is necessary to separately account for each product or service.
313716_11_ITEM8_P223_S3	This hierarchy provides more options for establishing selling price than existing guidance.
313716_11_ITEM8_P224_S0	ASU 2009-13 is required to be applied prospectively to new or materially modified revenue arrangements in fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010.
313716_11_ITEM8_P224_S1	We do not expect adoption of this standard to have a material impact on our consolidated results of operations and financial condition.

313716_11_ITEM8_P225_S1	The amendment requires new disclosures on the transfers of assets and liabilities between Level 1 (quoted prices in active market for identical assets or liabilities) and Level 2 (significant other observable inputs) of the fair value measurement hierarchy, including the reasons and the timing of the transfers.

313716_11_ITEM8_P225_S3	We have applied the new disclosure requirements as of January 1, 2010, which is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2010.

313716_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Management of the Company, under the supervision and with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, carried out an evaluation of the effectiveness as of December 31, 2010 of the design and operation of the Company's disclosure controls and procedures as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

313716_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	The management of Hardinge Inc. is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as such term is defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f).
313716_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Under the supervision of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, management conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010 based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
313716_11_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on that evaluation, management has concluded that it maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Ernst Young LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, has audited our consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K and, as part of their audit, has issued their attestation report, included herein, on the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P4_S0	There have been no changes in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the most recent fiscal quarter that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the company's internal control over financial reporting.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P5_S0	We have audited Hardinge Inc. and Subsidiaries' internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
313716_11_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Hardinge Inc. and Subsidiaries' management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management's Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P5_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P6_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
313716_11_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P6_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P6_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P7_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P7_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P8_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P8_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P9_S0	In our opinion, Hardinge Inc. and Subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on the COSO criteria.
313716_11_ITEM9A_P10_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Hardinge Inc. and Subsidiaries as of December 31, 2010 and 2009 and the related consolidated statements of operations, shareholders' equity and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2010 of Hardinge Inc. and Subsidiaries and our report dated March 14, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.

313716_11_ITEM15_P3_S0	The Hardinge Inc. Cash Incentive Plan (the Plan ) is designed to retain executives and reward them for making major contributions to the success and profitability of the Company.
313716_11_ITEM15_P3_S1	These objectives are accomplished by making incentive Awards under the Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P4_S0	(a) Award The Award to a Plan participant pursuant to terms and conditions of the Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P5_S0	(b) Award Agreement An agreement between the Company and a participant that sets forth the terms, conditions and limitations applicable to an Award.
313716_11_ITEM15_P6_S0	(c) Board The non-management Directors of Hardinge Inc.
313716_11_ITEM15_P7_S0	(d) Committee The Compensation Committee of the Board.
313716_11_ITEM15_P8_S0	(e) Company Hardinge Inc. ( Hardinge ) and any other corporation in which Hardinge controls, directly or indirectly, fifty percent (50%) or more of the combined voting power of all classes of voting securities.
313716_11_ITEM15_P9_S0	(f) Executive Officer Any officer of the Company identified by the Company in its annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission as an executive officer of the Company.
313716_11_ITEM15_P10_S0	(g) Target Award The Award expressed as a percentage of annualized base remuneration, which shall include Retention Bonuses, that may be earned by a participant for achievement of the target level of performance.
313716_11_ITEM15_P11_S0	Only Executive Officers are eligible for participation in the Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P12_S0	The Plan shall be administered by the Committee which shall have full power and authority to construe, interpret and administer the Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P12_S1	Each decision of the Committee shall be final, conclusive and binding upon all persons.
313716_11_ITEM15_P12_S2	No later than ninety (90) days after the start of each calendar year, the Committee shall recommend to the Board and the Board shall finally: (i) determine which Executive Officers are in positions in which they are likely to make substantial contributions to the Company s success and therefore participate in the Plan for the year; (ii) set Target Awards for each participant; (iii) establish performance goals and performance goal measures as provided by Section and (iv) establish the terms and conditions of the Award in effect for the year.
313716_11_ITEM15_P13_S0	(a) The Committee shall recommend to the Board and the Board shall finally establish performance goals applicable to a particular calendar year no later than ninety (90) days after the start of the year while the outcome of the performance goal is substantially uncertain.
313716_11_ITEM15_P14_S0	(b) Each performance goal applicable to a year shall identify one or more business criteria that is to be monitored during the year.
313716_11_ITEM15_P14_S1	Such business criteria include any of the following:
313716_11_ITEM15_P15_S0	Performance goals based on financial business criteria may be set on an earnings before interest and taxes, earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation or an after tax basis, may be defined by absolute or relative measures, and may be valued on a growth or fixed basis.
313716_11_ITEM15_P16_S0	(c) The Committee shall recommend to the Board and the Board shall finally determine the target level of performance that must be achieved with respect to each criteria that is identified in a performance goal in order for a performance goal to be treated as attained.
313716_11_ITEM15_P16_S1	In establishing the target level, the Board will specify the measures to be used to evaluate performance goal achievement and the weighting of each performance goal.
313716_11_ITEM15_P16_S2	The Board may also establish minimum threshold and maximum performance criteria and may make Target Awards based on its discretion without precise objective measurements.
313716_11_ITEM15_P16_S3	Profit, earnings and revenues used for any performance criteria measurements may exclude in the Committee s discretion: gains or losses on operating asset sales or dispositions; asset write-downs; litigation or claim judgments or settlements; accruals for historic obligations; effect of changes in tax law or rate on deferred tax liabilities; accruals for reorganization and restructuring programs; uninsured catastrophic property losses; the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles; and any extraordinary non-recurring items as described in Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 30 and/or in management s discussion and analysis of financial performance appearing in the Company s annual report to shareholders for the applicable year.
313716_11_ITEM15_P17_S0	(d) The Board may base performance goals on one or more of the foregoing business criteria.
313716_11_ITEM15_P17_S1	In the event performance goals are based on more than one business criteria, the Board may determine to make Awards upon attainment of the performance goal relating to any one or more of such criteria, provided the performance goals, when established, are stated as alternatives to one another.
313716_11_ITEM15_P18_S0	(e) At the time the Board sets performance goals, the Board will establish the Target Award for each participant.
313716_11_ITEM15_P19_S0	The Committee shall make Awards only in the event the Committee certifies in writing prior to payment of the Award that the performance goal or goals under which the Award is to be paid has or have been attained.
313716_11_ITEM15_P20_S0	(b) Depending on performance, actual Awards may vary from the Target Award, reflecting the minimum threshold to the maximum performance level of goal achievement.
313716_11_ITEM15_P21_S0	(c) Notwithstanding actual Company performance against applicable performance goals for a year, the Committee, in its sole and absolute discretion, may pay or withhold an amount not to exceed twenty-five percent (25%) of a participant s Target Award.
313716_11_ITEM15_P21_S1	In addition, the Committee in its sole and absolute discretion may reduce but not increase the amount of an Award otherwise payable to a participant upon attainment of the performance goal or goals established for a year.
313716_11_ITEM15_P22_S0	(d) A participant s performance must be satisfactory, regardless of Company performance, before he or she may be paid an Award.
313716_11_ITEM15_P23_S0	(e) In the event the performance goals for a year are attained, the Committee shall grant all or such portion of an Award for the year as has been earned based on performance achievement to any participant who is appointed or promoted to an Executive Officer position covered by this Plan during the year, or whose employment is terminated during the year, or who suffers a permanent disability.
313716_11_ITEM15_P24_S0	Each participant shall be paid the Award in cash as soon as practicable after the Committee has determined that Awards have been earned and are payable.
313716_11_ITEM15_P25_S0	The Company shall have the right to deduct applicable taxes from any Award payment.
313716_11_ITEM15_P26_S0	Amendment, Modification, Suspension or Discontinuance of this Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P27_S0	The Board may amend, modify, suspend or terminate the Plan for the purpose of meeting or addressing any changes in legal requirements or for any other purpose permitted by law.
313716_11_ITEM15_P27_S1	No amendment, suspension, termination or discontinuance may impair the right of a participant or his or her designated beneficiary to receive any Award accrued prior to the later of the date of adoption or the effective date of such amendment, suspension, termination or discontinuance.
313716_11_ITEM15_P27_S2	The exercise of the Committee s discretion as permitted by Section 6(c) shall not be deemed to constitute an amendment or modification subject to the provisions of this Section 9.
313716_11_ITEM15_P28_S0	If the employment of a participant terminates, other than pursuant to paragraphs (a) and (b) of this Section 10, all unpaid Awards shall be cancelled immediately, unless the Committee in its discretion determines otherwise.
313716_11_ITEM15_P29_S0	(a) Retirement When a participant s employment terminates as a result of retirement, the participant will receive an Award reflecting performance and actual period of employment during the calendar year of retirement.
313716_11_ITEM15_P30_S0	(b) Death or Disability of a Participant.
313716_11_ITEM15_P31_S0	In the event of a participant s death, the participant s estate or beneficiaries shall have the right to receive an Award reflecting performance and actual period of employment during the calendar year of death or disability.
313716_11_ITEM15_P31_S1	Rights to any such outstanding Awards shall pass by will or the laws of descent and distribution in the following order: (a) to beneficiaries so designated by the participant; if none, then (b) to a legal representative of the participant; if none, then (c) to the persons entitled thereto as determined by a court of competent jurisdiction.
313716_11_ITEM15_P31_S2	Awards so passing shall be made at such times and in such manner as if the participant were living.
313716_11_ITEM15_P32_S0	In the event a participant is disabled, the participant will receive an Award reflecting performance and actual period of employment during the calendar year.
313716_11_ITEM15_P32_S1	In the event the participant is incapacitated, the Award will be paid to the participant s authorized legal representative.
313716_11_ITEM15_P33_S0	After the death or disability of a participant, the Committee may in its sole discretion at any time (a) terminate restrictions in Award Agreements; (b) accelerate any or all Awards; and (c) instruct the Company to pay the total of any accelerated payments in a lump sum to the participant, the participant s estate, beneficiaries or representative.
313716_11_ITEM15_P34_S0	(iv) In the event of uncertainty as to interpretation of or controversies concerning this paragraph (b) of Section 10, the Committee s determinations shall be binding and conclusive.
313716_11_ITEM15_P35_S0	Unless the Award Agreement specifies otherwise, the Committee may cancel any unpaid Awards at any time if the participant is not in compliance with all other applicable provisions of the Award Agreement and the Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P35_S1	Awards may also be cancelled if the Committee determines that the participant has at any time engaged in activity harmful to the interest of or in competition with the Company.
313716_11_ITEM15_P36_S0	No award or any other benefit under the Plan shall be assignable or transferable by the participant during the participant s lifetime.
313716_11_ITEM15_P37_S0	Although bookkeeping accounts may be established with respect to participants, any such accounts shall be used merely as a bookkeeping convenience.
313716_11_ITEM15_P37_S1	The Company shall not be required to segregate any assets for payment under the Plan, nor shall the Plan be construed as providing for such segregation, nor shall the Company nor the Board nor the Committee be deemed to be a trustee of any Award under the Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P37_S2	Any liability of the Company to any participant with respect to an Award under the Plan shall be based solely upon any contractual obligations that may be created by the Plan and any Award Agreement; no such obligation of the Company shall be deemed to be secured by any pledge or other encumbrance on any property of the Company.
313716_11_ITEM15_P37_S3	Neither the Company nor the Board nor the Committee shall be required to give any security or bond for the performance of any obligation that may be created by the Plan.
313716_11_ITEM15_P38_S0	Nothing in this Plan shall confer upon any employee any right to continue in the employ of the Company or shall interfere with or restrict in any way the right of the Company to discharge an employee at any time for any reason whatsoever, with or without good cause.

313716_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	We are a global designer, manufacturer and distributor of machine tools, specializing in precision computer numerically controlled metal-cutting machines.
313716_12_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Company has the following direct and indirect wholly owned subsidiaries:
313716_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	We have manufacturing facilities located in China, Switzerland, Taiwan, the United Kingdom ("U.K.") and the United States ("U.S.").
313716_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	We manufacture the majority of the products we sell.
313716_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metal-cutting turning machines, grinding machines, vertical machining centers, and accessories related to those machines.
313716_12_ITEM1_P6_S1	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	We have been a manufacturer of industrial-use high precision and general precision turning machine tools since 1890.
313716_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	material from either bar stock or a rough-formed part by moving multiple cutting tools against the surface of a part rotating at very high speeds in a spindle mechanism.
313716_12_ITEM1_P8_S1	The multi-directional movement of the cutting tools allows the part to be shaped to the desired dimensions.
313716_12_ITEM1_P8_S2	On parts produced by our machines, those dimensions are often measured in millionths of an inch.
313716_12_ITEM1_P8_S3	We consider Hardinge to be a leader in the field of producing machines capable of consistently and cost-effectively producing parts to very close dimensions.
313716_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	Grinding is a machining process in which a part's surface is shaped to closer tolerances with a rotating abrasive wheel or tool.
313716_12_ITEM1_P9_S1	Grinding machines can be used to finish parts of various shapes and sizes.
313716_12_ITEM1_P9_S2	The grinding machines of our Kellenberger subsidiary are used to grind the inside and outside diameters of cylindrical parts.
313716_12_ITEM1_P9_S3	Such grinding machines are typically used to provide a more exact finish on a part that has been partially completed on a lathe.
313716_12_ITEM1_P9_S4	The grinding machines of Kellenberger, which are manufactured in both computer and manually controlled models, are generally purchased by the same type of customers as other Hardinge equipment and further our ability to be a primary source for our customers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P10_S0	Our Kellenberger precision grinding technology is complemented by our Hauser and Tschudin grinding brands.
313716_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	Hauser machines are jig grinders used to make demanding contour components, primarily for tool and mold-making applications.
313716_12_ITEM1_P11_S1	Tschudin product technology is focused on the specialized grinding of cylindrical parts when the customer requires high volume production.
313716_12_ITEM1_P11_S2	Our Tschudin machines are generally equipped with automatic loading and unloading mechanisms for the part being machined.
313716_12_ITEM1_P11_S3	These loading and unloading mechanisms significantly reduce the level of involvement a machine operator has to perform in the production process.
313716_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	During 2010, the Company established Jones Shipman Grinding Limited.
313716_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	after acquiring the assets of Jones and Shipman, a UK-based manufacturer of grinding and super-abrasive machines and machining systems.
313716_12_ITEM1_P12_S2	Jones Shipman manufactures and distributes a range of high-quality grinding (surface, creep feed and cylindrical) machines used by a diverse range of industries.
313716_12_ITEM1_P13_S0	Machining centers are designed to remove material from stationary, prismatic or box-like parts of various shapes with rotating tools that are capable of milling, drilling, tapping, reaming and routing.
313716_12_ITEM1_P13_S1	Machining centers have mechanisms that automatically change tools based on commands from a built-in computer control without the assistance of an operator.
313716_12_ITEM1_P13_S2	Machining centers are generally purchased by the same customers who purchase other Hardinge equipment.
313716_12_ITEM1_P13_S3	We supply a broad line of machining centers under our Bridgeport brand name addressing a range of sizes, speeds, and powers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our machines are generally computer controlled and use commands from an integrated computer to control the movement of cutting tools, grinding wheels, part positioning, and in the case of turning and grinding machines, the rotation speeds of the part being shaped.
313716_12_ITEM1_P14_S1	The computer control enables the operator to program operations such as part rotation, tooling selection, and tooling movement for a specific part and then stores that program in memory for future use.
313716_12_ITEM1_P14_S2	The machines are able to produce parts while left unattended when connected to automatic bar-feeding, robotics equipment, or other material handling devices designed to supply raw materials and remove machined parts from the machine.
313716_12_ITEM1_P15_S0	New products are critical to our growth plans.
313716_12_ITEM1_P15_S1	We gain access to new products through internal product development, acquisitions, joint ventures, license agreements, and partnerships.
313716_12_ITEM1_P15_S2	Products are introduced each year to both broaden our product offering, to take advantage of new technologies available to us, and to replace previous models nearing the end of their life cycles.
313716_12_ITEM1_P15_S3	These technologies generally allow our machines to run at higher speeds and with more power, thus increasing their efficiency.
313716_12_ITEM1_P15_S4	Customers routinely replace old machines with newer machines that can produce parts faster and with less time to set up the machine when converting from one type of part to another.
313716_12_ITEM1_P15_S5	Generally, our machines can be used to produce parts from all of the standard ferrous and non-ferrous metals, as well as plastics, composites, and exotic materials.
313716_12_ITEM1_P16_S0	We focus on products and solutions for companies making parts from hard to machine materials with hard to sustain close tolerances and hard to achieve surface finishes and which also may be hard to hold in the machine.
313716_12_ITEM1_P16_S1	We believe that with our high precision and super precision lathes, our grinding machines, and our rugged machining centers, combined with our accessory products and our technical expertise, we are uniquely qualified to be the supplier of choice for customers manufacturing to demanding specifications.
313716_12_ITEM1_P17_S0	On many of our machines, multiple options are available which allow customers to customize their machines to their specific operating performance and cost objectives.
313716_12_ITEM1_P17_S1	We produce machines for stock with popular option combinations for immediate delivery, as well as design and produce machines to specific customer requirements.
313716_12_ITEM1_P17_S2	In addition to our machines, we provide the necessary tooling, accessories, and support services to assist customers in maximizing their return on investment.
313716_12_ITEM1_P18_S0	The sale of repair parts is important to our business.
313716_12_ITEM1_P19_S0	Certain parts on machines wear over time or break through misuse.
313716_12_ITEM1_P19_S1	Customers will buy parts from us throughout the life of the machine, which is generally measured in multiple years.
313716_12_ITEM1_P19_S2	There are thousands of machines in operation in the world for which we provide those repair parts and in many cases the parts are available exclusively from us.
313716_12_ITEM1_P19_S3	In addition, we offer an extensive line of accessories including workholding, toolholding, and other industrial support products, which may be used on both our machines and those produced by others.
313716_12_ITEM1_P20_S0	We offer various warranties on our equipment and consider post-sale support to be a critical element of our business.
313716_12_ITEM1_P20_S1	Warranties on machines typically extend for twelve months after purchase.
313716_12_ITEM1_P20_S2	Services provided include operation and maintenance training, in-field maintenance, and in-field repair.
313716_12_ITEM1_P20_S3	We offer these post sales support services on a paid basis throughout the life of the machine.
313716_12_ITEM1_P20_S4	In territories covered by distributors, this support and service is offered through the distributor.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S0	We sell our products in most of the industrialized countries of the world through a combination of distributors, agents, and manufacturers' representatives.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S1	In certain areas of China, France, Germany, Netherlands, North America, and the United Kingdom, we have also used a direct sales force for portions of our product lines.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S2	Generally, our distributors have an exclusive right to sell our products in a defined geographic area.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S3	Our distributors operate as independent businesses and purchase products from us at discounted prices for their customers, while agents and representatives sell products on our behalf and receive commissions on sales.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S4	Our discount schedule is adjusted to reflect the level of pre and post sales support offered by our distributors.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S5	Our direct sales personnel earn a fixed salary plus commission.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S6	Sales through distributors are made only on standard commercial open account terms or through letters of credit.
313716_12_ITEM1_P21_S7	Distributors generally take title to products upon shipment from our facilities and do not have any special return privileges.
313716_12_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our non-machine products are sold in the U.S. mainly through direct telephone orders to a toll-free telephone number and via our web site at www.shophardinge.com.
313716_12_ITEM1_P22_S1	In most cases, we are able to package and ship in-stock tooling and repair parts within 24 hours of receiving orders.
313716_12_ITEM1_P22_S2	We can package and ship items with heavy demand within a few hours.
313716_12_ITEM1_P22_S3	In other parts of the world, these products are sold on either a direct sales basis or through distributor arrangements.
313716_12_ITEM1_P23_S0	We promote recognition of our products in the marketplace through advertising in trade publications, web presences, email newsletters, and participation in industry trade shows.
313716_12_ITEM1_P23_S1	In addition, we market our non-machine products through publication of general catalogues and other targeted catalogues, which we distribute to existing and prospective customers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P23_S2	We have a substantial presence on the internet at www.hardinge.com where customers can obtain information about our products and place orders for workholding, rotary, and knee mill products.
313716_12_ITEM1_P24_S0	A substantial portion of our end use customers are small and medium-sized independent job shops, which in turn sell machined parts to their industrial customers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P24_S1	Industries directly and indirectly served by us include aerospace, automotive, computer, communications, consumer-electronics, construction equipment, defense, energy, farm equipment, medical equipment, recreational equipment, and transportation.
313716_12_ITEM1_P25_S0	In 2011, no single customer or related group of customers accounted for more than 10% our consolidated sales.
313716_12_ITEM1_P25_S1	In 2010, a customer who is a supplier to the consumer electronics industry accounted for 10.7% of our consolidated sales.
313716_12_ITEM1_P25_S2	While valuing our relationship with each customer, we do not believe that the loss of any single customer, or any few customers, would have an adverse material effect on our business.
313716_12_ITEM1_P26_S0	Hardinge Inc. operates in a single business segment, industrial machine tools.
313716_12_ITEM1_P27_S0	In our industry, the barriers to entry for competition vary based on the level of product performance required.
313716_12_ITEM1_P27_S1	For the products with the highest performance in terms of accuracy and productivity, the barriers are generally technical in nature.
313716_12_ITEM1_P27_S2	For basic products, often the barriers are not technical; they are tied to product availability, competitive price position, and an effective distribution model that offers the pre and post sales support required by customers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P28_S0	Another significant barrier in the global machine tool industry is the high level of working capital that is required to operate the business.
313716_12_ITEM1_P29_S0	We compete in the various segments of the machine tool market within the products of turning, milling, grinding and workholding.
313716_12_ITEM1_P29_S1	We compete with numerous vendors in each market segment we serve.
313716_12_ITEM1_P29_S2	The primary competitive factors in the marketplace for our machine tools are reliability, price, delivery time, service, and technological characteristics.
313716_12_ITEM1_P29_S3	Our management considers our segment of the industry to be extremely competitive.
313716_12_ITEM1_P30_S0	There are many manufacturers of machine tools in the world.
313716_12_ITEM1_P30_S1	They can be categorized by the size of material their products can machine and the precision level they can achieve.
313716_12_ITEM1_P31_S0	For our high precision, multi-tasking turning and milling equipment, competition comes primarily from companies such as Mori-Seiki, Mazak, and Okuma, which are based in Japan, and DMG, which is based in Germany.
313716_12_ITEM1_P31_S1	Competition in our more standard turning and milling equipment comes to some degree from those companies as well as Doosan, which is based in South Korea, and Haas which is based in the U.S., as well as many Taiwanese companies.
313716_12_ITEM1_P31_S2	Our cylindrical grinding machines compete primarily with Studer, a Swiss Company as well as Toyoda and Shigiya, which are based in Japan.
313716_12_ITEM1_P31_S3	Our Hauser jig grinding machines compete primarily with Moore Tool, which is based in the U.S., and some Japanese suppliers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P31_S4	Our surface grinding machines compete with Okamoto in Japan and Chevalier in Taiwan.
313716_12_ITEM1_P31_S5	Our accessories products compete with many smaller companies.
313716_12_ITEM1_P32_S0	The overall number of our competitors providing product solutions serving our market segments may increase.
313716_12_ITEM1_P32_S1	Also, the composition of competitors may change as we broaden our product offerings and the geographic markets we serve.
313716_12_ITEM1_P32_S2	As we expand into new market segments, we will face competition not only from our existing competitors but from other competitors as well, including existing companies with strong technological, marketing and sales positions in those markets.
313716_12_ITEM1_P32_S3	In addition, several of our competitors may have greater resources, including financial, technical, and engineering resources, than we do.
313716_12_ITEM1_P33_S0	We produce certain of our lathes, knee mills, and related products at our Elmira, New York plant.
313716_12_ITEM1_P33_S1	The Kellenberger grinding machines and related products are manufactured at our St. Gallen, Switzerland plant and Hauser and Tschudin products are produced at our Biel, Switzerland facility.
313716_12_ITEM1_P33_S2	The Jones Shipman grinding machines are manufactured at our Leicester, England plant.
313716_12_ITEM1_P34_S0	machining centers and lathes at our facilities in Hardinge Taiwan in Nan Tou, Taiwan, Hardinge Machine (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. in Shanghai, China, and Hardinge Precision Machinery (Jiaxing) Co., Ltd. in Jiaxing, China.
313716_12_ITEM1_P35_S0	We manufacture products from various raw materials, including cast iron, sheet metal, and bar steel.
313716_12_ITEM1_P35_S1	We purchase a number of components, sub-assemblies and assemblies from outside suppliers, including the computer and electronic components for our computer controlled lathes, grinding machines, and machining centers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P35_S2	There are multiple suppliers for virtually all of our raw material, components, sub-assemblies and assemblies and historically, we have not experienced a serious supply interruption, however, with the recent increase in demand driven by early 2011 worldwide order activity, producers of bearings, ball screws, and linear guides had difficulty meeting demand.
313716_12_ITEM1_P35_S3	Similar demand increase in the future could impact our production schedules.
313716_12_ITEM1_P36_S0	A major component of our computer controlled machines is the computer and related electronics package.
313716_12_ITEM1_P36_S1	We purchase these components for our lathes and machining centers primarily from Fanuc Limited, a large Japanese electronics company and Heidenhain, a German control supplier.
313716_12_ITEM1_P36_S2	We also utilize controls from Siemens, another German control manufacturer, on certain machine models in our line of machining centers.
313716_12_ITEM1_P36_S3	On our grinding machines we offer Heidenhain and Fanuc controls.
313716_12_ITEM1_P36_S4	While we believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing from several other existing suppliers, and we occasionally do so for special orders, a disruption in the supply of the computer controls from one of our suppliers could cause us to experience a substantial disruption of our operations, depending on the circumstances at the time.
313716_12_ITEM1_P36_S5	We purchase parts from these suppliers under normal trade terms.
313716_12_ITEM1_P36_S6	There are no agreements with these suppliers to purchase minimum volumes per year.
313716_12_ITEM1_P37_S0	Our ongoing research and development program involves creating new products, modifying existing products to meet market demands, and redesigning existing products, both to add new functionality and to reduce the cost of manufacturing.
313716_12_ITEM1_P38_S0	The research and development departments throughout the world are staffed with experienced design engineers with varying levels of education, ranging from technical to doctoral degrees.
313716_12_ITEM1_P39_S0	The worldwide cost of research and development, all of which has been charged to cost of goods sold, amounted to $12.2 million, $9.4 million and $9.3 million, in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
313716_12_ITEM1_P40_S0	Although we hold several patents with respect to certain of our products, we do not believe that our business is dependent to any material extent upon any single patent or group of patents.
313716_12_ITEM1_P41_S0	Hardinge's business and that of the machine tool industry in general, is cyclical.
313716_12_ITEM1_P41_S1	It is not subject to significant seasonal trends.
313716_12_ITEM1_P41_S2	However, our quarterly results are subject to fluctuation based on the timing of our shipments of machine tools, which are largely dependent upon customer delivery requirements.
313716_12_ITEM1_P41_S3	Given that a larger percentage of our sales are now from Asia, the impact of plant shutdowns in that region by us and our customers due to the Lunar New Year may impact first quarter sales, income from operations, and net income, and result in the first quarter being the lowest quarter of the year.
313716_12_ITEM1_P42_S0	The ability to deliver products within a short period of time is an important competitive criterion.
313716_12_ITEM1_P42_S1	We must have inventory on hand to meet customers' delivery expectations, which for standard machines are typically from immediate to eight weeks delivery.
313716_12_ITEM1_P42_S2	Meeting this requirement is especially difficult with some of our products, where delivery is extended due to ocean travel times, depending on the location of the customer.
313716_12_ITEM1_P42_S3	This creates a need to have inventory of finished machines available in our major markets to serve our customers in a timely manner.
313716_12_ITEM1_P43_S0	We deliver many of our machine products within one to two months after the order.
313716_12_ITEM1_P43_S1	Some orders, especially multiple machine orders, are delivered on a turnkey basis with the machine or group of machines configured to make certain parts for the customer.
313716_12_ITEM1_P43_S2	This type of order often includes the addition of material handling equipment, tooling and specific programming.
313716_12_ITEM1_P43_S3	In those cases the customer usually observes and inspects the parts being made on the machine at our facility before it is shipped and the timing of the sale is dependent upon the customer's schedule and acceptance.
313716_12_ITEM1_P43_S4	Therefore, sales from quarter-to-quarter can vary depending upon the timing of those customers' acceptances and the significance of those orders.
313716_12_ITEM1_P44_S0	We feel it is important, where practical, to provide readily available workholding and replacement parts for the machines we sell and we carry inventory at levels sufficient to meet these customer requirements.
313716_12_ITEM1_P45_S0	We believe that our current operations and our current uses of property, plant and equipment conform in all material respects to applicable laws and regulations in the multiple countries in which we conduct business.
313716_12_ITEM1_P46_S0	No material portion of our business is subject to government contracts.
313716_12_ITEM1_P47_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_12_ITEM1_P48_S0	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liabilities for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_12_ITEM1_P49_S0	Hazardous substances and adverse environmental effects have been identified with respect to certain property we own and on adjacent areas.
313716_12_ITEM1_P50_S0	In particular, our Elmira, NY manufacturing facility is located within the Kentucky Avenue Wellfield on the National Priorities List of hazardous waste sites designated for cleanup by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_12_ITEM1_P51_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, NY.
313716_12_ITEM1_P52_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_12_ITEM1_P52_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_12_ITEM1_P52_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_12_ITEM1_P53_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_12_ITEM1_P54_S0	The Company, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation and Toshiba America, Inc. (the Potentially Responsible Parties or "PRPs") has agreed to voluntarily participate in the Remedial Investigation and Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_12_ITEM1_P54_S1	On September 29, 2006, the Director of Emergency and Remedial Response Division of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region II, approved and executed the Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_12_ITEM1_P54_S2	The PRPs also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the cost of the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_12_ITEM1_P55_S0	In May 2008, the EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan.
313716_12_ITEM1_P55_S1	The PRPs commenced field work in the spring of 2008 and on September 7, 2011 submitted the draft Remedial Investigation Report to the EPA.
313716_12_ITEM1_P55_S2	The PRPs are continuing to address EPA comments and to perform the tasks required by the RI/FS Work Plan and Administrative Settlement Agreement.
313716_12_ITEM1_P56_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice in February 2006, the Company had never been named as a PRP at the Site nor had the Company received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the Site.
313716_12_ITEM1_P57_S0	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond, and had found no evidence that our operations or property have contributed or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_12_ITEM1_P57_S1	We have not established a reserve for any potential costs relating to this Site, as it is too early in the process to determine our responsibility as well as to estimate any potential costs to remediate.
313716_12_ITEM1_P57_S2	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_12_ITEM1_P58_S0	Although we believe, based upon information currently available that, except as described in the preceding paragraphs, we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to the Company.
313716_12_ITEM1_P59_S0	As of December 31, 2011, Hardinge Inc. employed 1,332 persons, 409 of whom were located in the United States.
313716_12_ITEM1_P59_S1	None of our U.S. employees are covered by collective bargaining agreements.
313716_12_ITEM1_P59_S2	Management believes that relations with Hardinge's employees are good.
313716_12_ITEM1_P60_S0	Information related to foreign and domestic operations and sales is included in Note 8 to the Consolidated Financial Statements contained in this Annual Report.
313716_12_ITEM1_P61_S0	Our strategy has been to diversify our sales and operations geographically so that the impact of economic trends in different regions can be balanced.
313716_12_ITEM1_P62_S0	The risks associated with conducting business on an international basis are discussed further in Item 1A Risk Factors.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The various risks related to the Company's business include the risks described below.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	The business, financial condition or results of operations of Hardinge Inc. could be materially adversely affected by any of these risks.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The risks and uncertainties described below or elsewhere in this Form 10-K are not the only ones to which we are exposed.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also adversely affect our business and operations.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P1_S2	If any of the matters included in the following risks were to occur, our business, financial condition, results of operations, cash flows or prospects could be materially adversely affected.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our customers' activity levels and spending for our products and services have been impacted by the current global economic conditions, especially deterioration in the credit markets.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Many of our customers finance their purchases of our products through cash flow from operations, the incurrence of debt or from the proceeds received in connection with an issuance of equity.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The recent world-wide financial crisis and related impact on the global financial market generated significant losses due to failures of many dominant financial institutions.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The governments of the United States and several foreign countries instituted bailout plans to assist many banks and others impacted by the economic crisis.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P4_S2	This crisis has resulted in, among other things, a significant decline in the credit markets and the availability of credit, the impact of which is still being experienced today in some of our markets.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Additionally, many of our customers' equity values have substantially declined.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P4_S4	The combination of a reduction in borrowing bases under asset based credit facilities and the reduced availability of debt or equity financing may result in a decrease in our customers' spending for our products and may impact the ability of our customers to pay amounts owed to us.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P4_S5	In addition, this crisis and economic uncertainty resulted in an overall decrease in consumer and business spending, which negatively impacted the need our customers have for our products.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	While economic conditions have shown signs of improvement in many of our markets, future slow or negative growth in the global economy may materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Changes in general economic conditions and the cyclical nature of our business could harm our operating results.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our business is cyclical in nature, following the strength and weakness of the manufacturing economies in the geographic markets we serve.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P7_S1	As a result of this cyclicality, we have experienced, and in the future we can be expected to experience, significant fluctuations in sales and operating income, which may affect our business, operating results, financial condition and the market price of our common shares.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The following factors, among others, significantly influence demand for our products:
313716_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Fluctuations in capacity at both OEMs and job shops; The availability of skilled machinists; The need to replace machines that have reached the end of their useful life; The need to replace older machines with new technology that increases productivity, reduces general manufacturing costs, and machines parts in a new way; The evolution of end-use products requiring machining to more specific tolerances; Our customers' use of new materials requiring machining by different processes; General economic and manufacturing industry expansions and contractions; and Changes in manufacturing capabilities in developing regions.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our competitive position and prospects for growth may be diminished if we are unable to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The machine tool industry is subject to technological change, rapidly evolving industry standards, changing customer requirements, and improvements in and expansion of product offerings, especially with respect to computer-controlled products.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Our ability to anticipate changes in technology, industry standards, customer requirements and product offerings by competitors, and to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market, will be significant factors in our ability to compete and grow.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Moreover, if technologies or standards used in our products become obsolete or fail to gain widespread commercial acceptance, our business would be materially adversely affected.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Developments by our competitors or others may render our products or technologies obsolete or noncompetitive.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Failure to effectively introduce new products or product enhancements on a timely basis could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We rely on a limited number of suppliers to obtain certain components, sub-assemblies, assemblies and products.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Delays in deliveries from or the loss of any of these suppliers may cause us to incur additional costs, result in delays in manufacturing and delivering our products or cause us to carry excess or obsolete inventory.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Some components, sub-assemblies, or assemblies we use in the manufacturing of our products are purchased from a limited number of suppliers.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Our purchases from these suppliers are generally not made pursuant to long-term contracts and are subject to additional risks associated with purchasing products internationally, including risks associated with potential import restrictions and exchange rate fluctuations, as well as changes in tax laws, tariffs, and freight rates.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Although we believe that our relationships with these suppliers are good, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain these products from these suppliers on satisfactory terms indefinitely.

313716_12_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Our pension expense, the funding status of our plans and related charges in other comprehensive income, and our required contributions to our pension plans are directly affected by the value of plan assets, the projected rate of return on plan assets, the actual rate of return on plan assets and the actuarial assumptions we use to measure our defined benefit pension plan obligations, including the rate at which future obligations are discounted to a present value, or the discount rate.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Our market-related value of assets recognizes asset losses and gains over a five-year period, which we believe is consistent with the long-term nature of our pension obligations.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P50_S1	As a result, the effect of changes in the market value of assets on our pension expense may be experienced in future years rather than fully reflected in the expense for the year immediately following the year in which the fluctuations actually occurred.

313716_12_ITEM1A_P51_S3	Investment earnings in excess of the assumed rate of return may reduce future pension expenses and funding requirements.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P52_S0	For our domestic and foreign plans, discount rates are based on the yields on high grade corporate bonds in each market with maturities matching the projected benefit payments.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Discount rates are used to determine the present value of the projected and accumulated benefit obligation at the end of each year.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P52_S2	A change in the discount rate would impact the funded status of our plans.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P52_S3	An increase to the discount rate would reduce the pension liability and future pension expense and, conversely, a lower discount rate would increase pension liability and the future pension expense.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P53_S0	asset classes in which the portfolio is invested, and the expectations for future returns of each asset class.

313716_12_ITEM1A_P93_S0	In May 2008, the EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P93_S1	The PRPs commenced field work in the spring of 2008 and on September 7, 2011 submitted the draft Remedial Investigation Report to the EPA.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P93_S2	The PRPs are continuing to address EPA comments and to perform the tasks required by the RI/FS Work Plan and Administrative Settlement Agreement.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P94_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice in February 2006, the Company had never been named as a PRP at the Site nor had the Company received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the Site.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P95_S0	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond, and had found no evidence that our operations or property have contributed or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P95_S1	We have not established a reserve for any potential costs relating to this Site, as it is too early in the process to determine our responsibility as well as to estimate any potential costs to remediate.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P95_S2	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P96_S0	Although we believe, based upon information currently available that, except as described in the preceding paragraphs, we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to the Company.

313716_12_ITEM1A_P102_S0	Anti-takeover provisions in our charter documents and under New York law may discourage a third party from acquiring us.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P103_S0	Certain provisions of our certificate of incorporation and bylaws may have the effect of discouraging a third party from making a proposal to acquire us and, as a result, may inhibit a change in control of the Company under circumstances that could give the shareholders the opportunity to realize a premium over the then-prevailing market price of our common shares.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P104_S0	Our certificate of incorporation and bylaws provide that our Board of Directors, currently consisting of eight members, is divided into three classes of directors, with each class consisting of two or three directors, and with the classes serving staggered three-year terms.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P104_S1	This classification of the directors has the effect of making it more difficult for shareholders, including those holding a majority of our outstanding shares, to force an immediate change in the composition of our Board of Directors.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P105_S0	Removal of Directors and Filling of Vacancies.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P105_S1	Our certificate of incorporation provides that a member of our Board of Directors may be removed only for cause and upon the affirmative vote of the holders of 75% of the securities entitled to vote at an election of directors.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P105_S2	Newly created directorships and Board of Director vacancies resulting from death, removal or other causes may be filled only by a majority vote of the then remaining directors.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P105_S3	Accordingly, it is more difficult for shareholders, including those holding a majority of our outstanding shares, to force an immediate change in the composition of our Board of Directors.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P106_S0	Supermajority Voting Provisions for Certain Business Combinations.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P106_S1	Our certificate of incorporation requires the affirmative vote of at least 75% of all of the securities entitled to vote and at least 75% of shareholders who are not Major Shareholders (defined as 10% beneficial holders) in order to effect certain mergers, sales of assets or other business combinations involving the Company.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P106_S2	These provisions could have the effect of delaying, deferring or preventing a change of control of the Company.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P107_S0	In addition, as a New York corporation we are subject to provisions of the New York Business Corporation Law which may make it more difficult for a third party to acquire and exercise control over us pursuant to a tender offer or request or invitation for tenders.
313716_12_ITEM1A_P107_S1	These provisions could have the effect of deterring or delaying changes in incumbent management, proxy contests or changes in control.

313716_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	Our primary business is designing, manufacturing, and distributing high-precision computer controlled metal-cutting turning, grinding, and milling machines and related accessories.
313716_12_ITEM7_P0_S1	We are geographically diversified with manufacturing facilities in Switzerland, Taiwan, the United States ("U.S."), China, and the United Kingdom ("U.K.") with sales to most industrialized countries.
313716_12_ITEM7_P0_S2	Approximately 74% of our 2011 sales were to customers outside of North America, 82% of our 2011 products sold were manufactured outside of North America, and 70% of our employees were outside of North America.
313716_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our machine products are considered to be capital goods and are part of what has historically been a highly cyclical industry.
313716_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our management believes that a key performance indicator is our order level as compared to industry measures of market activity levels.
313716_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	General economic conditions around the world continued to improve during 2011 when compared to 2009 and 2010, as the world recovered from the global economic recession.
313716_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	Reduced availability of credit continues to impact our customers' ability to obtain financing in certain regions.
313716_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	Order volumes continued to improve in 2011, increasing 26% over 2010.
313716_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	This growth was on top of the increase of 70% in 2010 compared to 2009.
313716_12_ITEM7_P2_S4	The 2011 order levels exceeded the 2008 order levels for our Asia Other region, despite a slowdown in this region during the second half of 2011.
313716_12_ITEM7_P2_S5	Our North America and Europe regions were both very strong in 2011, increasing 42% and 33%, respectively, over 2010.
313716_12_ITEM7_P2_S6	However, these regions have not yet reached the 2008 levels.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	Metrics on machine tool market activity watched by our management include world machine tool consumption (a proxy for shipments), as reported annually by Gardner Publications in the Metalworking Insiders Report and metal-cutting machine orders as reported by the Association of Manufacturing Technology ("AMT"), the primary industry group for U.S. machine tool manufacturers.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	World machine tool consumption data as reported by the Metalworking Insiders Report showed an increase in machine tool consumption of 35% in 2011 compared to an increase of 19% in 2010.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	This report indicates that 2011 consumption in China, the world's largest market, increased by 35% (in US dollars) on top of a 2010 increase of 38%.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S3	Consumption in Germany, the world's third largest market, increased by 42% in local currencies in 2011 compared to a 2010 decrease of 9%.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S4	In the United Kingdom, machine tool consumption measured in local currency increased by 28% in 2011 and 6% in 2010.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S5	In the U.S., 2011 machine tool consumption increased by 53%, a sharp rebound from the 2010 decrease of 15%.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S6	In 2011, U.S. orders for metal-cutting machine tools reported by the AMT were $5.5 billion, an increase of 66% over 2010, driven by the economic recovery in the U.S. market.
313716_12_ITEM7_P3_S7	Despite the decrease in consumption, in 2010, orders for metal cutting machines increased by 85% versus 2009.
