313716_14_ITEM1_P3_S0	We are a global designer, manufacturer and distributor of machine tools, specializing in precision computer numerically controlled metalcutting machines and workholding technology solutions.
313716_14_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Company has the following direct and indirect wholly owned subsidiaries:
313716_14_ITEM1_P4_S0	We have manufacturing facilities located in China, Switzerland, Taiwan, Germany, France, the United Kingdom ("U.K.") and the United States ("U.S.").
313716_14_ITEM1_P5_S0	We manufacture the majority of the products we sell.
313716_14_ITEM1_P6_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metalcutting turning machines, grinding machines, machining centers, and repair parts related to those machines.
313716_14_ITEM1_P6_S1	The Company also engineers and supplies high precision, standard and specialty workholding devices, and other machine tool accessories.
313716_14_ITEM1_P6_S2	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_14_ITEM1_P7_S0	In connection with the acquisition of the Forkardt business ("Forkardt") in 2013, the Company has realigned the manner in which financial results are monitored and decisions are made, creating two unique business segments; Metalcutting Machine Solutions (MMS) and Aftermarket Tooling and Accessories (ATA).
313716_14_ITEM1_P8_S0	This segment includes operations related to grinding, turning, and milling, as discussed below, and related repair parts.
313716_14_ITEM1_P8_S1	The products are considered to be capital goods with sales prices ranging from approximately sixty thousand dollars for some high volume products to around $1.5 million for some lower volume grinding machines or other specialty built turnkey systems of multiple machines.
313716_14_ITEM1_P8_S2	Sales are subject to economic cycles and, because they are most often purchased to add manufacturing capacity, the cycles can be severe with customers delaying purchases during down cycles and then aggressively requiring machine deliveries during up cycles.
313716_14_ITEM1_P8_S3	Machines are purchased to a lesser extent during down cycles as our customers are looking for productivity improvements or they have new products that require new machining capabilities.
313716_14_ITEM1_P9_S0	We have been a manufacturer of industrial-use high precision and general precision turning machine tools since 1890.
313716_14_ITEM1_P10_S0	Turning machines, or lathes, are power-driven machines used to remove material from either bar stock or a rough-formed part by moving multiple cutting tools against the surface of a part rotating at very high speeds in a spindle mechanism.
313716_14_ITEM1_P10_S1	The multi-directional movement of the cutting tools allows the part to be shaped to the desired dimensions.
313716_14_ITEM1_P10_S2	On parts produced by our machines, those dimensions are often measured in millionths of an inch.
313716_14_ITEM1_P10_S3	We consider Hardinge to be a leader in the field of producing machines capable of consistently and cost-effectively producing parts to very close dimensions.
313716_14_ITEM1_P11_S0	Grinding is a machining process in which a part's surface is shaped to closer tolerances with a rotating abrasive wheel or tool than other available metalcutting technologies.
313716_14_ITEM1_P11_S1	Grinding machines can be used to finish parts of various shapes and sizes.
313716_14_ITEM1_P11_S2	The grinding machines of our Kellenberger subsidiary are used to grind the inside and outside diameters of cylindrical parts.
313716_14_ITEM1_P11_S3	Such grinding machines are typically used to provide a more exact finish on a part that has been partially completed on a lathe.
313716_14_ITEM1_P11_S4	The Kellenberger grinding machines are generally purchased by the same type of customers as other Hardinge equipment and further our ability to be a primary source for our customers.
313716_14_ITEM1_P12_S0	Our Kellenberger precision grinding technology is complemented by our Hauser, Tschudin, and Jones Shipman grinding brands.
313716_14_ITEM1_P13_S0	Hauser machines are jig grinders used to make demanding contour components, primarily for tool and mold-making applications.
313716_14_ITEM1_P13_S1	Tschudin product technology is focused on the specialized grinding of cylindrical parts when the customer requires high volume production.
313716_14_ITEM1_P13_S2	Our Tschudin machines are generally equipped with automatic loading and unloading mechanisms for the part being machined.
313716_14_ITEM1_P13_S3	These loading and unloading mechanisms significantly reduce the level of involvement a machine operator has to perform in the production process.
313716_14_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our Jones Shipman brand represents a line of high-quality grinding (surface, creep feed, and cylindrical) machines.
313716_14_ITEM1_P14_S1	These super-abrasive machines and machining systems are used by a diverse range of industries.
313716_14_ITEM1_P15_S0	In 2012, the Company acquired Usach Technologies, Inc. ("Usach"), an Illinois-based manufacturer of custom built high precision internal and external grinding machines and systems.
313716_14_ITEM1_P15_S1	The acquisition of Usach complements and enhances our grinding product portfolio.
313716_14_ITEM1_P16_S0	Machining centers are designed to remove material from stationary, prismatic or box-like parts of various shapes with rotating tools that are capable of milling, drilling, tapping, reaming and routing.
313716_14_ITEM1_P16_S1	Machining centers have mechanisms that automatically change tools based on commands from a built-in computer control without the assistance of an operator.
313716_14_ITEM1_P16_S2	Machining centers are generally purchased by the same customers who purchase other Hardinge equipment.
313716_14_ITEM1_P16_S3	We supply a broad line of machining centers under our Bridgeport brand name addressing a range of sizes, speeds, and powers.
313716_14_ITEM1_P17_S0	Our machines are generally computer controlled and use commands from an integrated computer to control the movement of cutting tools, grinding wheels, part positioning, and in the case of turning and grinding machines, the rotation speeds of the part being shaped.
313716_14_ITEM1_P17_S1	The computer control enables the operator to program operations such as part rotation, tooling selection, and tooling movement for a specific part and then stores that program in memory for future use.
313716_14_ITEM1_P17_S2	The machines are able to produce parts while left unattended when connected to automatic bar-feeding, robotics equipment, or other material handling devices designed to supply raw materials and remove machined parts from the machine.
313716_14_ITEM1_P18_S0	New products are critical to our growth plans.
313716_14_ITEM1_P18_S1	We gain access to new products through internal product development, acquisitions, joint ventures, license agreements, and partnerships.
313716_14_ITEM1_P18_S2	Products are introduced each year to both broaden our product offering, to take advantage of new technologies available to us, and to replace older models nearing the end of their respective product life cycles.
313716_14_ITEM1_P18_S3	These technologies generally allow our machines to run at higher speeds and with more power, thus increasing their efficiency.
313716_14_ITEM1_P18_S4	Customers routinely replace old machines with newer machines that can produce parts faster and with less time to set up the machine when converting from one type of part to another.
313716_14_ITEM1_P18_S5	Generally, our machines can be used to produce parts from all of the standard ferrous and non-ferrous metals, as well as plastics, composites, and exotic materials.
313716_14_ITEM1_P19_S0	We focus on products and solutions for companies making parts from hard to machine materials with hard to sustain close tolerances and hard to achieve surface finishes and which also may be hard to hold in the machine.
313716_14_ITEM1_P19_S1	We believe that with our high precision and super precision lathes, our grinding machines, and our rugged machining centers, combined with our accessory products and our technical expertise, we are uniquely qualified to be the supplier of choice for customers manufacturing to demanding specifications.
313716_14_ITEM1_P20_S0	On many of our machines, multiple options are available which allow customers to customize their machines to their specific operating performance and cost objectives.
313716_14_ITEM1_P20_S1	We produce machines for stock with popular option combinations for immediate delivery, as well as design and produce machines to specific customer requirements.
313716_14_ITEM1_P20_S2	In addition to our machines, we provide the necessary tooling, accessories, and support services to assist customers in maximizing their return on investment.
313716_14_ITEM1_P21_S0	The sale of repair parts is important to our business.
313716_14_ITEM1_P22_S0	Certain parts on machines wear out, fail, or need to be replaced due to misuse over time.
313716_14_ITEM1_P22_S1	Customers will buy parts from us throughout the life of the machine, which typically extends over many years.
313716_14_ITEM1_P22_S2	There are thousands of machines in operation in the world for which we provide those repair parts and in many cases the parts are available exclusively from us.
313716_14_ITEM1_P23_S0	We offer various warranties on our equipment and consider post-sale support to be a critical element of our business.
313716_14_ITEM1_P23_S1	Warranties on machines typically extend for twelve months after purchase.
313716_14_ITEM1_P23_S2	Services provided include operation and maintenance training, in-field maintenance, and in-field repair.
313716_14_ITEM1_P23_S3	We offer these post sales support services on a paid basis throughout the life of the machine.
313716_14_ITEM1_P23_S4	In territories covered by distributors, this support and service is offered through the distributor.
313716_14_ITEM1_P24_S0	This segment includes products that are purchased by manufacturers throughout the lives of their machines.
313716_14_ITEM1_P24_S1	The selling prices of these units are relatively low per piece with prices ranging from fifty dollars on high volume collets to twenty thousand dollars or more for specialty chucks.
313716_14_ITEM1_P24_S2	These products, while considered to be consumable are more durable in nature, with replacement due to wear over time.
313716_14_ITEM1_P25_S0	Our products are used on all types and brands of machine tools, not limited to our own.
313716_14_ITEM1_P26_S0	Sales levels are affected by manufacturing cycles, but not to the severity of the capital goods lines.
313716_14_ITEM1_P26_S1	While customers may not purchase large dollar machines during a down cycle, their factories are operating with their existing equipment and therefore accessories are still needed as they wear out or they are needed for a change in production requirements.
313716_14_ITEM1_P27_S0	We have been a supplier of Aftermarket Tooling Accessories and Solutions (ATA) since our inception.
313716_14_ITEM1_P27_S1	The two primary product groups in ATA are collets and chucks.
313716_14_ITEM1_P28_S0	Collets are cone-shaped metal sleeves used for holding circular or rod like pieces in a lathe or other machine that provide effective part holding and accurate part location during machining operations.
313716_14_ITEM1_P29_S0	Chucks are a specialized clamping device used to hold an object with radial symmetry, especially a cylindrical object.
313716_14_ITEM1_P29_S1	It is most commonly used to hold a rotating tool or a rotating work piece.
313716_14_ITEM1_P29_S2	Some of our specialty chucks can also hold irregularly shaped objects that lack radial symmetry.
313716_14_ITEM1_P30_S0	While our products are known for accuracy and durability, they are consumable in nature.
313716_14_ITEM1_P31_S0	In May of 2013, the Company acquired Forkardt, a global provider of specialty chucks.
313716_14_ITEM1_P31_S1	Forkardt is based in Traverse City, Michigan with operations in the United States and Europe that provide unique solutions for demanding workholding applications.
313716_14_ITEM1_P31_S2	This acquisition positions Hardinge as one of the largest manufacturers of these types of workholding solutions in the world.
313716_14_ITEM1_P31_S3	In December of 2013, we divested the Forkardt Swiss operations due to potential customer conflicts.
313716_14_ITEM1_P32_S0	We offer an extensive line of workholding and toolholding solutions that are available in tens of thousands of shapes and sizes to meet unique customer application needs.
313716_14_ITEM1_P32_S1	These solutions can be used on virtually all types and brands of metalcutting machines, as well as non-traditional uses in many industrial applications.
313716_14_ITEM1_P32_S2	The Company continues to explore opportunities to expand this business organically and through acquisitions.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S0	We sell our products in most of the industrialized countries of the world through a combination of distributors, agents, and manufacturers' representatives.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S1	In certain areas of China, France, Germany, North America, and the United Kingdom, we have also used a direct sales force for portions of our product lines.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S2	Generally, our distributors have an exclusive right to sell our products in a defined geographic area.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S3	Our distributors operate as independent businesses and purchase products from us at discounted prices for their customers, while agents and representatives sell products on our behalf and receive commissions on sales.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S4	Our discount schedule is adjusted to reflect the level of pre and post sales support offered by our distributors.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S5	Our direct sales personnel earn a fixed salary plus commission.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S6	Sales through distributors are made only on standard commercial open account terms or through letters of credit.
313716_14_ITEM1_P33_S7	Distributors generally take title to products upon shipment from our facilities and do not have any special return privileges.
313716_14_ITEM1_P34_S0	Our standard ATA products are sold through direct telephone orders and via our web site at www.shophardinge.com.
313716_14_ITEM1_P34_S1	Custom or special solutions are sold through direct sales and agents.
313716_14_ITEM1_P34_S2	In most cases, we are able to package and ship in-stock tooling, accessories, and repair parts within 24 hours of receiving orders.
313716_14_ITEM1_P34_S3	We can package and ship items with heavy demand within a few hours.
313716_14_ITEM1_P34_S4	In other parts of the world, these products are sold on either a direct sales basis or through distributor arrangements.
313716_14_ITEM1_P35_S0	We promote recognition of our products in the marketplace through advertising in trade publications, web presences, email newsletters, and participation in industry trade shows.
313716_14_ITEM1_P35_S1	In addition, we market our non-machine products and capabilities through publication of general catalogues and other targeted catalogues, which we distribute to existing and prospective customers.
313716_14_ITEM1_P35_S2	We have a considerable presence on the internet at www.hardinge.com and www.forkardt.com, where customers can obtain information about our products and place orders for accessories, tooling, knee mill products and repair parts.
313716_14_ITEM1_P36_S0	A substantial portion of our end use customers are small and medium-sized independent job shops, which in turn sell machined parts to their industrial customers.
313716_14_ITEM1_P36_S1	Industries directly and indirectly served by us include aerospace, automotive, computer, communications, consumer-electronics, construction equipment, defense, energy, farm equipment, medical equipment, recreational equipment, and transportation.
313716_14_ITEM1_P37_S0	No single customer or related group of customers accounted for more than 6% of our consolidated sales in 2013 or 2012.
313716_14_ITEM1_P37_S1	While valuing our relationship with each customer, we do not believe that the loss of any single customer, or any few customers, would have an adverse material effect on our business.
313716_14_ITEM1_P38_S0	In our industry, the barriers to entry for competition vary based on the level of product performance required.
313716_14_ITEM1_P38_S1	For the products with the highest performance in terms of accuracy and productivity, the barriers are generally technical in nature.
313716_14_ITEM1_P38_S2	For basic products, often the barriers are not technical; they are tied to product availability, competitive price position, and an effective distribution model that offers the pre and post sales support required by customers.
313716_14_ITEM1_P39_S0	Another significant barrier in the global machine tool industry is the high level of working capital that is required to operate the business.
313716_14_ITEM1_P40_S0	We compete in various sectors of the machine tool market within the products of turning, milling, grinding, tooling and accessories.
313716_14_ITEM1_P40_S1	We compete with numerous vendors in each market sector we serve.
313716_14_ITEM1_P40_S2	The primary competitive factors in the marketplace for our machine tools are reliability, price, delivery time, service, and technological characteristics.
313716_14_ITEM1_P40_S3	Our management considers our segment of the industry to be extremely competitive.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S0	There are many manufacturers of machine tools in the world.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S1	They can be categorized by the size of material their products can machine and the precision level their products can achieve.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S2	For our high precision, multi-tasking turning and milling equipment, competition comes primarily from companies such as DMG Mori Seiki, Mazak, and Okuma.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S3	Competition in our more standard turning and milling equipment comes, in part, from those companies as well as Doosan, which is based in South Korea, and Haas which is based in the U.S., as well as many Taiwanese companies.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S4	Our cylindrical grinding machines compete primarily with Studer, a Swiss company as well as Toyoda and Shigiya, which are based in Japan.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S5	Our Hauser jig grinding machines compete primarily with Moore Tool, which is based in the U.S., and some Japanese suppliers.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S6	Our surface grinding machines compete with Okamoto in Japan and Chevalier in Taiwan.
313716_14_ITEM1_P41_S7	Our ATA products compete with many smaller companies.
313716_14_ITEM1_P42_S0	The overall number of our competitors providing product solutions serving our target markets may increase.
313716_14_ITEM1_P42_S1	Also, the overall composition of companies with which we compete may change as we broaden our product offerings and the geographic markets we serve.
313716_14_ITEM1_P42_S2	As we expand into new market areas, we will face competition not only from our existing competitors but from other competitors as well, including existing companies with strong technological, marketing and sales positions in those markets.
313716_14_ITEM1_P42_S3	In addition, several of our competitors may have greater resources, including financial, technical, and engineering resources, than we do.
313716_14_ITEM1_P43_S0	Our machines within the MMS segment are produced around the world.
313716_14_ITEM1_P43_S1	We produce certain of our lathes, knee mills, and related products at our Elmira, New York plant.
313716_14_ITEM1_P43_S2	The Kellenberger grinding machines and related products are manufactured at our St. Gallen, Switzerland plant and Hauser and Tschudin products are produced at our Biel, Switzerland facility.
313716_14_ITEM1_P43_S3	The Jones Shipman grinding machines are manufactured at our Leicester, England plant.
313716_14_ITEM1_P43_S4	The Usach grinding machines are manufactured at our Elgin, Illinois plant.
313716_14_ITEM1_P43_S5	We produce machining centers and lathes at our facilities in Hardinge Taiwan in Nan Tou, Taiwan and Hardinge Precision Machinery (Jiaxing) Company, Ltd. in Jiaxing, China.
313716_14_ITEM1_P43_S6	The Company's Forkardt and Hardinge branded ATA segment products and solutions are engineered and produced in our Traverse City, Michigan, Elmira, NY, Kirchentellinsfurt, Germany, and Noisy le Sec, France plants.
313716_14_ITEM1_P44_S0	We manufacture products from various raw materials, including cast iron, sheet metal, and bar steel.
313716_14_ITEM1_P44_S1	We purchase a number of components, sub-assemblies and assemblies from outside suppliers, including the computer and electronic components for our computer controlled lathes, grinding machines, and machining centers.
313716_14_ITEM1_P44_S2	There are multiple suppliers for virtually all of our raw material, components, sub-assemblies and assemblies and historically, we have not experienced a serious supply interruption.
313716_14_ITEM1_P44_S3	However, in 2011, because of the increase in demand driven by early 2011 worldwide order activity, producers of bearings, ball screws, and linear guides had difficulty meeting the rise in demand.
313716_14_ITEM1_P44_S4	Similar demand increase in the future could impact our production schedules.
313716_14_ITEM1_P45_S0	A major component of our computer controlled machines is the computer and related electronics package.
313716_14_ITEM1_P45_S1	We purchase these components from Fanuc Limited, a Japanese electronics company, Heidenhain, a German control supplier, or from Siemens, another German control manufacturer.
313716_14_ITEM1_P45_S2	While we believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing from several other existing suppliers, and we occasionally do so for special orders, a disruption in the supply of the computer controls from one of our suppliers could cause us to experience a substantial disruption of our operations, depending on the circumstances at the time.
313716_14_ITEM1_P45_S3	We purchase parts from these suppliers under normal trade terms.
313716_14_ITEM1_P45_S4	There are no agreements with these suppliers to purchase minimum volumes per year.
313716_14_ITEM1_P46_S0	Our ongoing research and development program involves creating new products, modifying existing products to meet market demands, and redesigning existing products, both to add new functionality and to reduce the cost of manufacturing.
313716_14_ITEM1_P47_S0	The research and development departments throughout the world are staffed with experienced design engineers with varying levels of education, ranging from technical to doctoral degrees.
313716_14_ITEM1_P48_S0	The worldwide cost of research and development, all of which has been charged to cost of goods sold, amounted to $12.5 million, $12.3 million and $12.7 million, in 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
313716_14_ITEM1_P49_S0	Although we hold several patents with respect to certain of our products, we do not believe that our business is dependent to any material extent upon any single patent or group of patents.
313716_14_ITEM1_P50_S0	Hardinge's business and that of the machine tool industry in general, is cyclical.
313716_14_ITEM1_P50_S1	It is not subject to significant seasonal trends.
313716_14_ITEM1_P50_S2	However, our quarterly results are subject to fluctuation based on the timing of our shipments of machine tools, which are largely dependent upon customer delivery requirements.
313716_14_ITEM1_P51_S0	quarter sales, income from operations, and net income, and result in the first quarter being the lowest quarter of the year.
313716_14_ITEM1_P52_S0	The ability to deliver products within a short period of time is an important competitive criterion.
313716_14_ITEM1_P52_S1	We must have inventory on hand to meet customers' delivery expectations, which for standard machines typically range from immediate to eight weeks delivery.
313716_14_ITEM1_P52_S2	Meeting this requirement is especially difficult with some of our products, where delivery is extended due to time associated with shipping on ocean-going vessels, depending on the location of the customer.
313716_14_ITEM1_P52_S3	This creates a need to have inventory of finished machines available in our major markets to serve our customers in a timely manner.
313716_14_ITEM1_P53_S0	We deliver many of our machine products within one to two months after the order.
313716_14_ITEM1_P53_S1	Some orders, especially multiple machine orders, are delivered on a turnkey basis with the machine or group of machines configured to make certain parts for the customer.
313716_14_ITEM1_P53_S2	This type of order often includes the addition of material handling equipment, tooling and specific programming.
313716_14_ITEM1_P53_S3	In those cases the customer usually observes and inspects the parts being made on the machine at our facility before it is shipped and the timing of the sale is dependent upon the customer's schedule and acceptance.
313716_14_ITEM1_P53_S4	Therefore, sales from quarter-to-quarter can vary depending upon the timing of those customers' acceptances and the significance of those orders.
313716_14_ITEM1_P54_S0	We feel it is important, where practical, to provide readily available accessories and replacement parts for the machines we sell and we carry inventory at levels sufficient to meet these customer requirements.
313716_14_ITEM1_P55_S0	We believe that our current operations and our current uses of property, plant and equipment conform in all material respects to applicable laws and regulations in the multiple countries in which we conduct business.
313716_14_ITEM1_P56_S0	No material portion of our business is subject to government contracts.
313716_14_ITEM1_P57_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_14_ITEM1_P57_S1	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liability for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_14_ITEM1_P58_S0	Hazardous substances and adverse environmental effects have been identified with respect to real property we own and on adjacent parcels of real property.
313716_14_ITEM1_P59_S0	In particular, our Elmira, NY manufacturing facility is located within the Kentucky Avenue Wellfield on the National Priorities List of hazardous waste sites designated for cleanup by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_14_ITEM1_P60_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, NY.
313716_14_ITEM1_P61_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_14_ITEM1_P61_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_14_ITEM1_P61_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_14_ITEM1_P62_S0	information from the EPA concerning the Site.
313716_14_ITEM1_P62_S1	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond, and found no evidence that our operations or property have contributed or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_14_ITEM1_P62_S2	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_14_ITEM1_P63_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_14_ITEM1_P64_S0	The Company, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation and Toshiba America, Inc., the PRPs, have agreed to voluntarily participate in the Remedial Investigation and Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_14_ITEM1_P64_S1	On September 29, 2006, the Director of Emergency and Remedial Response Division of the EPA, Region II, approved and executed the Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_14_ITEM1_P64_S2	The PRPs also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the cost of the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_14_ITEM1_P65_S0	The EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan in May of 2008.
313716_14_ITEM1_P65_S1	On September 7, 2011, the PRPs submitted the draft Remedial Investigation Report to the EPA and on January 10, 2013, the draft Feasibility Study.
313716_14_ITEM1_P65_S2	The PRPs are currently working with the EPA to finalize the Feasibility Study.
313716_14_ITEM1_P66_S0	The draft Feasibility Study identified alternative remedial actions with estimated life-cycle costs ranging from $0.7 million to $3.4 million.
313716_14_ITEM1_P66_S1	We estimate that our portion of the potential costs range from $0.1 million to $0.5 million.
313716_14_ITEM1_P66_S2	Based on the current estimated costs of the various remedial alternatives now under consideration by the EPA, we have recorded a reserve of $0.2 million for the Company's share of remediation expenses at the Pond as of December 31, 2013.
313716_14_ITEM1_P66_S3	This reserve is reported as an accrued expense on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
313716_14_ITEM1_P67_S0	We believe, based upon information currently available that, except as described in the preceding paragraphs, we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation.
313716_14_ITEM1_P67_S1	Though the foregoing reflects the Company's current assessment as it relates to environmental remediation obligations, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to the Company.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The various risks related to the Company's business include the risks described below.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P0_S1	The business, financial condition or results of operations of Hardinge could be materially adversely affected by any of these risks.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The risks and uncertainties described below or elsewhere in this Form 10-K are not the only ones to which we are exposed.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also adversely affect our business and operations.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P1_S2	If any of the matters included in the following risks were to occur, our business, financial condition, results of operations, cash flows or prospects could be materially adversely affected.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our customers' activity levels and spending for our products and services have been impacted by the recent global economic conditions, especially deterioration in the credit markets.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P3_S0	For many of our customers, the purchase of our machines represents a significant capital expenditure.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P3_S1	For others, the purchase of our machines is a part of a larger improvement or expansion of manufacturing capability.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P3_S2	For all, the purchase represents a long term commitment of capital raised by incurrence of debt, issuance of equity or use of cash flow from operations.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Recent global economic and financial difficulties across the world are well documented.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Recently, governments in Europe, Asia and the U.S. intervened in an effort to improve conditions.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P4_S2	These interventions may have reduced the overall impact of the crisis, but also created instability, uncertainty and doubt.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P4_S3	During this period, many of our customers experienced uncertain cash flows and reduced access to credit and equity markets, all of which made commitment to larger long term capital projects difficult.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P4_S4	While global conditions appear to have improved, similar conditions in the future could negatively impact our operating results.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Changes in general economic conditions and the cyclical nature of our business could harm our operating results.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is cyclical in nature, following the strength and weakness of the manufacturing economies in the geographic markets we serve.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P6_S1	As a result of this cyclicality, we have experienced, and in the future we can be expected to experience, significant fluctuations in sales and operating income, which may affect our business, operating results, financial condition and the market price of our common shares.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The following factors, among others, significantly influence demand for our products:
313716_14_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Fluctuations in capacity at both OEMs and job shops; The availability of skilled machinists; The need to replace machines that have reached the end of their useful life; The need to replace older machines with new technology that increases productivity, reduces general manufacturing costs, and machines parts in a new way; The evolution of end-use products requiring machining to more specific tolerances; Our customers' use of new materials requiring machining by different processes; General economic and manufacturing industry expansions and contractions; and Changes in manufacturing capabilities in developing regions.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our competitive position and prospects for growth may be diminished if we are unable to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our ability to anticipate changes in technology, industry standards, customer requirements and product offerings by competitors, and to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market, will be significant factors in our ability to compete and grow.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Moreover, if technologies or standards used in our products become obsolete or fail to gain widespread commercial acceptance, our business would be materially adversely affected.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Developments by our competitors or others may render our products or technologies obsolete or noncompetitive.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P10_S3	Failure to effectively introduce new products or product enhancements on a timely basis could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We rely on a limited number of suppliers to obtain certain components, sub-assemblies, assemblies and products.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Delays in deliveries from or the loss of any of these suppliers may cause us to incur additional costs, result in delays in manufacturing and delivering our products or cause us to carry excess or obsolete inventory.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Some components, sub-assemblies, or assemblies we use in the manufacturing of our products are purchased from a limited number of suppliers.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Our purchases from these suppliers are generally not made pursuant to long-term contracts and are subject to additional risks associated with purchasing products internationally, including risks associated with potential import restrictions and exchange rate fluctuations, as well as changes in tax laws, tariffs, and freight rates.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Although we believe that our relationships with these suppliers are good, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain these products from these suppliers on satisfactory terms indefinitely.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P12_S3	The present economic environment could also pose the risk of one of these key suppliers going out of business, or cause delays in delivery times of critical components as business conditions rebound and demand increases.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing of components, sub-assemblies, assemblies or products from several other suppliers; however, a disruption in the supply from any of our suppliers could cause us to experience a material adverse effect on our operations.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We could incur costs due to conflict mineral regulations, which may materially adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P15_S0	The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted rules regarding disclosure of the use of conflict minerals (commonly referred to as tantalum, tin, tungsten, and gold), which are mined from the Democratic Republic of the Congo and surrounding countries.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P15_S1	This requirement could affect the sourcing of materials used in our products as well as the companies we use to manufacture components, assembles and subassemblies for our products.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P15_S2	In circumstances where conflict minerals in our products are found to be sourced from the Democratic Republic of the Congo or surrounding countries, we may take actions to change materials to reduce the possibility that our purchase of conflict minerals may fund armed groups in the region.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P15_S3	These actions could add costs to the manufacture of our products.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P15_S4	Our reputation may also suffer if we have included conflict minerals originating in the Democratic Republic of the Congo or surrounding countries in our products, and those conflict minerals funded armed groups in the region.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P17_S1	In 2013, approximately 67% of our products were sold in countries outside of North America.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P17_S2	In addition, a majority of our employees are located outside of the United States.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Acquisitions could disrupt our operations and harm our operating results.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P38_S2	In addition, we will rely on the availability of longer-term debt financing or equity financing to make investments in new opportunities.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P40_S0	We are subject to significant foreign exchange and currency risks that could adversely affect our operations and our ability to reinvest earnings from operations.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Our international operations generate sales in a number of foreign currencies including British Pound Sterling ("GBP"), Chinese Renminbi ("CNY"), Euros ("EUR"), New Taiwanese Dollars ("TWD"), and Swiss Francs ("CHF").
313716_14_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Therefore, our results of operations and financial condition are affected by fluctuations in exchange rates between these currencies and the U.S. dollar ("USD").
313716_14_ITEM1A_P41_S2	In addition, our purchases of components in CNY, EUR, TWD, CHF, and Japanese Yen ("JPY") are affected by inter-currency fluctuations in exchange rates.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P42_S0	We prepare our financial statements in U.S. Dollars in accordance with U.S. GAAP, but a sizable portion of our revenue and operating expenses are in foreign currencies.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P42_S1	As a result, we are subject to significant risks, including:
313716_14_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Foreign exchange risks resulting from changes in foreign exchange rates and the implementation of exchange controls; and Limitations on our ability to reinvest earnings from operations in one country to fund the capital needs of our operations in other countries.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Changes in exchange rates will result in increases or decreases in our revenues, costs, and earnings, and may also affect the book value of our assets located outside of the United States and the amount of our invested equity.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Although we may seek to decrease our currency exposure by engaging in hedges against significant transactions and balance sheet currency exposures where we deem it appropriate, we do not hedge against translation risks.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P44_S2	Though we monitor and manage our exposures to changes in currency exchange rates, and utilize currency exchange forward contracts and swaps to mitigate the impact of changes in currency values, changes in exchange rates nonetheless cannot always be predicted or hedged.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P44_S3	Consequently, we cannot assure that any efforts to minimize our risk to currency movements will be successful.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P44_S4	To the extent we sell our products in markets other than the market in which they are manufactured, currency fluctuations may result in our products becoming too expensive for customers in those markets.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Prices of some raw materials, especially steel and iron, fluctuate, which can adversely affect our sales, costs, and profitability.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P46_S0	We manufacture products with a relatively high iron casting or steel content, commodities for which worldwide prices fluctuate.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P46_S1	The availability of and prices for these and other raw materials are subject to volatility due to worldwide supply and demand forces, speculative actions, inventory levels, exchange rates, production costs, and anticipated or perceived shortages.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P46_S2	In some cases, raw material cost increases can be passed on to customers in the form of price increases; in other cases, they cannot.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P46_S3	If raw material prices increase and we are not able to charge our customers higher prices to compensate, it would adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Our quarterly results may fluctuate based on customer delivery requirements.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P48_S0	Our quarterly results are subject to significant fluctuation based on the timing of our shipments of machine tools, which are largely dependent upon customer delivery requirements.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P48_S1	With some individual machines priced in excess of $1.5 million and several machines frequently sold together as a package, a request by a customer to delay shipment at quarter end could significantly affect our quarterly results.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P48_S2	Given that a large percentage of our sales are from Asia, the impact of the plant shut-downs of one to two weeks in that region by us and our customers due to the celebration of the Lunar New Year holiday, our first quarter sales, income from operations, and net income may be the lowest quarter of the year.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Our expenditures for post-retirement pension obligations could be materially higher than we have predicted if our underlying assumptions prove to be incorrect or we are required to use different assumptions.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P50_S0	We provide defined benefit pension plans to eligible employees.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P50_S1	Our pension expense, the funding status of our plans and related charges in other comprehensive income, and required contributions to our pension plans are directly affected by the value of plan assets, the projected rate of return on plan assets, the actual rate of return on plan assets and the actuarial assumptions we use to measure our defined benefit pension plan obligations, including the rate at which future obligations are discounted to a present value, or the discount rate.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P51_S0	The market-related value of assets for our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan recognizes asset losses and gains over a five-year period, which we believe is consistent with the long-term nature of our pension obligations.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P51_S1	As a result, the effect of changes in the market value of assets on our pension expense may be experienced in future years rather than fully reflected in the expense for the year immediately following the year in which the fluctuations actually occurred.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P52_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2013, the value of our pension plan assets for our domestic and foreign plans increased by $16.7 million primarily due to the strong investment performance.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P52_S1	The investment performance of our pension plan assets could significantly impact the growth of those assets.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P52_S2	Should the assets earn a return less than the assumed rate of return over time, it is likely that future pension expenses and funding requirements would increase.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P52_S3	Investment earnings in excess of the assumed rate of return may reduce future pension expenses and funding requirements.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P53_S0	For our domestic and major foreign plans, discount rates are based on the yields on high grade corporate bonds in each market with maturities matching the projected benefit payments.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P53_S1	Discount rates are used to determine the projected and accumulated benefit obligation at the end of each year.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P53_S2	A change in the discount rate would impact the funded status of our plans.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P53_S3	An increase to the discount rate would generally reduce the pension liability and future pension expense and, conversely, a lower discount rate would generally increase the pension liability and the future pension expense.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P54_S0	To develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption, for our domestic and major foreign plans, we consider the current level of expected returns on risk free investments (primarily government bonds) in each market, the historical level of the risk premium associated with the other asset classes in which the portfolio is invested, and the expectations for future returns of each asset class.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P54_S1	The expected return for each asset class is then weighted based on the asset allocation to develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P55_S0	For our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan, which is the largest of our plans, the rate of return assumed on the market-related value of plan assets for determining pension expense was 7.75% for 2013 and for 2012.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P55_S1	The discount rate used for determining the obligation was 5.24% at December 31, 2013 compared to 4.31% at December 31, 2012.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P56_S0	We have two defined benefit plans associated with our Swiss subsidiary.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P56_S1	When viewed in aggregate, these two plans constitute the second largest of our defined benefit plans.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P57_S0	The rate of return assumed on the market-related value of plan assets for determining pension expense was 3.50% for 2013 and 3.70% for 2012.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P57_S1	The discount rate used for determining the obligation was 2.40% at December 31, 2013 compared to 2.00% at December 31, 2012.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P58_S0	During 2012, Congress enacted the Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century Act ("MAP-21").
313716_14_ITEM1A_P58_S1	In the short-term, MAP-21 will increase the discount rates used to determine the funding liabilities for our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan, resulting in significantly lower pension contributions.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P58_S2	As a result of MAP-21 and based on assumptions pertaining to asset returns and corporate bond yields, we do not expect to make cash contributions of to our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan in 2014.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P58_S3	We do expect to make a contribution of approximately $0.2 million to our U.S. supplemental pension plan in 2014.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P58_S4	We also expect to make contributions of approximately $2.6 million to the foreign plans in 2014.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P58_S5	If our current assumptions and estimates are not correct, contributions in years beyond 2013 may be more or less than the projected 2014 contributions.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P59_S0	In addition, we cannot predict whether changing market or economic conditions, regulatory changes or other factors will increase our pension expenses or our funding obligations, diverting funds we would otherwise apply to other uses.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P60_S0	At December 31, 2013, the excess of consolidated projected benefit obligations over plan assets was $26.9 million, when only taking into consideration plans whose projected benefit obligation exceeded the fair value of plan assets, and the excess of consolidated accumulated benefit obligations over plan assets was $26.5 million, when only taking into consideration plans whose accumulated benefit obligation exceeded the fair value of plan assets.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P61_S0	Our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan is currently underfunded and we will be required to make cash payments to the plan, reducing the cash available for our business.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P62_S0	We record a liability associated with our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan equal to the excess of the projected benefit obligation over the fair value of plan assets.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P62_S1	The liability recorded at December 31, 2013 was $18.9 million.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P63_S0	As a result of the enactment of MAP-21, we do not expect to contribute to our domestic qualified defined benefit pension plan in 2014.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Contribution levels are largely contingent on asset returns and corporate bond yields.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P64_S1	If the performance of the assets in our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan does not meet our expectations and/or corporate bond yields decrease, our future contributions to the plan could increase.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P65_S0	Our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan is subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, or ERISA.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P65_S1	Under ERISA, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, or PBGC, has the authority to terminate an underfunded pension plan under limited circumstances.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P66_S0	If we are unable to attract and retain skilled employees to work at our manufacturing facilities our operations and growth prospects would be adversely impacted.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P67_S0	We conduct substantially all of our manufacturing operations in less densely populated urban areas, which, in many cases, may represent a relatively small market for skilled labor force.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P67_S1	Our continued success depends on our ability to attract and retain a skilled labor force at these locations.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P67_S2	If we are not able to attract and retain the personnel we require, we may be unable to develop, manufacture, and market our products, or to expand our operations in a manner that best exploits market opportunities and capitalizes on our investment in our business.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P67_S3	This would materially adversely affect our business, operating results and financial condition.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P68_S0	Due to future technological changes, changes in market demand, or changes in market expectations, portions of our inventory may become obsolete or excessive.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P69_S0	The technologies within our products change and generally new versions of machines are brought to market in three to five year cycles.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P69_S1	The phasing out of an old product involves both estimating the amount of inventory to hold to satisfy the final demand for those machines as well as to satisfy future repair part needs.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P69_S2	Based on changing customer demand and expectations of delivery times for repair parts, we may find that we have either obsolete or excess inventory on hand.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P69_S3	Because of unforeseen changes in technology, market demand, or competition, we may have to write off unusable inventory at some time in the future, which may adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P70_S0	Major changes in the economic situation of our customer base could require us to write off significant portion of our receivables from customers.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P71_S0	In difficult economic periods, our customers lose work and find it difficult if not impossible to pay for products purchased from us.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P71_S1	Although appropriate credit reviews are done at the time of sale, rapidly changing economic conditions can have sudden impacts on customers' ability to pay.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P71_S2	We run the risk of bad debt on existing time payment contracts and open accounts.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P71_S3	If we write off significant parts of our customer accounts or notes receivable because of unforeseen changes in their business condition, it would adversely affect our results of operations, financial condition, and cash flows.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P72_S0	If we suffer damage to our factories, facilities or distribution system due to catastrophe, our operations could be seriously harmed.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P73_S0	Our factories, facilities, and distribution system are subject to the risk of catastrophic loss due to fire, flood, terrorism, or other natural or man-made disasters.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P73_S1	In particular, several of our facilities could be subject to a catastrophic loss caused by earthquake due to their locations.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P76_S0	We rely in part on independent distributors and the loss of these distributors could adversely affect our business.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P77_S1	We support an extensive distributor and agent network worldwide.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P78_S0	Rather than serving as passive conduits for delivery of product, many of our distributors are active participants in the sale and support of our products.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P78_S1	Many of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our customers.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P78_S2	In addition, the distribution agreements we have are typically cancelable by the distributor after a relatively short notice period.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P78_S3	The loss of a substantial number of our distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our customers could reduce our sales and profits.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P79_S0	We rely on estimated forecasts of our customers' needs and inaccuracies in such forecasts could adversely affect our business.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P80_S0	We generally sell our products pursuant to individual purchase orders instead of long-term purchase commitments.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P80_S1	Therefore, we rely on estimated demand forecasts, based upon input from our customers and the general economic environment, to determine how much material to purchase and product to manufacture.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P81_S0	Because our sales are based on purchase orders, our customers may cancel, delay, or otherwise modify their purchase commitments with little or no consequence to them and with little or no notice to us.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P81_S1	For these reasons, we generally have limited visibility regarding our customers' actual product needs.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P81_S2	The quantities or timing required by our customers for our products could vary significantly.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P81_S3	Whether in response to changes affecting the industry or a customer's specific business pressures, any cancellation, delay, or other modification in our customers' orders could significantly reduce our revenue, cause our operating results to fluctuate from period to period and make it more difficult for us to predict our revenue.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P81_S4	In the event of a cancellation or reduction of a customer order, we may not have enough time to reduce inventory purchases or our workforce to minimize the effect of the lost revenue on our business.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P81_S5	Order cancellations typically average approximately 2% of sales.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P82_S0	Cancellations could vary significantly during times of global economic uncertainty.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P83_S0	We could face potential product liability claims relating to products we manufacture, which could result in us having to expend significant time and expense to defend these claims and to pay material amounts in damages or settlement.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P84_S1	We currently maintain product liability insurance coverage; however, such insurance does not cover all types of damages that could be assessed against us in a product liability claim and the coverage amounts are subject to certain limitations under the applicable policies.

313716_14_ITEM1A_P89_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P89_S1	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liability for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P90_S0	Hazardous substances and adverse environmental effects have been identified with respect to real property we own and on adjacent parcels of real property.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P91_S0	In particular, our Elmira, NY manufacturing facility is located within the Kentucky Avenue Wellfield on the National Priorities List of hazardous waste sites designated for cleanup by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P92_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, NY.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P93_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P93_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P93_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P94_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice in February 2006, the Company had never been named as a potentially responsible party ("PRP") at the Site nor had the Company received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the Site.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P94_S1	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond, and found no evidence that our operations or property have contributed or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P94_S2	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P95_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P96_S0	The Company, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation and Toshiba America, Inc., the PRPs, have agreed to voluntarily participate in the Remedial Investigation and Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P97_S0	Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P97_S1	The PRPs also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the cost of the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P98_S0	The EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan in May of 2008.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P98_S1	On September 7, 2011, the PRPs submitted the draft Remedial Investigation Report to the EPA and on January 10, 2013, the draft Feasibility Study.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P98_S2	The PRPs are currently working with the EPA to finalize the Feasibility Study.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P99_S0	The draft Feasibility Study identified alternative remedial actions with estimated life-cycle costs ranging from $0.7 million to $3.4 million.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P99_S1	We estimate that our portion of the potential costs range from $0.1 million to $0.5 million.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P99_S2	Based on the current estimated costs of the various remedial alternatives now under consideration by the EPA, we have recorded a reserve of $0.2 million for the Company's share of remediation expenses at the Pond as of December 31, 2013.
313716_14_ITEM1A_P99_S3	This reserve is reported as an accrued expense on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

313716_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metalcutting turning machines, grinding machines, vertical machining centers, and repair parts related to those machines.
313716_14_ITEM7_P0_S1	The Company also engineers and supplies high precision, standard and specialty workholding devices, and other machine tool accessories.
313716_14_ITEM7_P0_S2	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_14_ITEM7_P0_S3	We are geographically diversified with manufacturing facilities in China, France, Germany, Switzerland, Taiwan, the United Kingdom ("U.K.") and the United States ("U.S.") with sales to most industrialized countries.
313716_14_ITEM7_P0_S4	Approximately 67% of our 2013 sales were to customers outside of North America, 68% of our 2013 products sold were manufactured outside of North America, and 66% of our employees were outside of North America.
313716_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our machine products are considered to be capital goods and are part of what has historically been a highly cyclical industry.
313716_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our management believes that a key performance indicator is our order level as compared to industry measures of market activity levels.
313716_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	General economic growth around the world in 2013 was slower than 2012, driven by the decelerating economy in China and uncertainties surrounding European financial and fiscal conditions.
313716_14_ITEM7_P2_S1	The concerns over economic situations negatively impacted our customers' decision for capital spending.
313716_14_ITEM7_P2_S2	Consequently, 2013 order volumes decreased approximately $25 million from our organic business, offset by orders from the Company's newly acquired businesses.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	Metrics on machine tool market activity watched by our management include world machine tool consumption (a proxy for shipments), as reported annually by Gardner Business Media in the World Machine-Tool Output and Consumption Survey and metalcutting machine orders as reported by the Association of Manufacturing Technology ("AMT"), the primary industry group for U.S. machine tool manufacturers.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	World machine tool consumption data as reported by the World Machine-Tool Output and Consumption Survey showed a decrease in machine tool consumption of 9% in 2013 compared to a decrease of 2.5% in 2012.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	This report indicates that 2013 consumption in China, the world's largest market, decreased by 12% (in US dollars) after a 1% decrease in 2012.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S3	Consumption in Germany, the world's third largest market, saw a 6% increase in consumption as measured in local currency in 2013 compared to no change in 2012.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S4	In the United Kingdom, machine tool consumption measured in local currency decreased by 9% in 2013 and increased by 11% in 2012.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S5	In the U.S., 2013 machine tool consumption decreased by 9%, as compared to a 19% increase in 2012.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S6	In 2013, U.S. orders for metalcutting machine tools reported by the AMT were $4.9 billion, down when compared to $5.7 billion reported in 2012.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S7	The AMT's statistics are reported on a voluntary basis from member companies.
313716_14_ITEM7_P3_S8	The report includes metalcutting machines of all types and sizes, including segments in which we do not compete.
313716_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	Other closely followed U.S. market indicators are tracked to determine activity levels in U.S. manufacturing plants that are prospective customers for our products.

313716_14_ITEM7_P81_S0	equivalent) at December 31, 2013 and CNY 21.0 million ($3.4 million equivalent) at December 31, 2012.

313716_14_ITEM7_P85_S0	In October 2013, we amended the terms of Term Loan.
313716_14_ITEM7_P85_S1	The amendment reduced mandatory principal payments associated with the sale of our common stock under the Company's stock offering program as described in Footnote 14 from 75% of net proceeds to 25% of net proceeds.
313716_14_ITEM7_P85_S2	This amendment was retroactive for all sales of common stock under this stock offering program.
313716_14_ITEM7_P85_S3	In 2013, the Company made principal payments of $1.5 million with stock offering proceeds.

313716_14_ITEM7_P112_S0	The following information has been provided in accordance with the Securities and Exchange Commission's requirements for disclosure of exposures to market risk arising from certain market risk sensitive instruments.
313716_14_ITEM7_P113_S0	Our earnings are affected by changes in short-term interest rates as a result of our floating interest rate debt.
313716_14_ITEM7_P113_S1	If market interest rates on debt subject to floating interest rates were to have increased by 2% over the actual rates paid in that year, interest expense would have increased by $0.6 million in 2013 and $0.5 million in 2012.
313716_14_ITEM7_P113_S2	These amounts are determined by considering the impact of hypothetical interest rates on the Company's outstanding borrowings.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S0	Our operations include manufacturing and sales activities in foreign jurisdictions.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S1	We currently manufacture our products in China, France, Germany, Switzerland, Taiwan, the United Kingdom, and the United States using production components purchased internationally, and we sell our products in those markets as well as other worldwide markets.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S2	Our subsidiaries in China, France, Germany, Switzerland, Taiwan, and the United Kingdom sell products in local currency to customers in those countries.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S3	These subsidiaries also transact business in currencies other than their functional currency outside of their home country.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S4	As a result of these sales in various currencies and in various countries of the world, our financial results could be significantly affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in the foreign markets in which we distribute our products.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S5	Our operating results are exposed to changes in exchange rates between the USD, GBP, CHF, EUR, TWD, CNY and JPY.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S6	As a result of having sales, purchases and certain intercompany transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currencies of our subsidiaries, we are exposed to the effect of currency exchange rate changes on our cash flows, earnings and balance sheet.
313716_14_ITEM7_P114_S7	To mitigate this currency risk, we enter into currency forward exchange contracts to hedge significant non-functional currency denominated transactions for periods consistent with the terms of the underlying transactions.
313716_14_ITEM7_P115_S0	Contracts generally have maturities that do not exceed one year.
313716_14_ITEM7_P116_S0	The preparation of our financial statements requires the application of a number of accounting policies which are described in the notes to the financial statements.
313716_14_ITEM7_P116_S1	These policies require the use of assumptions or estimates, which, if interpreted differently under different conditions or circumstances, could result in material changes to the reported results.
313716_14_ITEM7_P116_S2	Following is a discussion of those accounting policies, which were reviewed with our audit committee, and which we feel are most susceptible to such interpretation.
313716_14_ITEM7_P117_S0	We assess the collectability of our trade accounts receivable using a combination of methods.
313716_14_ITEM7_P117_S1	We review large individual accounts for evidence of circumstances that suggest a collection problem might exist.
313716_14_ITEM7_P117_S2	Such situations include, but are not limited to, the customer's past history of payments, its current financial condition as evidenced by credit ratings, financial statements or other sources, and recent collection activities.
313716_14_ITEM7_P118_S0	We provide a reserve for losses based on current payment trends in the economies where we hold concentrations of receivables and provide a reserve for what we believe to be the most likely risk of collectability.
313716_14_ITEM7_P118_S1	In order to make these allowances, we rely on assumptions regarding economic conditions, equipment resale values, and the likelihood that previous performance will be indicative of future results.
313716_14_ITEM7_P119_S0	We use a number of assumptions and estimates in determining the value of our inventory.
313716_14_ITEM7_P120_S0	deemed to be excessive based on an annual review of past usage and anticipated future usage.
313716_14_ITEM7_P120_S1	While we feel this is the most appropriate methodology for determining excess quantities, the possibility exists that customers will change their buying habits in the future should their own requirements change.
313716_14_ITEM7_P121_S0	Changes in metalcutting technology can render certain products obsolete or reduce their market value.
313716_14_ITEM7_P121_S1	We continually evaluate changes in technology and adjust our products and inventory carrying values accordingly, either by write-off or by price reductions.
313716_14_ITEM7_P121_S2	Changes in market conditions and realizable selling prices for our machines could reduce the value of our inventory.
313716_14_ITEM7_P121_S3	We continually evaluate the carrying value of our machine inventory against the estimated selling price, less related costs to sell and adjust our inventory carrying values accordingly.
313716_14_ITEM7_P121_S4	However, the possibility exists that a future technological development, currently unanticipated, might affect the marketability of specific products produced by the Company.
313716_14_ITEM7_P122_S0	We include in the cost of our inventories a component to cover the estimated cost of manufacturing overhead activities associated with production of our products.
313716_14_ITEM7_P123_S0	We believe that being able to offer immediate delivery on many of our products is critical to our competitive success.
313716_14_ITEM7_P123_S1	Likewise, we believe that maintaining an inventory of service parts, with a particular emphasis on purchased parts, is especially important to support our policy of maintaining serviceability of our products.
313716_14_ITEM7_P123_S2	Consequently, we maintain significant inventories of repair parts on many of our machine models, some of which are no longer in production.
313716_14_ITEM7_P123_S3	Our ability to accurately determine which parts are needed to maintain this serviceability is critical to our success in managing this element of our business.
313716_14_ITEM7_P124_S0	We have acquired other machine tool companies and, in certain instances, the assets of machine tool companies.
313716_14_ITEM7_P124_S1	When doing so, we have estimated the fair value of the assets acquired, and have used traditional models for establishing purchase price based on EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) multiples and present value of future cash flows.
313716_14_ITEM7_P124_S2	Consequently, the value of goodwill and purchased intangible assets on our balance sheet has been affected by the use of numerous estimates of the value of assets purchased and of future business opportunity.
313716_14_ITEM7_P125_S0	We review goodwill and indefinite lived intangible assets for impairment at least annually or when indictors of impairment are present.
313716_14_ITEM7_P126_S0	We regularly review the recent results and projected future results of our operations, as well as other relevant factors, to reconfirm the likelihood that existing deferred tax assets in each tax jurisdiction would be fully recoverable.
313716_14_ITEM7_P127_S0	We sponsor various defined benefit pension plans, defined contribution plans, and one postretirement benefit plan, all as described in Footnote 10 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
313716_14_ITEM7_P128_S0	The calculation of our plan expenses and liabilities require the use of a number of critical accounting estimates.
313716_14_ITEM7_P128_S1	Changes in the assumptions can result in different plan expense and liability amounts, and actual experience can differ from the assumptions.
313716_14_ITEM7_P128_S2	We believe that the most critical assumptions are the discount rate and the expected rate of return on plan assets.
313716_14_ITEM7_P129_S0	We annually review the discount rate to be used for retirement plan liabilities.
313716_14_ITEM7_P130_S0	In the U.S., we use bond pricing models based on high grade U.S. corporate bonds constructed to match the projected liability benefit payments.
313716_14_ITEM7_P130_S1	We discounted our future plan liabilities for our U.S. plan using a rate of 5.24% and 4.31% at our plan measurement date of December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
313716_14_ITEM7_P130_S2	We discounted our future plan liabilities for our foreign plans using rates appropriate for each country, which resulted in a blended rate of 2.75% and 2.34% at their measurement dates of December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
313716_14_ITEM7_P131_S0	A change in the discount rate can have a significant effect on retirement plan obligations.
313716_14_ITEM7_P131_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension obligations by approximately $13.2 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P131_S2	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension obligations by approximately $11.0 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P132_S0	increase the Swiss pension obligations by approximately $14.3 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P132_S1	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease the Swiss pension obligations by approximately $12.3 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P133_S0	A change in the discount rate can also have an effect on retirement plan expense.
313716_14_ITEM7_P133_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension expense by less than $0.1 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P133_S2	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.1 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P133_S3	A decrease of one percent would increase the Swiss pension expense by approximately $1.2 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P133_S4	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease the Swiss pension expense by approximately $0.7 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P134_S0	The expected rate of return on plan assets varies based on the investment mix of each particular plan and reflects the long-term average rate of return expected on funds invested or to be invested in each pension plan to provide for the benefits included in the pension liability.
313716_14_ITEM7_P134_S1	We review our expected rate of return annually based upon information available to us at that time, including the current level of expected returns on risk free investments (primarily government bonds in each market), the historical level of the risk premium associated with the other asset classes in which the portfolio is invested, and the expectations for future returns of each asset class.
313716_14_ITEM7_P134_S2	The expected return for each asset class was then weighted based on the asset allocation to develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption.
313716_14_ITEM7_P134_S3	For our domestic plans, the expected rate of return during fiscal 2014 is 7.50%, lower by 0.25% from the 7.75% rate used for fiscal 2013.
313716_14_ITEM7_P134_S4	For our foreign plans, we used rates of return appropriate for each country which resulted in a blended expected rate of return of 3.91% for both fiscal 2014 and for fiscal 2013.
313716_14_ITEM7_P135_S0	A change in the expected return on plan assets can also have a significant effect on retirement plan expense.
313716_14_ITEM7_P135_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.8 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P135_S2	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.8 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P135_S3	A decrease of one percent would increase the Swiss pension expense by approximately $0.9 million.
313716_14_ITEM7_P135_S4	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease the Swiss pension expense by approximately $0.9 million.

313716_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	Hardinge Inc. ("Hardinge", "we", "us" or "the Company") is a machine tool manufacturer, which designs and manufactures computer-numerically controlled cutting lathes, machining centers, grinding machines, collets, chucks, index fixtures and other industrial products.
313716_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	We sell our products to customers in North America, Europe and Asia.
313716_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	A substantial portion of our sales are to small and medium-sized independent job shops, which in turn sell machined parts to their industrial customers.
313716_14_ITEM8_P10_S3	Industries directly and indirectly served by the Company include: aerospace, automotive, communications, computer, construction equipment, defense, energy, farm equipment, medical equipment, recreational equipment and transportation.
313716_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
313716_14_ITEM8_P11_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions are eliminated in consolidation.

313716_14_ITEM8_P13_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
