313716_15_ITEM1_P3_S0	We are a global designer, manufacturer and distributor of machine tools, specializing in precision computer numerically controlled metalcutting machines and workholding technology solutions.
313716_15_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Company has the following direct and indirect wholly owned subsidiaries: North America:
313716_15_ITEM1_P4_S0	Traverse City, Michigan Hardinge Technology Systems, Inc.
313716_15_ITEM1_P5_S0	Elmira, New York Usach Technologies Inc.
313716_15_ITEM1_P6_S0	St. Gallen, Switzerland Hardinge Holdings B.V.
313716_15_ITEM1_P7_S0	Amsterdam, Netherlands Hardinge Machine Tools B.V.
313716_15_ITEM1_P8_S0	St. Gallen, Switzerland Asia and Other:
313716_15_ITEM1_P9_S0	Hong Kong, People's Republic of China Hardinge Machine (Shanghai) Co., Ltd.
313716_15_ITEM1_P10_S0	We have manufacturing facilities located in China, Switzerland, Taiwan, Germany, France, India, the United Kingdom ("U.K.") and the United States ("U.S.").
313716_15_ITEM1_P11_S0	We manufacture the majority of the products we sell.
313716_15_ITEM1_P12_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metalcutting turning machines, grinding machines, machining centers, and repair parts related to those machines.
313716_15_ITEM1_P12_S1	The Company also engineers and supplies high precision, standard and specialty workholding devices, and other machine tool accessories.
313716_15_ITEM1_P12_S2	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_15_ITEM1_P13_S0	The Company has two unique business segments: Metalcutting Machine Solutions ("MMS") and Aftermarket Tooling and Accessories ("ATA").
313716_15_ITEM1_P14_S0	This segment includes operations related to grinding, turning, and milling, as discussed below, and related repair parts.
313716_15_ITEM1_P14_S1	The products are considered to be capital goods with sales prices ranging from approximately forty thousand dollars for some high volume products to around two million dollars for some lower volume grinding machines or other specialty built turnkey systems of multiple machines.
313716_15_ITEM1_P14_S2	Sales are subject to economic cycles and, because they are most often purchased to add manufacturing capacity, the cycles can be severe with customers delaying purchases during down cycles and then aggressively requiring machine deliveries during up cycles.
313716_15_ITEM1_P14_S3	Machines are purchased to a lesser extent during down cycles as our customers are looking for productivity improvements or they have new products that require new machining capabilities.
313716_15_ITEM1_P15_S0	We have been a manufacturer of industrial-use high precision and general precision turning machine tools since 1890.
313716_15_ITEM1_P16_S0	Turning machines, or lathes, are power-driven machines used to remove material from either bar stock or a rough-formed part by moving multiple cutting tools against the surface of a part rotating at very high speeds in a spindle mechanism.
313716_15_ITEM1_P16_S1	The multi-directional movement of the cutting tools allows the part to be shaped to the desired dimensions.
313716_15_ITEM1_P16_S2	On parts produced by our machines, those dimensions are often measured in millionths of an inch.
313716_15_ITEM1_P16_S3	We consider Hardinge to be a leader in the field of producing machines capable of consistently and cost-effectively producing parts to very close dimensions.
313716_15_ITEM1_P17_S0	Grinding is a machining process in which a part's surface is shaped to closer tolerances with a rotating abrasive wheel or tool when compared with other available metalcutting technologies.
313716_15_ITEM1_P17_S1	Grinding machines can be used to finish parts of various shapes and sizes.
313716_15_ITEM1_P17_S2	The grinding machines of our Kellenberger subsidiary are used to grind the inside and outside diameters of cylindrical parts.
313716_15_ITEM1_P17_S3	Such grinding machines are typically used to provide a more exact finish on a part that has been partially completed on a lathe.
313716_15_ITEM1_P17_S4	The Kellenberger grinding machines are generally purchased by the same type of customers as other Hardinge equipment and further our ability to be a primary source for our customers.
313716_15_ITEM1_P18_S0	Our Kellenberger precision grinding technology is complemented by our Hauser, Tschudin, Jones Shipman, Usach, and Voumard grinding brands.
313716_15_ITEM1_P19_S0	Hauser machines are jig grinders used to make demanding contour components, primarily for tool and mold-making applications.
313716_15_ITEM1_P19_S1	Tschudin product technology is focused on the specialized grinding of cylindrical parts when the customer requires high volume production.
313716_15_ITEM1_P19_S2	Our Tschudin machines are generally equipped with automatic loading and unloading mechanisms for the part being machined.
313716_15_ITEM1_P19_S3	These loading and unloading mechanisms significantly reduce the level of involvement a machine operator has to perform in the production process.
313716_15_ITEM1_P20_S0	Our Jones Shipman brand represents a line of high-quality grinding (surface, creep feed, and cylindrical) machines.
313716_15_ITEM1_P20_S1	These super-abrasive machines and machining systems are used by a diverse range of industries.
313716_15_ITEM1_P20_S2	Usach and Voumard machines are high quality internal diameter cylindrical grinding systems used in production and job shop environments.
313716_15_ITEM1_P21_S0	Machining centers are designed to remove material from stationary, prismatic or box-like parts of various shapes with rotating tools that are capable of milling, drilling, tapping, reaming and routing.
313716_15_ITEM1_P21_S1	Machining centers have mechanisms that automatically change tools based on commands from a built-in computer control without the assistance of an operator.
313716_15_ITEM1_P21_S2	Machining centers are generally purchased by the same customers who purchase other Hardinge equipment.
313716_15_ITEM1_P21_S3	We supply a broad line of machining centers under our Bridgeport brand name addressing a range of sizes, speeds, and powers.
313716_15_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our machines are generally computer controlled and use commands from an integrated computer to control the movement of cutting tools, grinding wheels, part positioning, and in the case of turning and grinding machines, the rotation speeds of the part being shaped.
313716_15_ITEM1_P22_S1	The computer control enables the operator to program operations such as part rotation, tooling selection, and tooling movement for a specific part and then stores that program in memory for future use.
313716_15_ITEM1_P22_S2	The machines are able to produce parts while left unattended when connected to automatic bar-feeding, robotics equipment, or other material handling devices designed to supply raw materials and remove machined parts from the machine.
313716_15_ITEM1_P23_S0	New products are critical to our growth plans.
313716_15_ITEM1_P23_S1	We gain access to new products through internal product development, acquisitions, joint ventures, license agreements, and partnerships.
313716_15_ITEM1_P23_S2	Products are introduced each year to both broaden our product offering, to take advantage of new technologies available to us, and to replace older models nearing the end of their respective product life cycles.
313716_15_ITEM1_P23_S3	These technologies generally allow our machines to run at higher speeds and with more power, thus increasing their efficiency.
313716_15_ITEM1_P23_S4	Customers routinely replace old machines with newer machines that can produce parts faster and with less time to set up the machine when converting from one type of part to another.
313716_15_ITEM1_P23_S5	Generally, our machines can be used to produce parts from all of the standard ferrous and non-ferrous metals, as well as plastics, composites, and exotic materials.
313716_15_ITEM1_P24_S0	We focus on products and solutions for companies making parts from hard-to-machine materials with hard to sustain close tolerances and hard to achieve surface finishes that may be hard to hold in the machine.
313716_15_ITEM1_P24_S1	We believe that with our high precision and super precision lathes, our grinding machines, and our rugged machining centers, combined with our accessory products and our technical expertise, we are uniquely qualified to be the supplier of choice for customers manufacturing to demanding specifications.
313716_15_ITEM1_P25_S0	Multiple options are available on many of our machines, which allows customers to customize their machines to their specific operating performance and cost objectives.
313716_15_ITEM1_P25_S1	We produce machines for stock with popular option combinations for immediate delivery, as well as design and produce machines to specific customer requirements.
313716_15_ITEM1_P25_S2	In addition to our machines, we provide the necessary tooling, accessories, and support services to assist customers in maximizing their return on investment.
313716_15_ITEM1_P26_S0	The sale of repair parts is important to our business.
313716_15_ITEM1_P27_S0	Certain parts on machines wear out, fail, or need to be replaced due to misuse over time.
313716_15_ITEM1_P27_S1	Customers will buy parts from us throughout the life of the machine, which typically extends over many years.
313716_15_ITEM1_P27_S2	There are thousands of machines in operation in the world for which we provide those repair parts and in many cases the parts are available exclusively from us.
313716_15_ITEM1_P28_S0	We offer various warranties on our equipment and consider post-sale support to be a critical element of our business.
313716_15_ITEM1_P28_S1	Warranties on machines typically extend for twelve months after purchase.
313716_15_ITEM1_P28_S2	Services provided include operation and maintenance training, in-field maintenance, and in-field repair.
313716_15_ITEM1_P28_S3	We offer these post sales support services on a paid basis throughout the life of the machine.
313716_15_ITEM1_P28_S4	In territories covered by distributors, this support and service is offered through the distributor.
313716_15_ITEM1_P29_S0	This segment includes products that are purchased by manufacturers throughout the lives of their machines.
313716_15_ITEM1_P29_S1	The selling prices of these units are relatively low per piece with prices ranging from fifty dollars on high volume collets to twenty thousand dollars or more for specialty chucks.
313716_15_ITEM1_P29_S2	While considered to be consumable, these products are more durable in nature, with replacement due to wear over time.
313716_15_ITEM1_P30_S0	Our products are used on all types and brands of machine tools, not limited to our own.
313716_15_ITEM1_P31_S0	Sales levels are affected by manufacturing cycles, but not to the severity of the capital goods lines.
313716_15_ITEM1_P31_S1	While customers may not purchase large dollar machines during a down cycle, their factories are operating with their existing equipment and therefore accessories are still needed as they wear out or they are needed for a change in production requirements.
313716_15_ITEM1_P32_S0	The two primary product groups in ATA are collets and chucks.
313716_15_ITEM1_P33_S0	Collets are cone-shaped metal sleeves used for holding circular or rod like pieces in a lathe or other machine that provide effective part holding and accurate part location during machining operations.
313716_15_ITEM1_P34_S0	Chucks are a specialized clamping device used to hold an object with radial symmetry, especially a cylindrical object.
313716_15_ITEM1_P34_S1	It is most commonly used to hold a rotating tool or a rotating work piece.
313716_15_ITEM1_P34_S2	Some of our specialty chucks can also hold irregularly shaped objects that lack radial symmetry.
313716_15_ITEM1_P35_S0	While our products are known for accuracy and durability, they are consumable in nature.
313716_15_ITEM1_P36_S0	In May of 2013, the Company acquired Forkardt, a global provider of specialty chucks.
313716_15_ITEM1_P36_S1	Forkardt is based in Traverse City, Michigan with operations in the United States, Europe, and Asia that provide unique solutions for demanding workholding applications.
313716_15_ITEM1_P36_S2	This acquisition positions Hardinge as one of the largest manufacturers of rotating workholding solutions in the world.
313716_15_ITEM1_P36_S3	In December of 2013, we divested the Forkardt Swiss operations due to potential customer conflicts.
313716_15_ITEM1_P37_S0	We offer an extensive line of workholding and toolholding solutions that are available in tens of thousands of shapes and sizes to meet unique customer application needs.
313716_15_ITEM1_P37_S1	These solutions can be used on virtually all types and brands of metalcutting machines, as well as non-traditional uses in many industrial applications.
313716_15_ITEM1_P37_S2	The Company continues to explore opportunities to expand this business organically and through acquisitions.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S0	We sell our products in most of the industrialized countries of the world through a combination of distributors, agents, and manufacturers' representatives.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S1	In certain areas of China, France, Germany, North America, and the United Kingdom, we have also used a direct sales force for portions of our product lines.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S2	Generally, our distributors have an exclusive right to sell our products in a defined geographic area.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S3	Our distributors operate as independent businesses and purchase products from us at discounted prices for their customers, while agents and representatives sell products on our behalf and receive commissions on sales.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S4	Our discount schedule is adjusted to reflect the level of pre and post sales support offered by our distributors.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S5	Our direct sales personnel earn a fixed salary plus commission.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S6	Sales through distributors are made only on standard commercial open account terms or through letters of credit.
313716_15_ITEM1_P38_S7	Distributors generally take title to products upon shipment from our facilities and do not have any special return privileges.
313716_15_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our standard ATA products are sold through direct telephone orders and via our web site at www.shophardinge.com.
313716_15_ITEM1_P39_S1	Custom or special solutions are sold through direct sales and agents.
313716_15_ITEM1_P39_S2	In most cases, we are able to package and ship in-stock tooling, accessories, and repair parts within 24 hours of receiving orders.
313716_15_ITEM1_P39_S3	We can package and ship items with heavy demand within a few hours.
313716_15_ITEM1_P39_S4	In other parts of the world, these products are sold on either a direct sales basis or through distributor arrangements.
313716_15_ITEM1_P40_S0	We promote recognition of our products in the marketplace through advertising in trade publications, web presences, email newsletters, and participation in industry trade shows.
313716_15_ITEM1_P40_S1	In addition, we market our non-machine products and capabilities through publication of general catalogs and other targeted catalogs, which we distribute to existing and prospective customers.
313716_15_ITEM1_P40_S2	We have a considerable presence on the internet at www.hardinge.com and www.forkardt.com, where customers can obtain information about our products and place orders for accessories, tooling, knee mill products and repair parts.
313716_15_ITEM1_P41_S0	A substantial portion of our end use customers are small and medium-sized independent job shops, which in turn sell machined parts to their industrial customers.
313716_15_ITEM1_P41_S1	Industries directly and indirectly served by us include aerospace, automotive, computer, communications, consumer-electronics, construction equipment, defense, energy, farm equipment, medical equipment, recreational equipment, and transportation.
313716_15_ITEM1_P42_S0	No single customer or related group of customers accounted for more than 6% of our consolidated sales in 2014 or 2013 .
313716_15_ITEM1_P42_S1	While valuing our relationship with each customer, we do not believe that the loss of any single customer, or any few customers, would have an adverse material effect on our business.
313716_15_ITEM1_P43_S0	In our industry, the barriers to entry for competition vary based on the level of product performance required.
313716_15_ITEM1_P43_S1	For the products with the highest performance in terms of accuracy and productivity, the barriers are generally technical in nature.
313716_15_ITEM1_P43_S2	For basic products, often the barriers are not technical; they are tied to product availability, competitive price position, and an effective distribution model that offers the pre and post sales support required by customers.
313716_15_ITEM1_P44_S0	Another significant barrier in the global machine tool industry is the high level of working capital that is required to operate the business.
313716_15_ITEM1_P45_S0	We compete in various sectors of the machine tool market within the products of turning, milling, grinding, tooling and accessories.
313716_15_ITEM1_P45_S1	We compete with numerous vendors in each market sector we serve.
313716_15_ITEM1_P45_S2	The primary competitive factors in the marketplace for our machine tools are reliability, price, delivery time, service, and technological characteristics.
313716_15_ITEM1_P45_S3	Our management considers our segment of the industry to be extremely competitive.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S0	There are many manufacturers of machine tools in the world.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S1	They can be categorized by the size of material their products can machine and the precision level their products can achieve.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S2	For our high precision, multi-tasking turning and milling equipment, competition comes primarily from companies such as DMG Mori Seiki, Mazak, and Okuma.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S3	Competition in our more standard turning and milling equipment comes, in part, from those companies as well as Doosan, which is based in South Korea, and Haas which is based in the U.S., as well as many Taiwanese companies.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S4	Our internal and outer diameter (ID/OD) cylindrical grinding machines compete primarily with Studer, a Swiss company as well as Toyoda and Shigiya, which are based in Japan.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S5	Our Hauser jig grinding machines compete primarily with Moore Tool, which is based in the U.S., and some Japanese suppliers.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S6	Our surface grinding machines compete with Okamoto in Japan and Chevalier in Taiwan.
313716_15_ITEM1_P46_S7	Our ATA products compete with many smaller companies.
313716_15_ITEM1_P47_S0	The overall number of our competitors providing product solutions serving our target markets may increase.
313716_15_ITEM1_P47_S1	Also, the overall composition of companies with which we compete may change as we broaden our product offerings and the geographic markets we serve.
313716_15_ITEM1_P47_S2	As we expand into new market areas, we will face competition not only from our existing competitors but from other competitors as well, including existing companies with strong technological, marketing and sales positions in those markets.
313716_15_ITEM1_P47_S3	In addition, several of our competitors may have greater resources, including financial, technical, and engineering resources, than we do.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S0	Our machines within the MMS segment are produced around the world.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S1	We produce certain of our lathes, knee mills, and related products at our Elmira, New York plant.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S2	The Kellenberger and Voumard grinding machines and related products are manufactured at our St. Gallen, Switzerland plant and Hauser and Tschudin products are produced at our Biel, Switzerland facility.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S3	The Jones Shipman grinding machines are manufactured at our Leicester, England plant.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S4	The Usach grinding machines are manufactured at our Elgin, Illinois plant.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S5	We produce machining centers and lathes at our Hardinge Taiwan facility in Nan Tou, Taiwan and our Hardinge Precision Machinery (Jiaxing) Company, Ltd. facility in Jiaxing, China.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S6	The Company's Forkardt and Hardinge branded ATA segment products and solutions are engineered and produced in our plants located in Traverse City, Michigan, Elmira, New York, Kirchentellinsfurt, Germany, Noisy le Sec, France, and Hyderabad, India.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S7	We manufacture products from various raw materials, including cast iron, sheet metal, and bar steel.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S8	We purchase a number of components, sub-assemblies and assemblies from outside suppliers, including the computer and electronic components for our computer controlled lathes, grinding machines, and machining centers.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S9	There are multiple suppliers for virtually all of our raw material, components, sub-assemblies and assemblies and historically, we have not experienced a serious supply interruption.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S10	However, in 2011, because of the increase in demand driven by early 2011 worldwide order activity, producers of bearings, ball screws, and linear guides had difficulty meeting the rise in demand.
313716_15_ITEM1_P48_S11	Similar demand increase in the future could impact our production schedules.
313716_15_ITEM1_P49_S0	A major component of our computer controlled machines is the computer and related electronics package.
313716_15_ITEM1_P49_S1	We purchase these components from Fanuc Limited, a Japanese electronics company, Heidenhain, a German control supplier, Mitsubishi Electric, a Japanese electronics company, or from Siemens, another German control manufacturer.
313716_15_ITEM1_P49_S2	While we believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing from several other existing suppliers, and we occasionally do so for special orders, a disruption in the supply of the computer controls from one of our suppliers could cause us to experience a substantial disruption of our operations, depending on the circumstances at the time.
313716_15_ITEM1_P49_S3	We purchase parts from these suppliers under normal trade terms.
313716_15_ITEM1_P49_S4	There are no agreements with these suppliers to purchase minimum volumes per year.
313716_15_ITEM1_P50_S0	Our ongoing research and development program involves creating new products, modifying existing products to meet market demands, and redesigning existing products, both to add new functionality and to reduce the cost of manufacturing.
313716_15_ITEM1_P51_S0	The research and development departments throughout the world are staffed with experienced design engineers with varying levels of education, ranging from technical to doctoral degrees.
313716_15_ITEM1_P52_S0	The worldwide cost of research and development, all of which has been charged to cost of goods sold, amounted to $13.9 million , $12.5 million and $12.3 million , in 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
313716_15_ITEM1_P53_S0	Although we hold several patents with respect to certain of our products, we do not believe that our business is dependent to any material extent upon any single patent or group of patents.
313716_15_ITEM1_P54_S0	Hardinge's business and that of the machine tool industry in general, is cyclical.
313716_15_ITEM1_P54_S1	It is not subject to significant seasonal trends.
313716_15_ITEM1_P54_S2	However, our quarterly results are subject to fluctuation based on the timing of our shipments of machine tools, which are largely dependent upon customer delivery requirements.
313716_15_ITEM1_P54_S3	Given that a large percentage of our sales are from Asia, the impact of plant shutdowns in that region by us and our customers due to the celebration of the Lunar New Year holiday may impact the first quarter sales, income from operations, and net income, and result in the first quarter being the lowest quarter of the year.
313716_15_ITEM1_P55_S0	The ability to deliver products within a short period of time is an important competitive criterion.
313716_15_ITEM1_P55_S1	We must have inventory on hand to meet customers' delivery expectations, which for standard machines typically range from immediate to eight weeks delivery.
313716_15_ITEM1_P55_S2	Meeting this requirement is especially difficult with some of our products, where delivery is extended due to time associated with shipping on ocean-going vessels, depending on the location of the customer.
313716_15_ITEM1_P55_S3	This creates a need to have inventory of finished machines available in our major markets to serve our customers in a timely manner.
313716_15_ITEM1_P56_S0	We deliver many of our machine products within one to two months after the order.
313716_15_ITEM1_P56_S1	Some orders, especially multiple machine orders, are delivered on a turnkey basis with the machine or group of machines configured to make certain parts for the customer.
313716_15_ITEM1_P56_S2	This type of order often includes the addition of material handling equipment, tooling and specific programming.
313716_15_ITEM1_P56_S3	In those cases, the customer usually observes and inspects the parts being made on the machine at our facility before it is shipped and the timing of the sale is dependent upon the customer's schedule and acceptance.
313716_15_ITEM1_P56_S4	Therefore, sales from quarter-to-quarter can vary depending upon the timing of those customers' acceptances and the significance of those orders.
313716_15_ITEM1_P57_S0	We feel it is important, where practical, to provide readily available accessories and replacement parts for the machines we sell and we carry inventory at levels sufficient to meet these customer requirements.
313716_15_ITEM1_P58_S0	We believe that our current operations and our current uses of property, plant and equipment conform in all material respects to applicable laws and regulations in the various countries in which we conduct business.
313716_15_ITEM1_P59_S0	No material portion of our business is subject to government contracts.
313716_15_ITEM1_P60_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_15_ITEM1_P60_S1	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liability for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_15_ITEM1_P61_S0	Hazardous substances and adverse environmental effects have been identified with respect to real property we own and on adjacent parcels of real property.
313716_15_ITEM1_P62_S0	In particular, our Elmira, NY manufacturing facility is located within the Kentucky Avenue Wellfield on the National Priorities List of hazardous waste sites designated for cleanup by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_15_ITEM1_P63_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, NY.
313716_15_ITEM1_P64_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_15_ITEM1_P64_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_15_ITEM1_P64_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_15_ITEM1_P65_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice in February 2006, the Company had never been named as a potentially responsible party ("PRP") at the Site nor had the Company received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the Site.
313716_15_ITEM1_P65_S1	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond, and found no evidence that our operations or property have contributed or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_15_ITEM1_P65_S2	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot now be estimated with any degree of certainty.
313716_15_ITEM1_P66_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_15_ITEM1_P67_S0	The Company, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation and Toshiba America, Inc., (collectively, the "PRPs"), have agreed to voluntarily participate in the RI/FS by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_15_ITEM1_P67_S1	On September 29, 2006, the Director of Emergency and Remedial Response Division of the EPA, Region II, approved and executed the Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_15_ITEM1_P67_S2	The PRPs also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the cost of the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_15_ITEM1_P68_S0	The EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan in May of 2008.
313716_15_ITEM1_P68_S1	On September 7, 2011, the PRPs submitted the draft Remedial Investigation Report to the EPA and on January 10, 2013, the draft Feasibility Study was submitted to the EPA.
313716_15_ITEM1_P68_S2	The PRPs are preparing a revised draft feasibility study to update site information and to address issues raised by the EPA.
313716_15_ITEM1_P69_S0	The draft Feasibility Study identified alternative remedial actions with estimated life-cycle costs ranging from $0.7 million to $3.4 million .
313716_15_ITEM1_P69_S1	The proposed revised draft feasibility study is identifying an estimated life-cycle range from $0.9 million to $3.7 million .
313716_15_ITEM1_P69_S2	We estimate that our portion of the potential costs, based upon the proposed revised feasibility study, are estimated to range from $0.1 million to $0.5 million .
313716_15_ITEM1_P69_S3	Based on the current estimated costs of the various remedial alternatives now under consideration by the EPA, we have recorded a reserve of $0.2 million for the Company's share of remediation expenses at the Pond as of December 31, 2014 .
313716_15_ITEM1_P69_S4	This reserve is included in " Accrued expenses " in the Consolidated Balance Sheets .
313716_15_ITEM1_P70_S0	We believe, based upon information currently available that, except as described in the preceding paragraphs, we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation.
313716_15_ITEM1_P70_S1	Though the foregoing reflects the Company's current assessment as it relates to environmental remediation obligations, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to the Company.
313716_15_ITEM1_P71_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , Hardinge Inc. employed 1,478 persons, 493 of whom were located in the United States.
313716_15_ITEM1_P72_S0	Management believes that relations with our employees are good.
313716_15_ITEM1_P73_S0	Information related to foreign and domestic operations and sales is included in Note 17.
313716_15_ITEM1_P74_S0	"Segment Information" to the Consolidated Financial Statements contained in this Annual Report.
313716_15_ITEM1_P75_S0	Our strategy has been to diversify our sales and operations geographically so that the impact of economic trends in different regions can be balanced.
313716_15_ITEM1_P76_S0	The risks associated with conducting business on an international basis are discussed further in Item 1A. "Risk Factors".
313716_15_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The various risks related to the Company's business include the risks described below.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P0_S1	The business, financial condition or results of operations of Hardinge could be materially adversely affected by any of these risks.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The risks and uncertainties described below or elsewhere in this Form 10-K are not the only ones to which we are exposed.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also adversely affect our business and operations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P1_S2	If any of the matters included in the following risks were to occur, our business, financial condition, results of operations, cash flows or prospects could be materially adversely affected.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our customers' activity levels and spending for our products and services have been impacted by global economic conditions, especially deterioration in the credit markets.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P3_S0	For many of our customers, the purchase of our machines represents a significant capital expenditure.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P3_S1	For others, the purchase of our machines is a part of a larger improvement or expansion of manufacturing capability.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P3_S2	For all, the purchase represents a long term commitment of capital raised by incurrence of debt, issuance of equity or use of cash flow from operations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Global economic and financial difficulties across the world in recent years have been well documented.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Governments in Europe, Asia and the U.S. subsequently intervened in an effort to improve economic conditions.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P4_S2	These interventions may have reduced the overall impact of the crisis, but also created instability, uncertainty and doubt.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P4_S3	During this period, many of our customers experienced uncertain cash flows and reduced access to credit and equity markets, all of which made commitment to larger long term capital projects difficult.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P4_S4	While global conditions appear to have improved, similar conditions in the future could negatively impact our operating results.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Changes in general economic conditions and the cyclical nature of our business could harm our operating results.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is cyclical in nature, following the strength and weakness of the manufacturing economies in the geographic markets we serve.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P6_S1	As a result of this cyclicality, we have experienced, and in the future we can be expected to experience, significant fluctuations in sales and operating income, which may affect our business, operating results, financial condition and the market price of our common shares.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The following factors, among others, significantly influence demand for our products:
313716_15_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Changes in manufacturing capabilities in developing regions.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our competitive position and prospects for growth may be diminished if we are unable to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The machine tool industry is subject to technological change, rapidly evolving industry standards, changing customer requirements, and improvements in and expansion of product offerings, especially with respect to computer-controlled products.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Our ability to anticipate changes in technology, industry standards, customer requirements and product offerings by competitors, and to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market, will be significant factors in our ability to compete and grow.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Moreover, if technologies or standards used in our products become obsolete or fail to gain widespread commercial acceptance, our business would be materially adversely affected.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P10_S3	Developments by our competitors or others may render our products or technologies obsolete or noncompetitive.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P10_S4	Failure to effectively introduce new products or product enhancements on a timely basis could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We rely on a limited number of suppliers to obtain certain components, sub-assemblies, assemblies and products.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Delays in deliveries from or the loss of any of these suppliers may cause us to incur additional costs, result in delays in manufacturing and delivering our products or cause us to carry excess or obsolete inventory.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Some components, sub-assemblies, or assemblies we use in the manufacturing of our products are purchased from a limited number of suppliers.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Our purchases from these suppliers are generally not made pursuant to long-term contracts and are subject to additional risks associated with purchasing products internationally, including risks associated with potential import restrictions and exchange rate fluctuations, as well as changes in tax laws, tariffs, and freight rates.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Although we believe that our relationships with these suppliers are good, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain these products from these suppliers on satisfactory terms indefinitely.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P12_S3	The present economic environment could also pose the risk of one of these key suppliers going out of business, or cause delays in delivery times of critical components as business conditions rebound and demand increases.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing of components, sub-assemblies, assemblies or products from several other suppliers; however, a disruption in the supply from any of our suppliers could cause us to experience a material adverse effect on our operations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our business, financial condition, and results of operations could be adversely affected by the political and economic conditions of the countries in which we conduct business and other factors related to our international operations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We manufacture a substantial portion of our products overseas and sell our products throughout the world.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P15_S1	In 2014 , approximately 68% of our products were sold in countries outside of North America.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P15_S2	In addition, a majority of our employees are located outside of the United States.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Multiple factors relating to our international operations and to particular countries in which we operate could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations, and cash flows.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Health epidemics and other localized health risks.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Additionally, we must comply with complex foreign and U.S. laws and regulations, such as the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the U.K. Bribery Act and other local laws prohibiting corrupt payments to government officials, and anti-corruption regulations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P18_S1	Violations of these laws and regulations could result in fines and penalties, criminal sanctions, restrictions on our business conduct and on our ability to offer products in one or more countries, and could adversely affect our reputation, our ability to attract and retain employees, our international operations, our business and our operating results.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Although we have implemented policies and procedures designed to ensure compliance with these laws and regulations, there can be no assurance that our employees, contractors or agents, as well as those companies to which we outsource certain of our business operations, will not violate these policies.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Our business is highly competitive, and increased competition could reduce our sales, earnings and profitability.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P20_S0	The markets in which our machines and other products are sold are extremely competitive and highly fragmented.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P20_S1	In marketing our products, we compete primarily with other businesses on quality, reliability, price, value, delivery time, service, and technological characteristics.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P20_S2	We compete with a number of U.S., European, and Asian competitors, many of which are larger, have greater financial and other resources, and are supported by governmental or financial institution subsidies.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Increased competition could force us to lower our prices or to offer additional product features or services at a higher cost to us, which could reduce our earnings.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P21_S0	The greater financial resources or the lower amount of debt of certain of our competitors may enable them to commit larger amounts of capital in response to changing market conditions.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Certain competitors may also have the ability to develop product innovations that could put us at a disadvantage.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P21_S2	If we are unable to compete successfully against other manufacturers in our marketplace, we could lose customers, and our sales may decline.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P21_S3	There can also be no assurance that customers will continue to regard our products favorably, that we will be able to develop new products that appeal to customers, that we will be able to improve or maintain our profit margins on sales to our customers, or that we will be able to continue to compete successfully in our core markets.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P21_S4	While we believe our product lines compete effectively in their markets, we may not continue to do so.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Acquisitions could disrupt our operations and harm our operating results.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P23_S0	We may elect to increase our product offerings and the markets we serve through acquisitions of other companies, product lines, technologies and personnel.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Acquisitions involve numerous risks, including the following:
313716_15_ITEM1A_P24_S0	The potential loss of key employees of the acquired companies.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Acquisitions may also cause us to:
313716_15_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Acquisitions are inherently risky, and no assurance can be given that our recent or future acquisitions, if any, will be successful and will not have material adverse effect on our business, operating results or financial condition.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P26_S1	Failure to manage and successfully integrate acquisitions we make could harm our business and operating results in a material way.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P26_S2	Additionally, we may incur significant expenses related to potential acquisitions that are not completed.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Prior acquisitions have resulted in a wide range of outcomes, from successful introduction of new products, technologies, facilities, and personnel to an inability to do so.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Even when an acquired business has already developed and marketed products, there can be no assurance that product enhancements will be made in a timely fashion or that pre-acquisition due diligence will have identified all possible issues that might arise with respect to such products.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P28_S0	If we are unable to access additional capital on favorable terms, our liquidity, business, and results of operations could be adversely affected.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P29_S0	The ability to raise financial capital, either in public or private markets or through commercial banks, is critical to our current business and future growth.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Our business is generally working capital intensive requiring a long cash-out to cash-in cycle.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P29_S2	In addition, we will rely on the availability of longer-term debt financing or equity financing to make investments in new opportunities.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P29_S3	Our access to the financial markets could be adversely impacted by various factors including the following:
313716_15_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Volatility in our results that would substantially increase the cost of our capital.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We are subject to significant foreign exchange and currency risks that could adversely affect our operations and our ability to reinvest earnings from operations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Our international operations generate sales in a number of foreign currencies including British Pound Sterling ("GBP"), Chinese Renminbi ("CNY"), Euros ("EUR"), Indian Rupee ("INR"), New Taiwanese Dollars ("TWD"), and Swiss Francs ("CHF").
313716_15_ITEM1A_P32_S1	Therefore, our results of operations and financial condition are affected by fluctuations in exchange rates between these currencies and the U.S. dollar ("USD").
313716_15_ITEM1A_P32_S2	In addition, our purchases of components in CNY, EUR, TWD, CHF, and Japanese Yen ("JPY") are affected by inter-currency fluctuations in exchange rates.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We prepare our financial statements in USD in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ("US GAAP"), but a sizable portion of our revenue and operating expenses are in foreign currencies.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P33_S1	As a result, we are subject to significant risks, including:
313716_15_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Limitations on our ability to reinvest earnings from operations in one country to fund the capital needs of our operations in other countries.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Changes in exchange rates will result in increases or decreases in our revenues, costs, and earnings, and may also affect the book value of our assets located outside of the United States and the amount of our invested equity.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Although we may seek to decrease our currency exposure by engaging in hedges against significant transactions and balance sheet currency exposures where we deem it appropriate, we do not hedge against translation risks.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P35_S2	Though we monitor and manage our exposures to changes in currency exchange rates, and utilize currency exchange forward contracts and swaps to mitigate the impact of changes in currency values, changes in exchange rates nonetheless cannot always be predicted or hedged.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Consequently, we cannot assure that any efforts to minimize our risk to currency movements will be successful.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P35_S4	To the extent we sell our products in markets other than the market in which they are manufactured, currency fluctuations may result in our products becoming too expensive for customers in those markets.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Prices of some raw materials, especially steel and iron, fluctuate, which can adversely affect our sales, costs, and profitability.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P37_S0	We manufacture products with a relatively high iron casting or steel content, commodities for which worldwide prices fluctuate.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P37_S1	The availability of and prices for these and other raw materials are subject to volatility due to worldwide supply and demand forces, speculative actions, inventory levels, exchange rates, production costs, and anticipated or perceived shortages.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P37_S2	In some cases, raw material cost increases can be passed on to customers in the form of price increases; in other cases, they cannot.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P37_S3	If raw material prices increase and we are not able to charge our customers higher prices to compensate, it would adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Our expenditures for post-retirement pension obligations could be materially higher than we have predicted if our underlying assumptions prove to be incorrect or we are required to use different assumptions.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P39_S0	We provide defined benefit pension plans to eligible employees.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Our pension expense, the funding status of our plans and related charges in other comprehensive income (loss), and required contributions to our pension plans are directly affected by the value of plan assets, the projected rate of return on plan assets, the actual rate of return on plan assets and the actuarial assumptions we use to measure our defined benefit pension plan obligations, including the rate at which future obligations are discounted to a present value, or the discount rate.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P39_S2	Should the assets earn a return less than the assumed rate of return over time, it is likely that future pension expenses and funding requirements would increase.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P39_S3	Investment earnings in excess of the assumed rate of return may reduce future pension expenses and funding requirements.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P39_S4	A change in the discount rate would impact the funded status of our plans.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P39_S5	An increase to the discount rate would generally reduce the pension liability and future pension expense and, conversely, a lower discount rate would generally increase the pension liability and the future pension expense.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P40_S0	The market-related value of assets for our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan recognizes asset losses and gains over a five-year period, which we believe is consistent with the long-term nature of our pension obligations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P40_S1	As a result, the effect of changes in the market value of assets on our pension expense may be experienced in future years rather than fully reflected in the expense for the year immediately following the year in which the fluctuations actually occurred.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P41_S0	In addition, we cannot predict whether changing market or economic conditions, regulatory changes or other factors will increase our pension expenses or our funding obligations, diverting funds we would otherwise apply to other uses.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Contribution levels are largely contingent on asset returns and corporate bond yields.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P42_S1	If the performance of the assets in our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plan does not meet our expectations and/or corporate bond yields decrease, our future contributions to the plan could increase.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P43_S0	If we are unable to attract and retain skilled employees to work at our manufacturing facilities, our operations and growth prospects would be adversely impacted.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P44_S0	We conduct substantially all of our manufacturing operations in less densely populated urban areas, which, in many cases, may represent a relatively small market for skilled labor force.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Our continued success depends on our ability to attract and retain a skilled labor force at these locations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P44_S2	If we are not able to attract and retain the personnel we require, we may be unable to develop, manufacture, and market our products, or to expand our operations in a manner that best exploits market opportunities and capitalizes on our investment in our business.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P44_S3	This would materially adversely affect our business, operating results and financial condition.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Due to future technological changes, changes in market demand, or changes in market expectations, portions of our inventory may become obsolete or excessive.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P46_S0	The technologies incorporated in our products change and generally new versions of machines are brought to market in three to five year cycles.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P46_S1	The phasing out of an old product involves both estimating the amount of inventory to hold to satisfy the final demand for those machines as well as to satisfy future repair part needs.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P46_S2	Based on changing customer demand and expectations of delivery times for repair parts, we may find that we have either obsolete or excess inventory on hand.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P46_S3	Because of unforeseen changes in technology, market demand, or competition, we may have to write off unusable inventory at some time in the future, which may adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Major changes in the economic situation of our customer base could require us to write off significant portion of our receivables from customers.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P48_S0	In difficult economic periods, our customers lose work and find it difficult if not impossible to pay for products purchased from us.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P48_S1	Although appropriate credit reviews are done at the time of sale, rapidly changing economic conditions can have sudden impacts on our customers' ability to pay.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P48_S2	We run the risk of bad debt on existing time payment contracts and open accounts.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P48_S3	If we write off significant parts of our customer accounts or notes receivable because of unforeseen changes in their business condition, it would adversely affect our results of operations, financial condition, and cash flows.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P49_S0	If we suffer damage to our factories, facilities or distribution system due to catastrophe, our operations could be seriously harmed.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Our factories, facilities, and distribution system are subject to the risk of catastrophic loss due to fire, flood, terrorism, or other natural or man-made disasters.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P50_S1	In particular, several of our facilities could be subject to a catastrophic loss caused by earthquake due to their locations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Our facilities in Southeast Asia are located in areas with above average seismic activity.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P51_S1	If any of our facilities were to experience a catastrophic loss, it could disrupt our operations, delay production, shipments and revenue, and result in large expenses to repair or replace the facility.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P52_S0	Our business operations may be adversely affected by interruptions or failures of our technology information systems .
313716_15_ITEM1A_P53_S0	We are dependent on multiple information technology systems throughout our company to operate our business.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P53_S1	An interruption or failure of our information technology systems, or a cybersecurity attack, such as unauthorized access, malicious software or other intrusion, may result in a significant disruption of our business operations and materially increase our costs of operations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P54_S0	We rely in part on independent distributors and the loss of these distributors could adversely affect our business.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P55_S0	In addition to our direct sales force, we depend on the services of independent distributors and agents to sell our products and provide service and aftermarket support to our customers.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P55_S1	We support an extensive distributor and agent network worldwide.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P55_S2	In 2014 , approximately 66% of our sales were through distributors and agents.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P55_S3	No distributor accounted for more than 5% of our consolidated sales in 2014 .
313716_15_ITEM1A_P56_S0	Rather than serving as passive conduits for delivery of product, many of our distributors are active participants in the sale and support of our products.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P56_S1	Many of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our customers.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P56_S2	In addition, the distribution agreements we have are typically cancelable by the distributor after a relatively short notice period.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P56_S3	The loss of a substantial number of our distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our customers could reduce our sales and profits.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P57_S0	We rely on estimated forecasts of our customers' needs, and inaccuracies in such forecasts could adversely affect our business.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P58_S0	We generally sell our products pursuant to individual purchase orders instead of long-term purchase commitments.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P58_S1	Therefore, we rely on estimated demand forecasts, based upon input from our customers and the general economic environment, to determine how much material to purchase and product to manufacture.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Because our sales are based on purchase orders, our customers may cancel, delay, or otherwise modify their purchase commitments with little or no consequence to them and with little or no notice to us.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P59_S1	For these reasons, we generally have limited visibility regarding our customers' actual product needs.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P59_S2	The quantities or timing required by our customers for our products could vary significantly.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P59_S3	Whether in response to changes affecting the industry or a customer's specific business pressures, any cancellation, delay, or other modification in our customers' orders could significantly reduce our revenue, cause our operating results to fluctuate from period to period and make it more difficult for us to predict our revenue.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P59_S4	In the event of a cancellation or reduction of a customer order, we may not have enough time to reduce inventory purchases or our workforce to minimize the effect of the lost revenue on our business.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P59_S5	Order cancellations typically average approximately 2% of sales.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P60_S0	Cancellations could vary significantly during times of global economic uncertainty.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P61_S0	We could face potential product liability claims relating to products we manufacture, which could result in us having to expend significant time and expense to defend these claims and to pay material amounts in damages or settlement.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P62_S0	We face a business risk of exposure to product liability claims in the event that the use of our products is alleged to have resulted in injury or other adverse effects.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P62_S1	We currently maintain product liability insurance coverage; however, such insurance does not cover all types of damages that could be assessed against us in a product liability claim and the coverage amounts are subject to certain limitations under the applicable policies.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P62_S2	We may not be able to obtain product liability insurance on acceptable terms in the future.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P62_S3	Product liability claims can be expensive to defend and can divert the attention of management and other personnel for long periods of time, regardless of the ultimate outcome.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P62_S4	An unsuccessful product liability defense could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P62_S5	In addition, we believe our business depends on the strong brand reputation we have developed.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P62_S6	In the event that our reputation is damaged, we may face difficulty in maintaining our pricing positions with respect to some of our products, which would reduce our sales and profitability.

313716_15_ITEM1A_P76_S0	Our certificate of incorporation and bylaws provide that our Board of Directors, currently consisting of seven members, is divided into three classes of directors, with each class consisting of two or three directors, and with the classes serving staggered three-year terms.

313716_15_ITEM1A_P77_S0	Removal of Directors and Filling of Vacancies.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P77_S1	Our certificate of incorporation provides that a member of our Board of Directors may be removed only for cause and upon the affirmative vote of the holders of 75% of the securities entitled to vote at an election of directors.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P77_S2	Newly created directorships and Board of Director vacancies resulting from retirement, death, removal or other causes may be filled only by a majority vote of the then remaining directors.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P77_S3	Accordingly, it is more difficult for shareholders, including those holding a majority of our outstanding shares, to force an immediate change in the composition of our Board of Directors.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P78_S0	Supermajority Voting Provisions for Certain Business Combinations.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P78_S1	Our certificate of incorporation requires the affirmative vote of at least 75% of all of the securities entitled to vote and at least 75% of shareholders who are not Major Shareholders (defined as 10% beneficial holders) in order to effect certain mergers, sales of assets or other business combinations involving the Company.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P78_S2	These provisions could have the effect of delaying, deferring or preventing a change of control of the Company.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P79_S0	In addition, as a New York corporation we are subject to provisions of the New York Business Corporation Law which may make it more difficult for a third party to acquire and exercise control over us pursuant to a tender offer or request or invitation for tenders.
313716_15_ITEM1A_P79_S1	These provisions could have the effect of deterring or delaying changes in incumbent management, proxy contests or changes in control.

313716_15_ITEM6_P1_S3	In March 2014, the Company recognized $0.2 million of additional consideration as a result of final working capital adjustments.
313716_15_ITEM7_P0_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metalcutting turning machines, grinding machines, vertical machining centers, and repair parts related to those machines.
313716_15_ITEM7_P0_S1	The Company also engineers and supplies high precision, standard and specialty workholding devices, and other machine tool accessories.
313716_15_ITEM7_P0_S2	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_15_ITEM7_P0_S3	We are geographically diversified with manufacturing facilities in China, France, Germany, India, Switzerland, Taiwan, the United States ( U.S. ), and the United Kingdom ( U.K. ), with sales to most industrialized countries.
313716_15_ITEM7_P0_S4	Approximately 68% of our 2014 sales were to customers outside of North America, 71% of our 2014 products sold were manufactured outside of North America, and 67% of our employees in 2014 were employed outside of North America.
313716_15_ITEM7_P1_S0	Metrics on machine tool market activity monitored by our management include world machine tool shipments, as reported annually by Gardner Publications in the Metalworking Insiders Report, and metal-cutting machine orders, as reported by the Association of Manufacturing Technology, the primary industry group for U.S. machine tool manufacturers.
313716_15_ITEM7_P1_S1	Other closely followed U.S. market indicators are tracked to determine activity levels in U.S. manufacturing plants that are prospective customers for our products.
313716_15_ITEM7_P1_S2	One such measurement is the Purchasing Managers Index, as reported by the Institute for Supply Management.
313716_15_ITEM7_P1_S3	Another measurement is capacity utilization of U.S. manufacturing plants, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board.
313716_15_ITEM7_P1_S4	Similar information regarding machine tool shipments and economic indicators in foreign countries is published by trade associations, government agencies, and economic services in those countries.
313716_15_ITEM7_P2_S0	Non-machine sales, which include collets, chucks, accessories, repair parts and service revenue, accounted for approximately 34% of overall sales in 2014 and are an important part of our business due to an installed base of thousands of machines, and the growing needs demanded by specialty workholding applications.
313716_15_ITEM7_P2_S1	In the past, sales of these products and services have not fluctuated on a year-to-year basis as significantly as the sales of our machines have from time to time, but demand for these products and services typically track the direction of the related machine metrics.
313716_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	Other key performance indicators are geographic distribution of net sales ( sales ) and net orders ( orders ), gross profit as a percent of sales, income from operations, working capital changes, and debt level trends.
313716_15_ITEM7_P3_S1	In an industry where constant product technology development has led to an average model life of three to five years, effectiveness of technological innovation and development of new products are also key performance indicators.
313716_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	We are exposed to financial market risk resulting from changes in interest and foreign currency rates.
313716_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	Global economic conditions and related disruptions within the financial markets have also increased our exposure to the possible liquidity and credit risks of our counterparties.
313716_15_ITEM7_P4_S2	We believe we have sufficient liquidity to fund our foreseeable business needs, including cash and cash equivalents, cash flows from operations, our bank financing arrangements, and equity financing arrangements.
313716_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	We monitor the third-party depository institutions that hold our cash and cash equivalents.
313716_15_ITEM7_P5_S1	Our emphasis is primarily on safety of principal.
313716_15_ITEM7_P5_S2	Our cash and cash equivalents are diversified among counterparties to minimize exposure to any one of these entities.
313716_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	We are subject to credit risks relating to the ability of counterparties of hedging transactions to meet their contractual payment obligations.
313716_15_ITEM7_P6_S1	The risks related to creditworthiness and non-performance has been considered in the fair value measurements of our foreign currency forward exchange contracts.
313716_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	We expect that some of our customers and vendors may experience difficulty in maintaining the liquidity required to buy inventory or raw materials.
313716_15_ITEM7_P7_S1	We continue to monitor our customers financial condition in order to mitigate the risk associated with our ability to collect on our accounts receivable.
313716_15_ITEM7_P8_S0	Foreign currency exchange rate changes can be significant to reported results for several reasons.
313716_15_ITEM7_P9_S0	Our primary competitors, particularly for the most technologically advanced products, are now largely manufacturers in Japan, Germany, Switzerland, Korea, and Taiwan, which causes the worldwide valuation of their respective currencies to be central to competitive pricing in all of our markets.
313716_15_ITEM7_P9_S1	The major functional currencies of our subsidiaries are the British Pound Sterling ( GBP ), Chinese Renminbi ( CNY ), Euro ( EUR ), New Taiwanese Dollar ( TWD ), and Swiss Franc ( CHF ).
313716_15_ITEM7_P9_S2	Under US GAAP, results of foreign subsidiaries are translated into U.S. Dollars ( USD ) at the average exchange rate during the periods presented.
313716_15_ITEM7_P9_S3	Period-to-period changes in the exchange rate between their local currency and the USD may affect comparative data significantly.
313716_15_ITEM7_P9_S4	We also purchase computer controls and other components from suppliers throughout the world, with purchase costs reflecting currency changes.
313716_15_ITEM7_P10_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2014 , foreign currency fluctuations did not have a material impact on sales when compared to 2013 .

313716_15_ITEM7_P13_S0	Sales for the year ended December 31, 2014 were $311.6 million , a decrease of $17.8 million , or 5.4% when compared to the prior year.
313716_15_ITEM7_P13_S1	The leading cause of the overall decline in sales as compared to the prior year was primarily a result of lower sales volume at Usach of $17.9 million , due to the unusually strong shipments in 2013 that resulted from the significant backlog acquired at the end of 2012, combined with an overall decline in sales of the Company's other machine solutions of $15.4 million .
313716_15_ITEM7_P13_S2	These decreases were offset in part by the full year impact of the acquisition of Forkardt, which contributed $15.3 million in incremental sales during the year ended December 31, 2014 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P14_S0	North America sales were $100.9 million and $109.5 million , respectively, for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , a decrease of $8.6 million , or 7.8% .
313716_15_ITEM7_P14_S1	The current year decrease is driven by the reduction in Usach sales as mentioned above of $8.2 million , combined with reduced sales levels of the company s other grinding machines of $7.7 million , partially offset by the full year impact of the acquisition of Forkardt, which contributed $6.2 million in incremental sales during the year ended December 31, 2014 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P15_S0	Europe sales were $103.1 million and $100.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively, an increase of $2.9 million , or 2.9% .
313716_15_ITEM7_P15_S1	The full year impact of the acquisition of Forkardt contributed $7.7 million in incremental sales, offset by lower turning and milling machine sales of $5.3 million in 2014 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P16_S0	Asia sales were $107.7 million and $119.9 million for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively, a decrease of $12.2 million , or 10.2% .
313716_15_ITEM7_P16_S1	This decrease was primarily due to the decrease in Usach sales of $9.7 million , combined with an overall decrease in other grinding machine sales of $1.9 million , along with an unfavorable impact from currency exchange rate fluctuations of $1.1 million .
313716_15_ITEM7_P16_S2	The full year impact of the acquisition of Forkardt partially offset the overall decrease in sales, contributing $1.4 million in incremental sales.
313716_15_ITEM7_P17_S0	Demand from customers in China is the key driver of the performance of the machine tool industry, and while recent machine tool industry data from China is reporting a current year decline in demand, Hardinge has been able to maintain sales volume levels in the primary customer segments that it serves.
313716_15_ITEM7_P18_S0	Sales of machines accounted for approximately 66% of the consolidated sales for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared to 72% in 2013 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P18_S1	Sales of non-machine products and services, primarily consisting of collets, chucks, accessories, repair parts, and service revenue, accounted for 34% of the consolidated sales for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared to 28% in 2013 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P18_S2	The increase in the portion of non-machine sales over total sales during the year ended December 31, 2014 when compared to 2013 was primarily driven by sales activity from the acquired Forkardt business.

313716_15_ITEM7_P19_S1	The decline in gross margin was primarily a result of lower production levels in the Company s grinding facilities, which resulted in lower factory absorption.

313716_15_ITEM7_P20_S1	SG A for the year ended December 31, 2014 included $4.3 million of incremental SG A expense from our Forkardt acquisition, offset in part by the impact of $2.2 million of acquisition related expenses included in prior year, $0.6 million of additional SG A from our Voumard acquisition, and $0.4 million of unfavorable impact from changes in currency exchange rates.

313716_15_ITEM7_P64_S0	Summary of Cash Flows for the Year Ended December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 :
313716_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2014 , we generated $3.2 million net cash from operating activities.
313716_15_ITEM7_P65_S1	The net cash generated was driven by a net loss (as adjusted for depreciation and amortization expense and impairment loss), an increase in accounts payable due to timing of purchases and payment activity, and decreases in other assets.
313716_15_ITEM7_P65_S2	These cash inflows were offset in part by an increase in customer receivables due to the timing of sales and collection activity, a decrease in accrued expenses, primarily as a result of lower accrued commissions and bonuses as a result of lower current year sales, a decrease in customer deposits due to timing of shipments and new orders received, and an increase in inventories based on orders and associated production levels.
313716_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013 , we generated $25.8 million net cash in operating activities.
313716_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	The generation of net cash was primarily driven by a decrease in inventory levels, combined with net income, as adjusted for impairment charges and depreciation and amortization expense.
313716_15_ITEM7_P66_S2	The cash inflow was offset in part by a decrease in accrued expenses and accounts payable, primarily as a result of slowing business activities as a result of lower order levels, and a decrease in customer deposits, driven by the fulfillment of customer orders.
313716_15_ITEM7_P67_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2012 , we generated $23.4 million net cash in operating activities.
313716_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	The generation of net cash was primarily driven by collections on customer receivables, reduced inventory levels, and releases of restricted cash.
313716_15_ITEM7_P68_S1	The cash inflow was offset in part by a decrease in accounts payable and accrued expenses, which decreased due to slowing business activities as a result of lower order levels, and lower customer deposits, which decreased as customer orders were fulfilled and delivered.
313716_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	Net cash used in investing activities was $8.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P69_S1	The primary uses of cash was for the acquisitions of Forkardt India and Voumard totaling $5.7 million , combined with capital expenditures during the year of $3.2 million , which were made primarily for maintenance capital purchases.
313716_15_ITEM7_P69_S2	These cash outflows were offset in part by additional consideration of $0.2 million received during the current year as a result of the final working capital adjustments on the sale of the Forkardt Switzerland operations, and proceeds from the sale of fixed assets made during the ordinary course of business of $0.2 million .
313716_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	Net cash used in investing activities was $31.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P70_S1	In May of 2013, we used $34.3 million net cash to acquire Forkardt.
313716_15_ITEM7_P70_S2	In addition, we used $3.9 million in cash for capital expenditures, which were made primarily for maintenance capital purchases.
313716_15_ITEM7_P70_S3	These cash outflows were offset in part by $6.3 million in proceeds generated from Forkardt Swiss business divestiture.
313716_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	Net cash used in investing activities was $15.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
313716_15_ITEM7_P71_S1	In December of 2012, we used $8.8 million net cash to acquire Usach.
313716_15_ITEM7_P71_S2	In addition, we used $7.6 million in cash for capital expenditures, primarily for the expansion of manufacturing facilities in Switzerland and China, combined with purchases made during the ordinary course of business.

313716_15_ITEM7_P72_S1	Cash used was primarily attributable to $9.3 million of payments on long-term debt due to the mandatory principal payments in connection with the at-the-market stock offering program, pay down of debt with a portion of the proceeds from the sale of the Forkardt Switzerland operations, and normal scheduled payment activity, combined with a $7.5 million payment of contingent consideration in connection with the Usach acquisition, and year-to-date dividends paid of $1.0 million .
313716_15_ITEM7_P72_S2	These cash outflows were offset in part by $5.7 million of proceeds from sale of common stock in connection with the at-the-market stock offering sales agreement entered into on August 9, 2013.
