313716_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	We are a global designer, manufacturer and distributor of machine tools, specializing in precision computer numerically controlled metalcutting machines and workholding technology solutions.
313716_17_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Company has the following direct and indirect wholly owned subsidiaries: North America:
313716_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	Traverse City, Michigan Hardinge Technology Systems, Inc.
313716_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	St. Gallen, Switzerland Hardinge Holdings B.V.
313716_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	Amsterdam, Netherlands Hardinge Machine Tools B.V.
313716_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	St. Gallen, Switzerland Asia and Other:
313716_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	Hyderabad, India Forkardt Precision Machinery (Shanghai) Co., Ltd.
313716_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	Hong Kong, People's Republic of China Hardinge Machine (Shanghai) Co., Ltd.
313716_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	We have manufacturing facilities located in China, Switzerland, Taiwan, Germany, France, India, the United Kingdom ("U.K.") and the United States ("U.S.").
313716_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	We manufacture the majority of the products we sell.
313716_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metalcutting turning machines, grinding machines, machining centers, and repair parts related to those machines.
313716_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	The Company also engineers and supplies high precision, standard and specialty workholding devices, and other machine tool accessories.
313716_17_ITEM1_P12_S2	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	The Company has two unique business segments: Metalcutting Machine Solutions ("MMS") and Aftermarket Tooling and Accessories ("ATA").
313716_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	This segment includes operations related to grinding, turning, and milling, as discussed below, and related repair parts.
313716_17_ITEM1_P14_S1	The products are considered to be capital goods with sales prices ranging from approximately forty thousand dollars for some standard products to approximately two million dollars for specialized grinding machines or other specialty built turnkey systems of multiple machines.
313716_17_ITEM1_P14_S2	Sales are subject to economic cycles and, because they are most often purchased to add manufacturing capacity, the cycles can be severe with customers delaying purchases during down cycles and then aggressively requiring machine deliveries during up cycles.
313716_17_ITEM1_P14_S3	Machines are purchased to a lesser extent during down cycles, as customers are looking for productivity improvements or they have new products that require new machining capabilities.
313716_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	We have been a manufacturer of industrial-use high precision and general precision turning machine tools since 1890.
313716_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	Turning machines, or lathes, are power-driven machines used to remove material from either bar stock or a rough-formed part by moving multiple cutting tools against the surface of a part rotating at very high speeds in a spindle mechanism.
313716_17_ITEM1_P16_S1	The multi-directional movement of the cutting tools allows the part to be shaped to the desired dimensions.
313716_17_ITEM1_P16_S2	On parts produced by our machines, those dimensions are often measured in millionths of an inch.
313716_17_ITEM1_P16_S3	We consider Hardinge to be a leader in the field of producing machines capable of consistently and cost-effectively producing parts to very close dimensions.
313716_17_ITEM1_P17_S0	Grinding is a machining process in which a part's surface is shaped to closer tolerances with a rotating abrasive wheel or tool.
313716_17_ITEM1_P17_S1	Grinding machines can be used to finish parts of various shapes and sizes.
313716_17_ITEM1_P17_S2	The grinding machines of our Kellenberger subsidiary are used to grind the inside and outside diameters of cylindrical parts.
313716_17_ITEM1_P17_S3	Such grinding machines are typically used to provide a more exact finish on a part that has been partially completed on a lathe.
313716_17_ITEM1_P17_S4	The Kellenberger grinding machines are generally purchased by the same type of customers as other Hardinge equipment and further our ability to be a primary source for our customers.
313716_17_ITEM1_P18_S0	Our Kellenberger precision grinding technology is complemented by our Hauser, Tschudin, Usach, and Voumard grinding brands.
313716_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	Hauser machines are jig grinders used to make demanding contour components, primarily for tool and mold-making applications.
313716_17_ITEM1_P19_S1	Tschudin product technology is focused on the specialized grinding of cylindrical parts when the customer requires high volume production.
313716_17_ITEM1_P19_S2	Our Tschudin machines are generally equipped with automatic loading and unloading mechanisms for the part being machined.
313716_17_ITEM1_P19_S3	These loading and unloading mechanisms significantly reduce machine operator involvement in the production process.
313716_17_ITEM1_P20_S0	Usach and Voumard machines are high quality internal diameter cylindrical grinding systems used in production and job shop environments.
313716_17_ITEM1_P21_S0	Machining centers are designed to remove material from stationary, prismatic, or box-like parts of various shapes with rotating tools that are capable of milling, drilling, tapping, reaming and routing.
313716_17_ITEM1_P21_S1	Machining centers have mechanisms that automatically change tools based on commands from an integrated computer control without the assistance of an operator.
313716_17_ITEM1_P21_S2	Machining centers are generally purchased by the same customers who purchase other Hardinge equipment.
313716_17_ITEM1_P21_S3	We supply a broad line of machining centers under our Bridgeport brand name addressing a range of sizes, speeds, and powers.
313716_17_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our machines generally use commands from an integrated computer to control the movement of cutting tools, grinding wheels, part positioning, and in the case of turning and grinding machines, the rotation speeds of the part being shaped.
313716_17_ITEM1_P22_S1	The computer control enables the operator to program operations such as part rotation, tooling selection, and tooling movement for a specific part and then stores that program in memory for future use.
313716_17_ITEM1_P22_S2	The machines are able to produce parts while left unattended when connected to automatic bar-feeding, robotics equipment, or other material handling devices designed to supply raw materials and remove machined parts from the machine.
313716_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	New products are critical to our growth plans.
313716_17_ITEM1_P23_S1	We gain access to new products through internal product development, acquisitions, joint ventures, license agreements, and partnerships.
313716_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	offering, to take advantage of new technologies available to us, and to replace older models nearing the end of their respective product life cycles.
313716_17_ITEM1_P24_S1	These technologies generally allow our machines to run at higher speeds and with more power, thus increasing their efficiency.
313716_17_ITEM1_P24_S2	Customers routinely replace old machines with newer machines that can produce parts faster and with less time to set up the machine when converting from one type of part to another.
313716_17_ITEM1_P24_S3	Generally, our machines can be used to produce parts from all of the standard ferrous and non-ferrous metals, as well as plastics, composites, and exotic materials.
313716_17_ITEM1_P25_S0	We focus on products and solutions for companies making parts from hard to machine materials with hard to sustain close tolerances and hard to achieve surface finishes that may be hard to hold in the machine.
313716_17_ITEM1_P25_S1	We believe that with our high precision and super precision lathes, our grinding machines, and our rugged machining centers, combined with our accessory products and our technical expertise, we are uniquely qualified to be the supplier of choice for customers manufacturing to demanding specifications.
313716_17_ITEM1_P26_S0	Multiple options are available on many of our machines, which allows customers to customize their machines to their specific operating performance and cost objectives.
313716_17_ITEM1_P26_S1	We produce machines for stock with popular option combinations for immediate delivery, as well as design and produce machines to specific customer requirements.
313716_17_ITEM1_P26_S2	In addition to our machines, we provide the necessary tooling, accessories, and support services to assist customers in maximizing their return on investment.
313716_17_ITEM1_P27_S0	The sale of repair parts is important to our business.
313716_17_ITEM1_P28_S0	Certain parts on machines wear out, fail, or need to be replaced due to misuse over time.
313716_17_ITEM1_P28_S1	Customers will buy parts from us throughout the life of the machine, which typically extends over many years.
313716_17_ITEM1_P28_S2	There are thousands of machines in operation in the world for which we provide those repair parts and in many cases the parts are available exclusively from us.
313716_17_ITEM1_P29_S0	We offer various warranties on our equipment and consider post-sale support to be a critical element of our business.
313716_17_ITEM1_P29_S1	Warranties on machines typically extend for twelve months after purchase.
313716_17_ITEM1_P29_S2	Services provided include operation and maintenance training, in-field maintenance, and in-field repair.
313716_17_ITEM1_P29_S3	We offer these post sales support services on a paid basis throughout the life of the machine.
313716_17_ITEM1_P29_S4	In territories covered by distributors, this support and service is offered through the distributor.
313716_17_ITEM1_P30_S0	This segment includes products that are purchased by manufacturers throughout the lives of their machines.
313716_17_ITEM1_P30_S1	The selling prices of these units are relatively low per piece with prices ranging from forty dollars on high volume collets to two hundred thousand dollars or more for specialty chucks.
313716_17_ITEM1_P30_S2	While considered to be consumable, these products are more durable in nature, with replacement due to wear over time.
313716_17_ITEM1_P31_S0	Our products are used on all types and brands of machine tools, not limited to our own.
313716_17_ITEM1_P32_S0	Sales levels are affected by manufacturing cycles, but not as severely as capital goods lines.
313716_17_ITEM1_P32_S1	While customers may not purchase high cost machines during a down cycle, their factories are operating with their existing equipment and therefore accessories are still needed as they wear out or they are needed for a change in production requirements.
313716_17_ITEM1_P33_S0	The two primary product groups in ATA are collets and chucks.
313716_17_ITEM1_P34_S0	Collets are cone-shaped metal sleeves used for holding circular or rod-like pieces in a lathe or other machine that provide effective part holding and accurate part location during machining operations.
313716_17_ITEM1_P35_S0	Chucks are a specialized clamping device used to hold an object with radial symmetry, especially a cylindrical object.
313716_17_ITEM1_P35_S1	It is most commonly used to hold a rotating work piece.
313716_17_ITEM1_P35_S2	Some of our specialty chucks can also hold irregularly shaped objects that lack radial symmetry.
313716_17_ITEM1_P36_S0	While our products are known for accuracy and durability, they are consumable in nature.
313716_17_ITEM1_P37_S0	We offer an extensive line of workholding and toolholding solutions that are available in tens of thousands of shapes and sizes to meet unique customer application needs.
313716_17_ITEM1_P37_S1	These solutions can be used on virtually all types and brands of metalcutting machines, as well as non-traditional uses in many industrial applications.
313716_17_ITEM1_P37_S2	The Company continues to explore opportunities to expand this business organically and through acquisitions.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S0	We sell our products in most of the industrialized countries of the world through a combination of distributors, agents, and manufacturers' representatives.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S1	In certain areas of China, France, Germany, India, North America, and the United Kingdom, we have also used a direct sales force for portions of our product lines.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S2	Generally, our distributors have an exclusive right to sell our products in a defined geographic area.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S3	Our distributors operate as independent businesses and purchase products from us at discounted prices for their customers, while agents and representatives sell products on our behalf and receive commissions on sales.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S4	Our discount schedule is adjusted to reflect the level of pre and post sales support offered by our distributors.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S5	Our direct sales personnel earn a fixed salary plus commission.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S6	Sales through distributors are made only on standard commercial open account terms or through letters of credit.
313716_17_ITEM1_P38_S7	Distributors generally take title to products upon shipment from our facilities and do not have any special return privileges.
313716_17_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our standard ATA products are sold through direct telephone orders and via our web site at www.shophardinge.com.
313716_17_ITEM1_P39_S1	Custom or special solutions are sold through direct sales and agents.
313716_17_ITEM1_P39_S2	In most cases, we are able to package and ship in-stock tooling, accessories, and repair parts within 24 hours of receiving orders.
313716_17_ITEM1_P39_S3	We can package and ship items with heavy demand within a few hours.
313716_17_ITEM1_P39_S4	In other parts of the world, these products are sold on either a direct sales basis or through distributor arrangements.
313716_17_ITEM1_P40_S0	We promote our products through advertising in trade publications, web presences, email newsletters, and participation in industry trade shows.
313716_17_ITEM1_P40_S1	In addition, we market our non-machine products and capabilities through the publication of general catalogs and other targeted catalogs, which we distribute to existing and prospective customers.
313716_17_ITEM1_P40_S2	We have a considerable presence on the internet at www.hardinge.com and www.forkardt.com, where customers can obtain information about our products and place orders for accessories, tooling, knee mill products and repair parts.
313716_17_ITEM1_P41_S0	A substantial portion of our end use customers are small and medium-sized independent job shops, which in turn sell machined parts to their industrial customers.
313716_17_ITEM1_P41_S1	Industries directly and indirectly served by us include aerospace, automotive, computer, communications, consumer-electronics, construction equipment, defense, energy, farm equipment, medical equipment, recreational equipment, and transportation.
313716_17_ITEM1_P42_S0	No single customer or related group of customers accounted for more than 5% of our consolidated sales in 2016 or 2015 .
313716_17_ITEM1_P42_S1	While valuing our relationship with each customer, we do not believe that the loss of any single customer, or any few customers, would have an adverse material effect on our business.
313716_17_ITEM1_P43_S0	In our industry, the barriers to entry for competition vary based on the level of product performance required.
313716_17_ITEM1_P43_S1	For the products with the highest performance in terms of accuracy and productivity, the barriers are generally technical in nature.
313716_17_ITEM1_P43_S2	For basic products, often the barriers are not technical; they are tied to product availability, competitive price position, and an effective distribution model that offers the pre and post sales support required by customers.
313716_17_ITEM1_P44_S0	Another significant barrier in the global machine tool industry is the high level of working capital that is required to operate the business.
313716_17_ITEM1_P45_S0	We compete in various sectors of the machine tool market within the products of turning, milling, grinding, tooling and accessories.
313716_17_ITEM1_P45_S1	We compete with multiple companies in each market sector we serve.
313716_17_ITEM1_P45_S2	The primary competitive factors in the marketplace for our machine tools are reliability, price, delivery time, service, and technological characteristics.
313716_17_ITEM1_P45_S3	Our management considers our segment of the industry to be extremely competitive.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S0	There are many manufacturers of machine tools in the world.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S1	They can be categorized by the size of material their products can machine and the precision level their products can achieve.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S2	For our high precision, multi-tasking turning and milling equipment, competition comes primarily from companies such as DMG Mori Seiki, Mazak, and Okuma.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S3	Competition in our more standard turning and milling equipment comes, in part, from those companies as well as Doosan, which is based in South Korea, and Haas, which is based in the U.S., as well as many Taiwanese companies.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S4	Our internal and outer diameter (ID/OD) cylindrical grinding machines compete primarily with products manufactured by Studer, a Swiss company, as well as Toyoda and Shigiya, which are based in Japan.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S5	Our Hauser jig grinding machines compete primarily with products manufactured by Moore Tool, which is based in the U.S., and some Japanese suppliers.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S6	Our surface grinding machines compete with products manufactured by Okamoto in Japan and Chevalier in Taiwan.
313716_17_ITEM1_P46_S7	Our ATA products compete with many products manufactured by smaller companies.
313716_17_ITEM1_P47_S0	The overall number of our competitors providing product solutions serving our target markets may increase.
313716_17_ITEM1_P47_S1	Also, the overall composition of companies with which we compete may change as we broaden our product offerings and the geographic markets we serve.
313716_17_ITEM1_P47_S2	As we expand into new market areas, we will face competition not only from our existing competitors but from other competitors as well, including existing companies with strong technological, marketing and sales positions in those markets.
313716_17_ITEM1_P47_S3	In addition, several of our competitors may have greater resources, including financial, technical, and engineering resources, than we do.
313716_17_ITEM1_P48_S0	Our machines within the MMS segment are produced around the world.
313716_17_ITEM1_P48_S1	We produce certain of our lathes, knee mills, and related products at our Elmira, New York plant.
313716_17_ITEM1_P48_S2	The Kellenberger and Voumard grinding machines and related products are manufactured at our St. Gallen, Switzerland plant and Hauser and Tschudin products are produced at our Biel, Switzerland facility.
313716_17_ITEM1_P48_S3	The Jones Shipman grinding machines are manufactured at our Leicester, England plant.
313716_17_ITEM1_P48_S4	The Usach grinding machines are manufactured at our Elgin, Illinois plant.
313716_17_ITEM1_P48_S5	We produce machining centers and lathes at our Hardinge Taiwan facility in Nan Tou, Taiwan and our Hardinge Precision Machinery (Jiaxing) Company, Ltd. facility in Jiaxing, China.
313716_17_ITEM1_P48_S6	The Company's Forkardt and Hardinge branded ATA segment products and solutions are engineered and produced in our plants located in Traverse City, Michigan, Elmira, New York, Reutlingen, Germany, Noisy le Sec, France, Hyderabad, India and Shanghai, China.
313716_17_ITEM1_P49_S0	We manufacture products from various raw materials, including cast iron, sheet metal, and bar steel.
313716_17_ITEM1_P49_S1	We purchase a number of components, sub-assemblies and assemblies from outside suppliers, including the computer and electronic components for our computer controlled lathes, grinding machines, and machining centers.
313716_17_ITEM1_P49_S2	There are multiple suppliers for virtually all of our raw material, components, sub-assemblies and assemblies and historically, we have not experienced a serious supply interruption.
313716_17_ITEM1_P49_S3	However, in 2011, because of the increase in demand driven by early 2011 worldwide order activity, producers of bearings, ball screws, and linear guides had difficulty meeting the rise in demand.
313716_17_ITEM1_P49_S4	Similar demand increase in the future could impact our production schedules.
313716_17_ITEM1_P50_S0	A major component of our computer controlled machines is the computer and related electronics package.
313716_17_ITEM1_P50_S1	We purchase these components from Fanuc Limited, a Japanese electronics company, Heidenhain, a German control supplier, Mitsubishi Electric, a Japanese electronics company, or from Siemens, another German control manufacturer.
313716_17_ITEM1_P50_S2	While we believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing from several other existing suppliers, and we occasionally do so for special orders, a disruption in the supply of the computer controls from one of our suppliers could cause us to experience a substantial disruption of our operations, depending on the circumstances at the time.
313716_17_ITEM1_P50_S3	We purchase parts from these suppliers under normal trade terms.
313716_17_ITEM1_P50_S4	There are no agreements with these suppliers to purchase minimum volumes per year.
313716_17_ITEM1_P51_S0	Our ongoing research and development program involves creating new products, modifying existing products to meet market demands, and redesigning existing products, both to add new functionality and to reduce the cost of manufacturing.
313716_17_ITEM1_P51_S1	Our research and development departments throughout the world are staffed with experienced design engineers with varying levels of education, ranging from technical to doctoral degrees.
313716_17_ITEM1_P52_S0	The worldwide cost of research and development, all of which has been charged to operating expense, amounted to $13.5 million , $14.1 million and $13.9 million , in 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
313716_17_ITEM1_P53_S0	Although we hold several patents with respect to certain of our products, we do not believe that our business is dependent to any material extent upon any single patent or group of patents.
313716_17_ITEM1_P54_S0	Hardinge's business and that of the machine tool industry in general, is cyclical.
313716_17_ITEM1_P54_S1	It is not subject to significant seasonal trends.
313716_17_ITEM1_P54_S2	However, our quarterly results are subject to fluctuation based on the timing of our shipments of machine tools, which are largely dependent upon customer delivery requirements.
313716_17_ITEM1_P54_S3	Given that a large percentage of our sales are from Asia, the impact of plant shutdowns in that region by us and our customers due to the celebration of the Lunar New Year holiday may impact the first quarter sales, income from operations, and net income, and result in the first quarter being the lowest quarter of the year.
313716_17_ITEM1_P55_S0	The ability to deliver products within a short period of time is an important competitive criterion.
313716_17_ITEM1_P55_S1	We must have inventory on hand to meet customers' delivery expectations, which for standard machines typically range from immediate to eight weeks delivery.
313716_17_ITEM1_P55_S2	Meeting this requirement is especially difficult with some of our products, where delivery is extended due to time associated with shipping on ocean-going vessels, depending on the location of the customer.
313716_17_ITEM1_P55_S3	This creates a need to have inventory of finished machines available in our major markets to serve our customers in a timely manner.
313716_17_ITEM1_P56_S0	We deliver many of our machine products within one to two months after the order.
313716_17_ITEM1_P56_S1	Some orders, especially multiple machine orders, are delivered on a turnkey basis with the machine or group of machines configured to make certain parts for the customer.
313716_17_ITEM1_P56_S2	This type of order often includes the addition of material handling equipment, tooling and specific programming.
313716_17_ITEM1_P56_S3	In those cases, the customer usually observes and inspects the parts being made on the machine at our facility before shipment so the timing of the sale is dependent upon the customer's schedule and acceptance.
313716_17_ITEM1_P56_S4	Lead time for these types of orders, especially grinding machines, can range from six to eight months.
313716_17_ITEM1_P56_S5	Therefore, sales from quarter-to-quarter can vary depending upon the timing of customers' acceptances and the significance of those orders.
313716_17_ITEM1_P57_S0	We feel it is important, where practical, to provide readily available accessories and replacement parts for the machines we sell and we carry inventory at levels sufficient to meet these customer requirements.
313716_17_ITEM1_P58_S0	We believe that our current operations and our current uses of property, plant and equipment conform in all material respects to applicable laws and regulations in the various countries in which we conduct business.
313716_17_ITEM1_P59_S0	No material portion of our business is subject to government contracts.
313716_17_ITEM1_P60_S0	Our operations are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to environmental matters.
313716_17_ITEM1_P60_S1	Certain environmental laws can impose joint and several liability for releases or threatened releases of hazardous substances upon certain statutorily defined parties regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the original activity or disposal.
313716_17_ITEM1_P61_S0	Hazardous substances and adverse environmental effects have been identified with respect to real property we own and on adjacent parcels of real property.
313716_17_ITEM1_P62_S0	In particular, our Elmira, NY manufacturing facility is located within the Kentucky Avenue Wellfield on the National Priorities List of hazardous waste sites designated for cleanup by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") because of groundwater contamination.
313716_17_ITEM1_P63_S0	The Kentucky Avenue Wellfield Site (the "Site") encompasses an area which includes sections of the Town of Horseheads and the Village of Elmira Heights in Chemung County, NY.
313716_17_ITEM1_P64_S0	In February 2006, the Company received a Special Notice Concerning a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study ("RI/FS") for the Koppers Pond (the "Pond") portion of the Site.
313716_17_ITEM1_P64_S1	The EPA documented the release and threatened release of hazardous substances into the environment at the Site, including releases into and in the vicinity of the Pond.
313716_17_ITEM1_P64_S2	The hazardous substances, including metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, have been detected in sediments in the Pond.
313716_17_ITEM1_P65_S0	Until receipt of this Special Notice in February 2006, the Company had never been named as a potentially responsible party ("PRP") at the Site nor had the Company received any requests for information from the EPA concerning the Site.
313716_17_ITEM1_P65_S1	Environmental sampling on our property within this Site under supervision of regulatory authorities had identified off-site sources for such groundwater contamination and sediment contamination in the Pond, and found no evidence that our operations or property have contributed or are contributing to the contamination.
313716_17_ITEM1_P65_S2	We have notified all appropriate insurance carriers and are actively cooperating with them, but whether coverage will be available has not yet been determined and possible insurance recovery cannot be estimated with any degree of certainty at this time.
313716_17_ITEM1_P66_S0	A substantial portion of the Pond is located on our property.
313716_17_ITEM1_P67_S0	The Company, along with Beazer East, Inc., the Village of Horseheads, the Town of Horseheads, the County of Chemung, CBS Corporation and Toshiba America, Inc., (collectively, the "PRP's"), agreed to voluntarily participate in the RI/FS by signing an Administrative Settlement Agreement and Order of Consent on September 29, 2006.
313716_17_ITEM1_P67_S1	On September 29, 2006, the Director of Emergency and Remedial Response Division of the EPA, Region II, approved and executed the Agreement on behalf of the EPA.
313716_17_ITEM1_P67_S2	The PRP's also signed a PRP Member Agreement, agreeing to share the costs associated with the RI/FS study on a per capita basis.
313716_17_ITEM1_P68_S0	The EPA approved the RI/FS Work Plan in May of 2008.
313716_17_ITEM1_P68_S1	In July of 2012 the PRP's submitted a Remedial Investigation (RI) to respond to EPA issues raised in the initial draft RI.
313716_17_ITEM1_P68_S2	In January 2016, the PRP's submitted a draft Feasibility Study (FS), also to respond to issues raised by the EPA about previous drafts of the FS.
313716_17_ITEM1_P68_S3	In July 2016, the EPA announced its proposed remediation plan based on an alternative put forth in a July 2016 Woodruff Curran FS with an estimated total clean-up phase cost of $1.9 million.
313716_17_ITEM1_P69_S0	The preferred remedy consists of the placement of a continuous six-inch thick soil and sand cap, including a geotextile membrane to act as a demarcation layer, over Koppers Pond.
313716_17_ITEM1_P69_S1	The preferred remedy includes long-term monitoring and institutional controls.
313716_17_ITEM1_P69_S2	After a public comment period the EPA concluded this RI phase of its process documented in a letter in December 2016.
313716_17_ITEM1_P70_S0	The Company has recorded a reserve of $0.3 million for its estimated related liability, assuming all of the PRP's would continue to share costs equally in the clean-up phase of the project.
313716_17_ITEM1_P70_S1	Based on our understanding including discussions with our experts, it is possible that the PRP's may change and/or the relative split of costs may be different for this final phase of the project.
313716_17_ITEM1_P70_S2	However, this will not be known for quite some time, and this ongoing estimate of 7 split equally is viewed as the best possible estimate at the moment.
313716_17_ITEM1_P70_S3	This reserve is reported in Accrued expenses on the Consolidated Balance Sheets .
313716_17_ITEM1_P71_S0	We believe, based upon information currently available that, except as described in the preceding paragraphs, we will not have material liabilities for environmental remediation.
313716_17_ITEM1_P71_S1	Though the foregoing reflects the Company's current assessment as it relates to environmental remediation obligations, it is possible that future remedial requirements or changes in the enforcement of existing laws and regulations, which are subject to extensive regulatory discretion, will result in material liabilities to the Company.
313716_17_ITEM1_P72_S0	As of December 31, 2016 , Hardinge Inc. employed 1,451 persons, 463 of whom were located in the United States.
313716_17_ITEM1_P73_S0	Management believes that relations with our employees are good.

313716_17_ITEM1_P76_S0	Our strategy has been to diversify our sales and operations geographically so that the impact of economic trends in different regions can be balanced.
313716_17_ITEM1_P77_S0	The risks associated with conducting business on an international basis are discussed further in Item 1A. "Risk Factors".
313716_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Current and potential shareholders should carefully consider the risks described below.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These are the risks and uncertainties we believe are most important for shareholders to consider.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us, which we currently deem immaterial or which are similar to those faced by other companies in our industry or business in general, may also impair our business operations.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Any of these factors, many of which are beyond our control, could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, operating results, cash flow, and stock price.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Changes in general economic conditions and the cyclical nature of our business could harm our operating results.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our business is cyclical in nature, following the strength and weakness of the manufacturing economies in the geographic markets we serve.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P2_S1	As a result of this cyclicality, we have experienced, and in the future we can be expected to experience, significant fluctuations in sales and operating income, which may affect our business, operating results, financial condition and the market price of our common shares.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The following factors, among others, significantly influence demand for our products:
313716_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Changes in manufacturing capabilities in developing regions.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Our business is highly competitive, and increased competition could reduce our sales, earnings and profitability.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The markets in which our machines and other products are sold are extremely competitive and highly fragmented.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P6_S1	In marketing our products, we compete primarily with other businesses on quality, reliability, price, value, delivery time, service, and technological characteristics.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We compete with a number of U.S., European, and Asian competitors, many of which are larger, have greater financial and other resources, and are supported by governmental or financial institution subsidies.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Increased competition could force us to lower our prices or to offer additional product features or services at a higher cost to us, which could reduce our earnings.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The greater financial resources or the lower amount of debt of certain of our competitors may enable them to commit larger amounts of capital in response to changing market conditions.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Certain competitors may also have the ability to develop product innovations that could put us at a disadvantage.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P7_S2	If we are unable to compete successfully against other manufacturers in our marketplace, we could lose customers, and our sales may decline.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P7_S3	There can also be no assurance that customers will continue to regard our products favorably, that we will be able to develop new products that appeal to customers, that we will be able to improve or maintain our profit margins on sales to our customers, or that we will be able to continue to compete successfully in our core markets.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P7_S4	While we believe our product lines compete effectively in their markets, we may not continue to do so.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Our competitive position and prospects for growth may be diminished if we are unable to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P9_S0	The machine tool industry is subject to technological change, rapidly evolving industry standards, changing customer requirements, and improvements in and expansion of product offerings, especially with respect to computer-controlled products.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Our ability to anticipate changes in technology, industry standards, customer requirements and product offerings by competitors, and to develop and introduce new and enhanced products on a timely basis that are accepted in the market, will be significant factors in our ability to compete and grow.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P9_S2	Moreover, if technologies or standards used in our products become obsolete or fail to gain widespread commercial acceptance, our business would be materially adversely affected.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P9_S3	Developments by our competitors or others may render our products or technologies obsolete or noncompetitive.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P9_S4	Failure to effectively introduce new products or product enhancements on a timely basis could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our business, financial condition, and results of operations could be adversely affected by the political and economic conditions of the countries in which we conduct business and other factors related to our international operations.

313716_17_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We manufacture products with a relatively high iron casting or steel content, commodities for which worldwide prices fluctuate.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P15_S1	The availability of, and prices for, these and other raw materials are subject to volatility due to worldwide supply and demand forces, speculative actions, inventory levels, exchange rates, production costs, and anticipated or perceived shortages.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P15_S2	In some cases, raw material cost increases can be passed on to customers in the form of price increases; in other cases, they cannot.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P15_S3	If raw material prices increase and we are not able to charge our customers higher prices to compensate, it would adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We rely on a limited number of suppliers to obtain certain components, sub-assemblies, assemblies and products.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Delays in deliveries from or the loss of any of these suppliers may cause us to incur additional costs, result in delays in manufacturing and delivering our products or cause us to carry excess or obsolete inventory.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Some components, sub-assemblies, or assemblies we use in the manufacturing of our products are purchased from a limited number of suppliers.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Our purchases from these suppliers are generally not made pursuant to long-term contracts and are subject to additional risks associated with purchasing products internationally, including risks associated with potential import restrictions and exchange rate fluctuations, as well as changes in tax laws, tariffs, and freight rates.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Although we believe that our relationships with these suppliers are good, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain these products from these suppliers on satisfactory terms indefinitely.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We believe that design changes could be made to our machines to allow sourcing of components, sub-assemblies, assemblies or products from several other suppliers; however, a disruption in the supply from any of our suppliers could cause us to experience a material adverse effect on our operations.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We rely in part on independent distributors and the loss of these distributors could adversely affect our business.

313716_17_ITEM1A_P20_S1	We maintain an extensive distributor and agent network worldwide.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P20_S2	In 2016, approximately 30% of our sales were through distributors.

313716_17_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Many of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our customers.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P21_S2	In addition, the distribution agreements we have are typically cancelable by the distributor after a relatively short notice period.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P21_S3	The loss of a substantial number of our distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our customers could reduce our sales and profits.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P22_S0	If we are unable to attract and retain skilled employees to work at our manufacturing facilities our operations and growth prospects would be adversely impacted.

313716_17_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Our continued success depends on our ability to attract and retain a skilled labor force at these locations.

313716_17_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We may be adversely affected by attacks on information technology systems as well as other cybersecurity risks and business disruptions.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Our business may be impacted by disruptions to our own or third party information technology systems, which may result from attacks on or failures of such infrastructure.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P32_S1	Cybersecurity risks are evolving and include, but are not limited to, attacks on our information technology systems and attacks on the information technology systems of third parties in attempts to gain unauthorized access to our confidential or other proprietary information or information relating to our employees, customers and other third parties.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P32_S2	Cybersecurity risks may also include attacks targeting the security, integrity and/or reliability of the hardware, software and information installed, stored or transmitted in our products, including after the purchase of those products and when they are incorporated into our customers facilities and/or infrastructure.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P32_S3	Such attacks could potentially result in disruptions to systems, unauthorized release of confidential or otherwise protected information and corruption of data.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P32_S4	We believe that we have adopted appropriate measures to mitigate potential risks to our technology, products, services and operations from these potential attacks.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P32_S5	However, given the unpredictability of the timing, nature and scope of such attacks or other disruptions, we could potentially be subject to production downtimes, operational delays, other damaging effects on our operations or our ability to provide products and services to our customers, the unintended release of confidential or otherwise protected information, misappropriation, destruction or corruption of data, security breaches, other improper use of our or third party systems, networks or products, financial losses from remedial actions, loss of business or potential liability, and/or damage to our reputation, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our operating results.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our customers' activity levels and spending for our products and services have been impacted by global economic conditions, especially deterioration in the credit markets.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P34_S0	For many of our customers, the purchase of our machines represents a significant capital expenditure.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P34_S1	For others, the purchase of our machines is a part of a larger improvement or expansion of manufacturing capability.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P34_S2	For all, the purchase represents a long term commitment of capital raised by incurrence of debt, issuance of equity or use of cash flow from operations.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We rely on estimated forecasts of our customers' needs and inaccuracies in such forecasts could adversely affect our business.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We generally sell our products pursuant to individual purchase orders instead of long-term purchase commitments.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P36_S1	Therefore, we rely on estimated demand forecasts, based upon input from our customers and the general economic environment, to determine how much material to purchase and product to manufacture.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Because our sales are based on purchase orders, our customers may cancel, delay, or otherwise modify their purchase commitments with little or no consequence to them and with little or no notice to us.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P37_S1	For these reasons, we generally have limited visibility regarding our customers' actual product needs.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P37_S2	The quantities or timing required by our customers for our products could vary significantly.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P37_S3	Whether in response to changes affecting the industry or a customer's specific business pressures, any cancellation, delay, or other modification in our customers' orders could significantly reduce our revenue, causing our operating results to fluctuate from period to period and make it more difficult for us to predict our revenue.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P37_S4	In the event of a cancellation or reduction of a customer order, we may not have enough time to reduce inventory purchases or our workforce to minimize the effect of the lost revenue on our business.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P37_S5	Order cancellations typically average approximately 2% of sales.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Cancellations could vary significantly during times of global economic uncertainty.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Major changes in the economic situation of our customer base could require us to write off significant portion of our receivables from customers.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P40_S0	In difficult economic periods, our customers lose work and find it difficult if not impossible to pay for products purchased from us.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Although appropriate credit reviews are done at the time of sale, rapidly changing economic conditions can have sudden impacts on customers' ability to pay.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P40_S2	We run the risk of bad debt with customers on open account.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P40_S3	If we write off significant parts of our customer accounts receivable because of unforeseen changes in their business condition, it would adversely affect our results of operations, financial condition, and cash flows.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Anti-takeover provisions in our charter documents and under New York law may discourage a third party from acquiring us.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Certain provisions of our certificate of incorporation and bylaws may have the effect of discouraging a third party from making a proposal to acquire us and, as a result, may inhibit a change in control of the Company under circumstances that could give the shareholders the opportunity to realize a premium over the then-prevailing market price of our common shares.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Our certificate of incorporation and bylaws provide that our Board of Directors, currently consisting of nine members, is divided into three classes of directors, with each class consisting of three directors, and with the classes serving staggered three-year terms.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P43_S1	This classification of the directors has the effect of making it more difficult for shareholders, including those holding a majority of our outstanding shares, to force an immediate change in the composition of our Board of Directors.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Removal of Directors and Filling of Vacancies.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Our certificate of incorporation provides that a member of our Board of Directors may be removed only for cause and upon the affirmative vote of the holders of 75% of the securities entitled to vote at an election of directors.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P44_S2	Newly created directorships and Board of Director vacancies resulting from retirement, death, removal or other causes may be filled only by a majority vote of the then remaining directors.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P44_S3	Accordingly, it is more difficult for shareholders, including those holding a majority of our outstanding shares, to force an immediate change in the composition of our Board of Directors.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Supermajority Voting Provisions for Certain Business Combinations.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P45_S1	Our certificate of incorporation requires the affirmative vote of at least 75% of all of the securities entitled to vote and at least 75% of shareholders who are not Major Shareholders (defined as 10% beneficial holders) in order to effect certain mergers, sales of assets or other business combinations involving the Company.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P45_S2	These provisions could have the effect of delaying, deferring or preventing a change of control of the Company.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P46_S0	In addition, as a New York corporation we are subject to provisions of the New York Business Corporation Law which may make it more difficult for a third party to acquire and exercise control over us pursuant to a tender offer or request or invitation for tenders.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P46_S1	These provisions could have the effect of deterring or delaying changes in incumbent management, proxy contests or changes in control.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Our certificate of incorporation authorizes the issuance of shares of blank check preferred stock.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P48_S0	Our certificate of incorporation provides that our Board of Directors is authorized to issue from time to time, without further stockholder approval, up to 2,000,000 shares of preferred stock (the Board of Directors has already designated 250,000 of such shares of preferred stock as Series A Preferred Stock) in one or more series and to fix and designate the rights, preferences, privileges and restrictions of the preferred stock, including dividend rights, conversion rights, voting rights, redemption rights and terms of redemption and liquidation preferences.
313716_17_ITEM1A_P48_S1	Such shares of preferred stock could have preferences over our common stock with respect to dividends and liquidation rights.

313716_17_ITEM7_P0_S0	We supply high precision computer controlled metalcutting turning machines, grinding machines, vertical machining centers, and repair parts related to those machines.
313716_17_ITEM7_P0_S1	The Company also engineers and supplies high precision, standard and specialty workholding devices, and other machine tool accessories.
313716_17_ITEM7_P0_S2	We believe our products are known for accuracy, reliability, durability and value.
313716_17_ITEM7_P0_S3	We are geographically diversified with manufacturing facilities in China, France, Germany, India, Switzerland, Taiwan, the United States ( U.S. ), and the United Kingdom ( U.K. ), with sales to most industrialized countries.
313716_17_ITEM7_P0_S4	Approximately 68% of our 2016 sales were to customers outside of North America, 71% of our 2016 products sold were manufactured outside of North America, and 68% of our employees in 2016 were employed outside of North America.
313716_17_ITEM7_P1_S0	Metrics on machine tool market activity monitored by our management include world machine tool shipments, as reported annually by Gardner Publications in the Metalworking Insiders Report, and metal-cutting machine orders, as reported by the Association of Manufacturing Technology, the primary industry group for U.S. machine tool manufacturers.
313716_17_ITEM7_P1_S1	Other closely followed U.S. market indicators are tracked to determine activity levels in U.S. manufacturing plants that are prospective customers for our products.
313716_17_ITEM7_P1_S2	One such measurement is the Purchasing Managers Index, as reported by the Institute for Supply Management.
313716_17_ITEM7_P1_S3	Another measurement is capacity utilization of U.S. manufacturing plants, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board.
313716_17_ITEM7_P1_S4	Similar information regarding machine tool shipments and economic indicators in foreign countries is published by trade associations, government agencies, and economic services in those countries.
313716_17_ITEM7_P2_S0	Non-machine sales, which include collets, chucks, accessories, repair parts and service revenue, accounted for approximately 33% of overall sales in 2016 and are an important part of our business due to an installed base of thousands of machines, and the growing needs demanded by specialty workholding applications.
313716_17_ITEM7_P2_S1	In the past, sales of these products and services have not fluctuated on a year-to-year basis as significantly as the sales of our machines have from time to time, but demand for these products and services typically track the direction of the related machine metrics.
313716_17_ITEM7_P3_S0	Other key performance indicators are geographic distribution of net sales ( sales ), gross profit as a percent of sales, income from operations, working capital changes, and debt level trends.
313716_17_ITEM7_P3_S1	In an industry where constant product technology development has led to an average model life of three to five years, effectiveness of technological innovation and development of new products are also key performance indicators.

313716_17_ITEM7_P79_S0	There were no significant changes to accounting policies in 2016.
313716_17_ITEM7_P80_S0	The preparation of our financial statements requires the application of a number of accounting policies, which are described in the notes to the financial statements.
313716_17_ITEM7_P80_S1	These policies require the use of assumptions or estimates, which, if interpreted differently under different conditions or circumstances, could result in material changes to the reported results.
313716_17_ITEM7_P80_S2	Following is a discussion of those accounting policies that were reviewed with our audit committee, and which we feel are most susceptible to such interpretation.
313716_17_ITEM7_P81_S0	We assess the collectability of our trade accounts receivable using a combination of methods.
313716_17_ITEM7_P81_S1	We review large individual accounts for evidence of circumstances that suggest a collection problem might exist.
313716_17_ITEM7_P81_S2	Such situations include, but are not limited to, the customer's past history of payments, its current financial condition as evidenced by credit ratings, financial statements or other sources, and recent collection activities.
313716_17_ITEM7_P82_S0	We provide a reserve for losses based on current payment trends in the economies where we hold concentrations of receivables and provide a reserve for what we believe to be the most likely risk of collectability.
313716_17_ITEM7_P82_S1	In order to make these allowances, we rely on assumptions regarding economic conditions, equipment resale values, and the likelihood that previous performance will be indicative of future results.
313716_17_ITEM7_P83_S0	We use a number of assumptions and estimates in determining the value of our inventory.
313716_17_ITEM7_P84_S0	An allowance is provided for the value of inventory quantities of specific items that are deemed to be excessive based on an annual review of past usage and anticipated future usage.
313716_17_ITEM7_P84_S1	While we feel this is the most appropriate methodology for determining excess quantities, the possibility exists that customers will change their buying habits in the future should their own requirements change.
313716_17_ITEM7_P85_S0	Changes in metalcutting technology can render certain products obsolete or reduce their market value.
313716_17_ITEM7_P85_S1	We continually evaluate changes in technology and adjust our products and inventory carrying values accordingly, either by write-off or by price reductions.
313716_17_ITEM7_P85_S2	Changes in market conditions and realizable selling prices for our machines could reduce the value of our inventory.
313716_17_ITEM7_P85_S3	We continually evaluate the carrying value of our machine inventory against the estimated selling price, less related costs to sell and adjust our inventory carrying values accordingly.
313716_17_ITEM7_P85_S4	However, the possibility exists that a future technological development, currently unanticipated, might affect the marketability of specific products produced by the Company.
313716_17_ITEM7_P86_S0	We include in the cost of our inventories a component to cover the estimated cost of manufacturing overhead activities associated with production of our products.
313716_17_ITEM7_P87_S0	We believe that being able to offer immediate delivery on many of our products is critical to our competitive success.
313716_17_ITEM7_P87_S1	Likewise, we believe that maintaining an inventory of service parts, with a particular emphasis on purchased parts, is especially important to support our policy of maintaining serviceability of our products.
313716_17_ITEM7_P87_S2	Consequently, we maintain significant inventories of repair parts on many of our machine models, some of which are no longer in production.
313716_17_ITEM7_P87_S3	Our ability to accurately determine which parts are needed to maintain this serviceability is critical to our success in managing this element of our business.
313716_17_ITEM7_P88_S0	We review goodwill for impairment at least annually or when indicators of impairment are present.
313716_17_ITEM7_P88_S1	These events or circumstances could include a significant long-term adverse change in the business climate, poor indicators of operating performance, or a sale or disposition of a significant portion of a reporting unit.
313716_17_ITEM7_P89_S0	We test goodwill at the reporting unit level, which is one level below our operating segments.
313716_17_ITEM7_P89_S1	We identify our reporting units by assessing whether the components of our operating segments constitute businesses for which discrete financial information is available and segment management regularly reviews the operating results of those components.
313716_17_ITEM7_P90_S0	We also aggregate components that have similar economic characteristics into single reporting units (for example, similar products and/or services, similar long-term financial results, product processes, classes of customers, etc.).
313716_17_ITEM7_P90_S1	We have three reporting units, only one of which currently has goodwill.
313716_17_ITEM7_P90_S2	Our ATA reporting unit had goodwill totaling $6.6 million as of December 31, 2016 .
313716_17_ITEM7_P91_S0	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, we proceed to a two-step impairment test.
313716_17_ITEM7_P92_S0	Our annual goodwill impairment review was performed as of October 1, 2016.
313716_17_ITEM7_P92_S1	As a result of this assessment we determined that the fair value of our reporting units that have goodwill exceeded the carrying value.
313716_17_ITEM7_P93_S0	We regularly review the recent results and projected future results of our operations, as well as other relevant factors, to reconfirm the likelihood that existing deferred tax assets in each tax jurisdiction would be fully recoverable.
313716_17_ITEM7_P94_S0	A valuation allowance is established when it is more likely than not that all or a portion of deferred tax assets are not expected to be realized.
313716_17_ITEM7_P94_S1	The Company assesses all available positive and negative evidence to determine whether a valuation allowance is needed.
313716_17_ITEM7_P94_S2	Positive and negative evidence to be considered includes scheduled reversals of deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income, tax-planning strategies, and results of recent operations.
313716_17_ITEM7_P94_S3	Supporting a conclusion that a valuation allowance is not necessary is difficult when there is negative evidence such as cumulative losses in recent years.
313716_17_ITEM7_P95_S0	A full valuation allowance is maintained on the tax benefits of the U.S. net deferred tax assets and it is expected that a full valuation allowance on future tax benefits will be recorded until an appropriate level of profitability in the U.S. is sustained.
313716_17_ITEM7_P95_S1	A valuation allowance is also maintained on the U.K., German, Dutch, and Canadian deferred tax assets related to tax loss carryforwards in those jurisdictions, as well as all other deferred tax assets of those entities.
313716_17_ITEM7_P96_S0	The calculation of the tax liabilities requires significant judgment, the use of estimates and the interpretation and application of complex tax laws.
313716_17_ITEM7_P97_S0	The provision for income taxes reflects a combination of income earned and taxed in the U.S. and the various states, as well as federal and provincial jurisdictions in Switzerland, U.K., Canada, Germany, France, the Netherlands, China, Taiwan, and India.
313716_17_ITEM7_P97_S1	Jurisdictional tax law changes, increases or decreases in permanent differences between book and tax items, accruals or adjustments of accruals for tax contingencies or valuation allowances, and the change in the mix of earnings from these taxing jurisdictions all affect the overall effective tax rate.
313716_17_ITEM7_P98_S0	We sponsor various defined benefit pension plans, defined contribution plans, and two postretirement benefit plans, all as described in Note 14.
313716_17_ITEM7_P99_S0	"Employee Benefits" to the Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 8 of this Form 10-K.
313716_17_ITEM7_P100_S0	The calculation of our plan expenses and liabilities require the use of a number of critical accounting estimates.
313716_17_ITEM7_P100_S1	Changes in the assumptions can result in different plan expense and liability amounts, and actual experience can differ from the assumptions.
313716_17_ITEM7_P100_S2	We believe that the most critical assumptions are the discount rate and the expected rate of return on plan assets.
313716_17_ITEM7_P101_S0	We annually review the discount rate to be used for retirement plan liabilities.
313716_17_ITEM7_P102_S0	In the U.S., we use bond pricing models based on high grade U.S. corporate bonds constructed to match the projected liability benefit payments.
313716_17_ITEM7_P102_S1	We discounted our future plan liabilities for our U.S. plan using rates of 4.39% and 4.75% at our plan measurement dates of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
313716_17_ITEM7_P102_S2	We discounted our future plan liabilities for our foreign plans using rates appropriate for each country, which resulted in blended rates of 0.89% and 1.21% at their measurement dates of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
313716_17_ITEM7_P103_S0	A change in the discount rate can have a significant effect on retirement plan obligations.
313716_17_ITEM7_P103_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension obligations by approximately $13.5 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P103_S2	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension obligations by approximately $11.2 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P103_S3	A decrease of one percent in the discount rate would increase the Swiss pension obligations by approximately $19.4 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P103_S4	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease the Swiss pension obligations by approximately $15.9 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P104_S0	A change in the discount rate can also have an effect on retirement plan expense.
313716_17_ITEM7_P104_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. 2017 pension expense by approximately $0.09 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P104_S2	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease U.S. 2017 pension expense by approximately $0.03 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P104_S3	A decrease of one percent would increase the Swiss pension expense by approximately $1.5 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P104_S4	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease the Swiss pension expense by approximately $1.8 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P105_S0	The expected rate of return on plan assets varies based on the investment mix of each particular plan and reflects the long-term average rate of return expected on funds invested or to be invested in each pension plan to provide for the benefits included in the pension liability.
313716_17_ITEM7_P105_S1	We review our expected rate of return annually based upon information available to us at that time, including the current level of expected returns on risk free investments (primarily government bonds in each market), the historical level of the risk premium associated with the other asset classes in which the portfolio is invested, and the expectations for future returns of each asset class.
313716_17_ITEM7_P105_S2	The expected return for each asset class is then weighted based on the asset allocation to develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption.
313716_17_ITEM7_P106_S0	return during fiscal 2017 is 7.50%, which is the same rate used for fiscal 2016 .
313716_17_ITEM7_P106_S1	For our foreign plans, we used rates of return appropriate for each country which resulted in a blended expected rate of return of 3.14% for fiscal 2017 , compared to 3.91% for fiscal 2016 .
313716_17_ITEM7_P107_S0	A change in the expected return on plan assets can also have a significant effect on retirement plan expense.
313716_17_ITEM7_P107_S1	For example, a decrease of one percent would increase U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.8 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P107_S2	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease U.S. pension expense by approximately $0.8 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P107_S3	A decrease of one percent would increase the Swiss pension expense by approximately $0.9 million.
313716_17_ITEM7_P107_S4	Conversely, an increase of one percent would decrease the Swiss pension expense by approximately $0.9 million.
